Task.Action: Where applicable, check supply voltage and that polarities are correct.
Task.Notes: If supply voltages are not found, check to see if supply is via a controller. Refer to manufacturer's data sheet.

Task.Action: Where applicable, check for presence and that polarity is correct.
Task.Notes: Refer to manufacturer's data sheet. The previous note can also apply to the control signal.

Task.Item: 3. Auxiliary control functions i.e. on/off switches, frost protection, position indicators.
Task.Action: Check operation.
Task.Notes: See relevant manufacturer's data sheet and auxiliary section.

Task.Action: Check to prove actuator will mechanically open/close valve or damper to its working limits.
Task.Notes: Ensure that the actuator is returned to the 'auto' position after check is completed.

Task.Action: Check for correct position for application when power fails.
Task.Notes: This will entail interrupting the power to the actuator at a convenient point. Do not forget to reconnect the supply when the check is complete.

Task.Item: 6. Reaction to safety signal i.e. fire/smoke.
Task.Action: Check that the actuator assumes correct position (if applicable).
Task.Notes: See relevant control/sensor section for this operation.

Task.Action: Check for correct response to signal.
Check
Check for signs of leakage of fluid around actuator seals. Change seals if necessary.

Legislation.Content: BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.

Introduction.Content: Pneumatic actuators do not have an electrical supply but function by air pressure alone. Therefore should there be any loss in pressure, the performance of the actuator (and thus the whole system) will be impaired making it inefficient.
Introduction.Notes: Electro/pneumatic controllers will have an electrical supply to them and therefore all necessary precautions will need to be taken to isolate supplies.

Task.Action: Check operation between actuator and controller.
Task.Notes: With a variance in pressure from the controller, the actuator will modulate.

Task.Action: Check condition of glands and seals. Check pipework for deterioration.
Check that any filters are clear of water and oil (filter may not be local to the actuator).
Task.Notes: If water and/or oil is present, trace pipe work back to identify the source of the water or oil and rectify the problem

Task.Action: Check to ensure actuator achieves stroke limits. Check for minimum/maximum setting.
Task.Notes: Ensure manual override is reset to correct automatic position.

Task.Item: 5. Linkage assembly, i.e. nuts bolts, spring, valve stem or damper assembly.
Task.Action: Check  a) wear  b) security  c) corrosion
As recommended.
Task.Notes: See manufacturer's data sheet. Only use manufacturer's recommended cleaning agents and lubricants.

Task.Action: Check calibration - controller output to actuator position. More than one actuator may be fed from the control supply.
Task.Notes: Note control pressure operation range is correct (could be sequenced control)

Task.Item: 8. Auxiliary control units. e.g. positioners, electrical feedback units and end switches.
Task.Action: Check operation.

Task.Item: 9. Reaction to safety signal i.e. fire/smoke.
Task.Action: Check that the actuator assumes correct position (if applicable).
Task.Notes: See relevant control/sensor section for this operation.

Legislation.Content: BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.

Introduction.Content: Ensure the correct grade and type of hydraulic oil is used for any topping up purposes.

Task.Action: Where applicable, check supply voltage and that polarities are correct.
Task.Notes: If supply voltages are not found, check to see if supply is via a controller. Refer to manufacturer's recommendations.

Task.Action: Where applicable, check for presence and that polarity is correct.
Task.Notes: Refer to manufacturer's recommendations. The previous note can also apply to the control signal.

Task.Item: Auxiliary control functions i.e. on/off switches, frost protection and feedback potentiometers
Task.Action: Check operation.
Task.Notes: See relevant manufacturer's recommendations and auxiliary section.

Task.Action: Check to prove actuator will mechanically open/close valve or damper to its working limits.
Task.Notes: Ensure that the actuator is returned to the 'auto' position after check is completed.

Task.Action: Check for correct position for application when power fails.
Task.Notes: This will entail interrupting the power to the actuator at a convenient point. Do not forget to reconnect the supply when the check is complete.

Task.Action: Check for correct response to signal.
Check.
Check for signs of leakage of hydraulic fluid around actuator seals. Change seals if necessary. On completion of the works, bleed through the system to ensure there is no air trapped in the pipework.

Task.Item: Reaction to Safety Signal i.e. Fire/Smoke
Task.Action: Check that the actuator assumes correct position (if applicable).
Task.Notes: See relevant control/sensor section for this operation.

Legislation.Content: BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.

Task.Action: Check supply voltage and that polarities are correct.
Task.Notes: If supply voltages are not found, check to see if supply is via a controller. Refer to manufacturer's data sheet.

Task.Action: Check for presence and that polarity is correct.
Task.Notes: Refer to manufacturer's data sheet. The previous note can also apply to the control signal.

Task.Item: 3. Auxiliary control functions i.e. on/off switches, frost protection and position indicators.
Task.Action: Check operation.
Task.Notes: See relevant manufacturer's data sheet and auxiliary section.

Task.Action: Check to prove actuator will mechanically open/close valve or damper to its working limits.
Task.Notes: Ensure that the actuator is returned to the 'auto' position after check is completed. If the actuator is of the direct coupled type, ensure that the clamp assembly is not worn and the fixings are tight.

Task.Action: Check for correct position for application when power fails.
Task.Notes: This will entail interrupting the power to the actuator at a convenient point . Do not forget to reconnect the supply when the check is complete.

Task.Item: 6. Reaction to safety signal i.e. fire/smoke.
Task.Action: Check that the actuator assumes correct position (if applicable).
Task.Notes: The signal could be in any form from a fusible link in the supply or gear box to an independent signal from a control. If the actuator is integrated into the fire alarm circuit, checks may have to be made whilst a fire drill is in operation. See manufacturer's data sheet on this actuator and relevant control and/or sensor section.

Task.Action: Check for correct response to signal.
Check.

Legislation.Content: BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.

Introduction.Content:
Power fail - Motor return actuators are commonly enabled to return to the desired position by means of an electricity supply independent from the rest of the building. Care should be taken to monitor the amount of operations left in the batteries and they should be replaced according to the manufacturer's instructions. The disposal of batteries calls for special arrangements, which should conform to all environmental and Health and Safety requirements.


If the following actuators perform a safety function e.g. fitted to a fire/smoke damper, the frequency of checks should be taken as the maximum time between checks and reference should be made to the particular manufacturer's recommended frequencies. It should be remembered that people's lives and property could depend on the actuators functioning correctly.

Task.Action: Check supply voltage and that polarities are correct.
Task.Notes: If supply voltages are not found, check to see if supply is via a controller. Refer to manufacturer's data sheet.

Task.Action: Check for presence and that polarity is correct.
Task.Notes: Refer to manufacturer's data sheet. The previous note can also apply to the control signal.

Task.Item: 3. Auxiliary control functions i.e. on/off switches, frost protection and feedback potentiometers.
Task.Action: Check operation.
Task.Notes: See relevant manufacturer's data sheet and auxiliary section.

Task.Action: Check to prove actuator will mechanically open/close valve or damper by moving to its working limits.
Task.Notes: Ensure that the actuator is returned to the 'auto' position after check is completed.

Task.Action: Check for correct position for application when power fails.
Task.Notes: This check must be performed before power is restored to the system or actuator.

Task.Item: 6. Reaction to safety signal, e.g. fire/smoke.
Task.Action: Check that the actuator assumes correct position (if applicable).
Check condition.
Task.Notes: Note use by date and consider life expectancy of battery. See heading note above regarding disposal.

Task.Action: Check to ensure that the switches are made to make or break at the correct position and that they perform their correct function.
Check to ensure that: a) winding/tracking is not dirty or broken, b) wiper is making contact and is not dirty, c) potentiometer performs its correct function.
Task.Notes: If the winding is broken, do not attempt to repair. Provide a replacement. If the wiper is not making correct contact, gently bend it until smooth contact is attained.

Task.Action: Check for:  a) corrosion  b) deformed or bent component  c) wear on moving parts and mounting brackets.
Task.Notes: Where required, clean and lubricate parts i.e. ball joints and sockets and moving parts. Refer to manufacturer should any item deem to be in need of replacement. Refer to data sheet on manufacturer's maintenance instructions.

Task.Action: Ensure that the actuator achieves the required stroke limits.  Adjust if necessary.

Legislation.Content: BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.

Task.Action: Check supply voltage and that polarities are correct.
Task.Notes: If supply voltages are not found, check to see if supply is via a controller. Refer to manufacturer's data sheet.

Task.Action: Check for presence and that polarity is correct.
Task.Notes: Refer to manufacturer's data sheet. The previous note can also apply to the control signal.

Task.Item: 3. Auxiliary control functions i.e. on/off switched, frost protection, feedback potentiometers.
Task.Action: Check operation.
Task.Notes: See relevant manufacturer's data sheet and auxiliary section.

Task.Action: Check to prove actuator will mechanically open/close valve or damper to its working limits.
Task.Notes: The actuator may be fitted with the facility to manually wind up the spring, if so the spring must be wound up with the recommended tool. See manufacturer's data sheet. If the tool is capable of being removed, do so at the end of the test and ensure that the actuator is left in the original position. Ensure that the actuator is returned to the 'auto' position (if fitted) after the check is completed. Care must be taken in winding up the mechanism to ensure the spring is not over tensioned.

Task.Action: Check for correct position for application when power fails.
Task.Notes: This check must be performed before power is restored to the system or actuator.

Task.Item: 6. Running times of spring and motor.
Task.Action: Check.
Task.Notes: Times should be within the tolerances specified in the manufacturer's data.

Task.Item: 7. Reaction to safety signal, e.g. fire smoke.
Task.Action: Check that the actuator assumes correct position (if applicable).
Task.Notes: This signal could be in any form, from a fusible link in the supply or gearbox to an independent signal from a control. If the actuator is integrated into the fire alarm circuit, checks may have to be made whilst a fire drill is in operation.

Task.Action: Check for correct response to signal.
Check to ensure that the switches are made to make or break at the correct position and that they perform their correct function.
Check to ensure that:  a) winding/tracking is not dirty or broken, b) wiper is making contact and is not dirty, c) potentiometer performs its correct function.
Task.Notes: If the winding is broken, do not attempt to repair. Provide a replacement. If the wiper is not making correct contact, gently bend it until smooth contact is attained.

Task.Action: Check for:  a) corrosion, b) deformed or bent component, c) wear on moving parts and mounting brackets.
Task.Notes: Where required, clean and lubricate parts i.e. ball joints and sockets and moving parts. Refer to manufacturer should any item deem to be in need of replacement. Refer to data sheet on manufacturer's maintenance instructions.

Task.Action: Ensure that the actuator achieves the required stroke limits. Adjust if necessary.

Legislation.Content: BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.

Task.Action: Check manometer reading and renew filter media as indicated.
Task.Notes: Check the pressure differential across the filters. It should be noted that checking the filter should be carried out weekly by the client.

Task.Item: Guide vane actuators and modulating dampers
Task.Action: Check operation.
Check for condensate carry-over and that drains are clear.

Task.Item: Humidifier pumps, sprays and water supply to tank
Task.Action: Check operation.
Air should be vented from heating and cooling coils where fitted.
Check tension, alignment, and condition.
Task.Notes: Re-tension or replace as necessary. For detailed maintenance procedures, see Belt drives (SFG 04-01).

Task.Item: Damper and guide vane pivots and linkages
Task.Action: Lubricate lightly.
Check to see that louvres are clear and not obstructed, couplings are secure and that motor runs without excessive noise or vibration.

Task.Item: Frost protection, boost thermostat and controls
Task.Action: Check operation. For detailed maintenance refer to Sensors and Switching Devices (SFG 50).
Task.Notes: This check should be carried out in September and February in Great Britain.

Task.Action: Check operation of fan in accordance with the relevant section of Fans (SFG 20).
Check alignment, security.
Check alignment and for excessive clearance.
Task.Notes: Wear is indicated by excessive clearance and couplings should be replaced.

Task.Action: Check condition and clean. Check air and water pressure drops across coils. Check operation of the heating and cooling coil in accordance with task Heat Exchangers (SFG 29-01).
Task.Notes: Even when filters are fitted, dirt can build up causing loss of machine output.

Task.Action: Check operation and condition.
Task.Notes: Calibration/Interrogation/Control Adjustment.  See relevant sections Control Panels and Controllers (SFG 14) and Sensors and Switching Devices (SFG 50).

Task.Action: Fully open and close and then reset at the original setting.
Thoroughly clean interior and check for corrosion. On re-assembly check for air tightness.
Task.Notes: Include heating and cooling coils, fan impeller and eliminator plates and other fittings.

Task.Action: Check all motors in accordance with Motors (SFG 39-01).
Task.Notes: This should not exceed data plate value. Measure shaft float and end play.

Task.Item: Anti-vibration mountings and ductwork flexible connections
Task.Action: Check condition.
Check and adjust as necessary.
Task.Notes: The correct tensioning of V-belts prevents excessive bearing wear. Motor position should be adjusted so that only a slight 'bow' appears on the slack side of the belt when in operation. Recommended tensions are given in the installations instructions. After a few days running, check tension.

Task.Action: Check and adjust as required.
Task.Notes: Poor alignment of the pulleys will cause excessive wear on the sides of the belt and shorten their lives.

Task.Item: 3. Bearings. ('Sealed for life' bearings should not normally require attention).
Task.Action: Check for wear and lubricate at frequencies recommended by the manufacturer. Where oil filled, drain, strip and clean bearing assembly, reassemble and fill with clean oil.
Check for secure mounting and positioning.
Task.Notes: Belt replacement. As necessary. New and used V-belts should not be run together on the same set.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Atmospheric Gas Burner - Free Standing Boiler

Introduction.Content:
Boiler room ventilation should comply with BS 5440 -2: 2009 for boilers not exceeding 70kW and BS 6644:2005 for boilers with a capacity between 70kW and 1.8MW.

Undetected CO is poisonous, life threatening and also causes energy waste. Flames should be bluish and burning in a stable manner. The burner should be quiet in operation, no excessive noise should occur when the burner ignites or shuts down.

Consider the installation of a CO detector that complies with BS EN 50291-1:2010 and BS EN 50292:2002.

Task.Item: 1a. Before proceeding with dismantling of boiler.
Task.Action: Check casing for damage or breakages. Inspect for loose fittings or connections and any sign of leaks.
Task.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area.  Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations.  Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Action: Record settings.
Check that all are in accordance with current Codes of Practice.
Task.Notes: Local electrical isolator should be fitted. Supply to the boiler must be direct, i.e. not fed through a time switch.

Task.Item: 3. Isolate boiler for gas and electrical supplies.
Task.Action: Record any work which needs rectification or replacement.
Disconnect thermocouple and pilot tube from burners.

Task.Item: 5. Remove burners and pilot assembly, plus baffles if fitted.
Task.Action: Brush all accessible flueways thoroughly from top to bottom, clean all deposits from the burner box, refit baffles and flue cover - checking cover seal. Check for cracking and wear.
Task.Notes: Cleaning should be thorough and carried out as per the manufacturer's instructions.

Task.Action: Remove.
Remove and clean ports.
Remove and clean.
Task.Notes: Clean by blowing through or washing. Do not use pin as this will damage the injector.

Task.Action: Replace/clean with fine wire brush, reassemble pilot.
Task.Notes: Make sure head lines up with the pilot flame.

Task.Action: Replace.
Remove from burners and clean.
Refit.

Task.Item: 9. Burners, Gas valve, thermocouple and pilot tube.
Task.Action: Check adjust and refit along with main burner.
Open gas cock and test for gas soundness, reconnect electrical services. Test controls operation, relight pilot and run up boiler.
Task.Notes: Test flame setting, thermocouple sensitivity and check manifold gas pressure against manufacturer's settings, adjust if required. If in doubt check gas supply standing pressure at the meter .

Task.Action: Ensure that no products of combustion are entering the area of the building where the boiler is situated.
Task.Notes: The checks should be carried out in line with the requirements of the Gas Safety (installations and Use) regulations

Task.Action: Check electrical installation for safety and that local isolator is fitted.
Task.Notes: If not, provide written report to client.

Task.Action: Provide written report.
Task.Notes: The report should be signed by the servicing engineer and the client/responsible person/clients representative. Premature failure of the plant will result if a satisfactory service is not carried out. Depending on the nature/urgency of the fault and the type of premises this report may be verbal. Gas work must be carried out by a competent engineer qualified as required by the Gas Safety (Installation and Use) Regulations.

Task.Action: Recommendations
Task.Notes: If after servicing the appliance it is considered unsafe, the recommendation to the client is that it must be taken out of use. If approval for this action is refused an appropriate label must be attached to the appliance and a written report must be signed by the client/responsible person/clients representative. Both the gas supplier and a supervisor/manager must be informed.

Legislation.Content: Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)
HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996
Boiler (Efficiency) Regulations 1993

Introduction.Content:
The essential feature of a condensing boiler is that to increase the efficiency the flue gases are cooled below their dew point with the result that condensate is produced which has to be removed from the flue via drainage pipework.

Boiler room ventilation should comply with BS 5440 -2: 2009 for boilers not exceeding 70kW and BS 6644:2005 for boilers with a capacity between 70kW and 1.8MW.

Undetected CO is poisonous, life threatening and also causes energy waste. Flames should be bluish and burning in a stable manner. The burner should be quiet in operation, no excessive noise should occur when the burner ignites or shuts down. 

In domestic premises, consider the installation of a CO detector that complies with BS EN 50291-1:2010 and BS EN 50292:2002.

Task.Item: 1a. Before proceeding with dismantling of boiler. 1b. Test fire.
Task.Action: Check casing for damage or breakages. Inspect for loose fittings or connections and any sign of leaks. Record settings.
Task.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations.  Refer to www.hse.gov.uk..

Task.Action: Check that there is a steady fall back to the boiler from the flue to allow condensate to run back. With the boiler operating at low return, temperature [less than 50 C], check that condensate flows freely from the drain pipe.
Task.Notes: Risk Assessment may be required. Waste Disposal Licensing Regulations may apply.

Task.Action: Check that all are in accordance with current Codes of Practice.
Task.Notes: Local electrical isolator should be fitted. Supply to the boiler must be direct i.e. not fed through a time switch.

Task.Action: Clean and inspect.
Clean with water and a soft brush.
Check crystal level and top up if necessary.

Task.Item: 7. Condensate drain pipe and U-siphon trap.
Task.Action: Clean, inspect and flush.
Task.Notes: Ensure trap contains water to act as a seal

Task.Action: Check operation and clean any deposits off blades.

Task.Item: 9. Isolate boiler for gas and electrical supplies.
Task.Action: Record any work which needs rectification or replacement.
Disconnect thermocouple and pilot tube from burners.

Task.Item: 11. Remove burners and pilot assembly and baffles if fitted.
Task.Action: Brush all accessible flue ways thoroughly from top to bottom, clean all deposits from the burner box, refit baffles and flue cover - checking cover seal. Check for cracking and wear.
Task.Notes: Cleaning should be thorough and carried out as per the manufacturer's instructions.

Task.Action: Remove.
Remove and clean ports.
Remove and clean.
Task.Notes: Clean by blowing through or washing. Do not use pin as this will damage the injector.

Task.Action: Replace/clean with fine wire brush, reassemble pilot.
Task.Notes: Make sure head lines up with the pilot and not the burner.

Task.Action: Replace.
Remove from burners and clean.
Refit.

Task.Item: 15. Burners, Gas valve, thermocouple and pilot tube.
Task.Action: Check adjust and refit along with main burner.
Check treatment regime is correct.
Inspect, clean with compressed air.
Task.Notes: If there are any signs of bending, replace. For all condensing boilers, manufacturers specific service instructions take precedence.

Task.Action: Open gas cock and test for gas soundness, reconnect electrical services. Test controls operation, relight pilot and run up boiler.
Task.Notes: Test flame setting and thermocouple sensitivity and check manifold gas pressure against manufacturer`s settings, adjust if required. If in doubt check gas supply standing pressure at the meter .

Task.Action: Ensure that no products of combustion are entering the area of the building where the boiler is situated.
Task.Notes: The checks should be carried out in line with the requirements of the Gas Safety (installations and Use) regulations

Task.Action: Check electrical installation for safety and that local isolator is fitted.
Task.Notes: If not provide written report to client.

Task.Action: Provide written report.
Task.Notes: The report must be signed by the servicing engineer and the client/responsible person/clients representative. Premature failure of the plant will result if a satisfactory service is not carried out, by a competent engineer qualified as required by the Gas Safety Regulations. Depending on the nature/urgency of the fault and the type of premises this report may be verbal.

Task.Action: Recommendations
Task.Notes: If, after servicing, the appliance is considered unsafe the recommendation to the client is that it must be taken out of use. If approval for this action is refused an appropriate label must be attached to the appliance and a written report must be signed by the client/responsible person/clients representative and the gas supplier and a supervisor/manager informed.

Legislation.Content: Boiler (Efficiency) Regulations 1993
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)
Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995
HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Coal Fired Boilers - Bunkers and Conveyors

Introduction.Content:
The burning of coal is a complex operation involving the storage, handling and combustion of solid material, plus the handling, disposal of gaseous and solid waste. The materials are abrasive with the wear and tear on mechanical plant considerable, hence regular maintenance is vital to ensure continuous working and a clean environment. The maintenance of each section of the coal burning operation is examined in sequence.

WARNING. A risk assessment and method statement must be undertaken in accordance with the Confined Spaces Regulations, before entering any confined space such as a hopper, flue chamber or boiler to ensure that there is adequate ventilation and an absence of any fumes or flue gases.

Task.Action: Check and isolate and Lock Off from electricity supply, remove fuses if used.
Task.Notes: Depending on the Establishment, a Permit to Work system may be in operation. The Authorised Person should be approached for the issue of the permit.

Task.Action: Inspect for wear and corrosion and repair as necessary.
Inspect, renew worn sections, check and replace joints as necessary.
Task.Notes: Lubrication of rollers, idlers and drums should be carried out frequently as part of the client`s regular routine.

Task.Action: Grease outrigger bearing on worm shaft and tube rotation guide.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Coal Fired Boilers - Coal Storage Handling and Feed Mechanisms, Automatic Ash Removal (where fitted)

Introduction.Content:
The burning of coal is a complex operation involving the storage, handling, combustion of solid material, together with the handling, disposal of gaseous and solid waste. The materials are abrasive and the wear and tear on mechanical plant considerable, hence regular maintenance is vital to ensure continuous working and a clean environment. The maintenance of each section of the coal burning operation is examined in sequence.  (See also Motors SFG 39)

WARNING. A risk assessment and method statement must be undertaken before entering any confined space such as a hopper, flue chamber or boiler to ensure that there is adequate ventilation and an absence of any fumes or flue gases.

Task.Action:
Prior to any maintenance works:

 

Check and isolate and Lock Off from electricity supply.

Remove fuses, if used.

Replace fuses when works complete and ready to bring back on line.
Task.Notes: Depending on the Establishment, a Permit to Work system may be in operation. The Authorised Person should be approached for the issue of the permit.

Task.Action: Empty and check for signs of wear or corrosion.
Task.Notes: Paint all internal components exposed to coal. If remedial work necessary, report to client.

Task.Action: Rod through and replace worn components.
Task.Notes: Check for erosion and thinning on bends.

Task.Action: Inspect tooth type drive belt for wear. Replace if necessary. Check for wear.

Task.Item: 5. Pneumatic system. (Applies to both coal feed and ash removal, where fitted).
Task.Action: Inspect and replace items listed under notes. Check for air tightness.
Task.Notes:
(a) air seals on each outlet cyclone

(b) clean blades of fan

(c) ensure timing sequence

(d) check 'bags'

(e) check bag shaker and lubricate as appropriate

It is essential to maintain air tightness on pneumatic systems otherwise the coal feed cannot be maintained, output is reduced and energy wasted.

Task.Action: Check oil level and replenish if necessary.
Check effectiveness.
Check low level switches, fuses and action of fan emergency safety switch in OFF position.
Task.Notes: Insufficient air can lead to blockage of feed pipes whilst excessive air can cause degradation of the coal and produce fines.

Task.Action: Check working of vibrator, fan rotation, bunker filters.
Check suction nozzle entrainment point, action of air control valves and discharge valve.
Lubricate fan and motor bearings.
Task.Notes: Use manufacturer's recommended lubricants. In a dirty environment more frequent lubrication will be necessary.

Task.Action: Check all electrical trips.
Task.Notes: These should be set for manual reset.

Task.Action: Clean separator of any fines which have build up on internal surfaces.
Task.Notes: Regular monthly checks of air tightness should be made.

Legislation.Content: Lifting Operations and Lifting Equipment Regulations 1998 (LOLER)

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Coal Feed Mechanisms - Under Feed Stokers

Introduction.Content:
The burning of coal is a complex operation involving the storage, handling, combustion of solid material, together with the handling, disposal of gaseous and solid waste. The materials are abrasive and the wear and tear on mechanical plant considerable, hence regular maintenance is vital to ensure continuous working and a clean environment. The maintenance of each section of the coal burning operation is examined in sequence.  (See also Motors SFG 39)

WARNING. A risk assessment and method statement must be undertaken before entering any confined space such as a hopper, flue chamber or boiler to ensure that there is adequate ventilation and an absence of any fumes or flue gases.

Task.Action: Check and isolate and Lock Off from electricity supply. Remove fuses, if used.
Task.Notes: Depending on the Establishment, a Permit to Work system may be in operation. The Authorised Person should be approached for the issue of the permit.

Task.Action: Check and clean out.
Check end feedscrew and refractory brickwork.
Remove from retort plenum chamber.
Examine and report condition. Check pickup screw high tension bolt.
Task.Notes: Advise client if replacement necessary. Refit safety guards after service.

Task.Action: Clean air hole and refit.
Clean if fitted.
Grease and lubricate.

Task.Item: 9. Gearbox or angle stoker gear unit.
Task.Action: Drain oil and refill with new oil.
Task.Notes: Check for leaks before and after 'running in' on return to operation.

Task.Action: Check, free if necessary, and lubricate.
Check and adjust shearpin alignment if necessary.
Task.Notes: Free rotary tube if jammed and grease tube joint.

Task.Action: Close isolator switch. Run stoker and check sequence.
Task.Notes: Visually check pressure gauge and boiler thermostat. Report on condition of plant.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Coal Feed Mechanisms - Chain Grate Stokers

Introduction.Content:
The burning of coal is a complex operation involving the storage, handling, combustion of solid material, together with the handling, disposal of gaseous and solid waste. The materials are abrasive and the wear and tear on mechanical plant considerable, hence regular maintenance is vital to ensure continuous working and a clean environment. The maintenance of each section of the coal burning operation is examined in sequence.  (See also Motors SFG 39)

WARNING. A risk assessment and method statement must be undertaken before entering any confined space such as a hopper, flue chamber or boiler to ensure that there is adequate ventilation and an absence of any fumes or flue gases.

Task.Action: Check and isolate and Lock off from electricity supply. Remove fuses, if used.
Task.Notes: Depending on the Establishment, a Permit to Work system may be in operation. The Authorised Person should be approached for the issue of the permit.

Task.Action: Empty and check internal and external coatings.
Task.Notes: If there are signs of deterioration consult the manufacturer.

Task.Item: 3. Level probes on coal surge bunkers.
Task.Action: Check and clean as necessary.
Task.Notes: When plant put back on line prove operation of plant under all plant operating conditions.

Task.Action: Ensure excess water can be drained off.
Check coal auger supports.
Remove augers and check for wear and distortion.
Reassemble and recoat coal tube.
Task.Notes: Use bituminised sealant or similar protective coating.

Task.Action: Check internally for signs of wear and rectify as necessary.
Check security.
Check condition, security and make good as required.
Withdraw and inspect for wear. Check condition of rear skid plate.
Task.Notes: Drain oil in gear cases, clean and refill, grease bearings on the force draught fan.

Task.Action: Renew rear side steel bars and any links showing signs of burning.
Task.Notes: Remove a section of chain to inspect inside of air box and interior seals.

Task.Action: Check bottom plate and chassis for distortion.
Repair or replace arch and if necessary firedoor lining.
Examine and renew switchgear contacts where necessary. Replace any worn or damaged regulator parts.

Introduction.Content:
The burning of coal is a complex operation involving the storage, handling, combustion of solid material, together with the handling, disposal of gaseous and solid waste. The materials are abrasive and the wear and tear on mechanical plant considerable, hence regular maintenance is vital to ensure continuous working and a clean environment. The maintenance of each section of the coal burning operation is examined in sequence.  (See also Motors SFG 39)

WARNING. A risk assessment and method statement must be undertaken before entering any confined space such as a hopper, flue chamber or boiler to ensure that there is adequate ventilation and an absence of any fumes or flue gases.

Task.Action: Check for wear and report if remedial work required.
Check and isolate and Lock off from electricity supply. Remove fuses, if used. Check operation and wear on seals.
Check for holes or distortion.
Task.Notes: Examine rubber tubing to ash skip for wear.

Task.Action: Grease inner bearing, grease nipples and jaw crusher outrigger bearing assembly.
Task.Notes: Under no circumstances should an excess of grease be applied to the bearing assemblies.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Check operation and adjust nozzles for correct spray pattern if necessary
Grease pulleys, cable guides and winch unit.
Clean paddles shaft and end bearing housing of any build up of ash.

Introduction.Content:
Boiler room ventilation should comply with BS 5440 -2: 2009 for boilers not exceeding 70kW and BS 6644:2005 for boilers with a capacity between 70kW and 1.8MW.

Undetected CO is poisonous, life threatening and also causes energy waste. Flames should be bluish and burning in a stable manner. The burner should be quiet in operation, no excessive noise should occur when the burner ignites or shuts down.

In domestic premises, consider the installation of a CO detector that complies with BS EN 50291-1:2010 and BS EN 50292:2002.

Task.Action: Note any visible defects.
Task.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations. Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Action: Carry out and note any visual defects, record results.
Check that all are in accordance with current Codes of Practice.
Task.Notes: Local electrical isolator should be fitted. Supply to the boiler must be direct, i.e. not fed through a time switch.

Task.Action: Where applicable, Check that there is a steady fall back to the boiler from the flue to allow condensate to run back. With the boiler operating at low return, temperature [less than 50C], check that condensate flows freely from the drain pipe.
Task.Notes: Risk Assessment may be required Waste Disposal Regulations may apply.

Task.Item: 5. Isolate from electricity and gas supply.
Task.Action: Switch off, remove fuses and/or lock off and turn off gas supply at main cock.
Task.Notes: Before starting any dismantling of equipment it is essential for safety reasons that the plant be isolated from incoming services.

Task.Item: 6. Fan/mix chamber, gas train and controller assembly.
Task.Action: Remove, thoroughly clean, with a soft brush. Lubricate if necessary.
Clean and check air passages.
Task.Notes: Ensure air passages are clear to pressure switch.

Task.Action: Inspect for soundness.
Task.Notes: If probe is bent or shows signs of oxidation it should be replaced.

Task.Action: Reassemble and fire, check air and gas settings, carry out combustion efficiency test.
Task.Notes: It is important that reference is made to the boiler and burner manufacturer's specifications.

Task.Action: Test under no air conditions.
Test and take probe readings.

Task.Item: 12. Boiler flue ways and connecting flues.
Task.Action: Open and remove by brushing and/or vacuum all soot and scale. Reseal, check for air leaks and reseal as necessary.
Drain down, remove and thoroughly clean with wire brush.
Clean and descale module in accordance with manufacturers instructions.
Task.Notes: Always follow recommendations from manufacturer. Waste Disposal Regulations may apply.

Task.Action: Check crystal level and top up if necessary.
Check security of mechanical parts and secure mounting of appliances.
Task.Notes: A maintenance check should be carried out on this type of burner twice a year but refer to manufacturer's specification.

Task.Action: Provide written report which should be signed by the service engineer and kept by client.
Task.Notes: Premature failure and excessive fuel costs will result if satisfactory service is not carried out. All service and maintenance must be carried out by a registered engineer in accordance with Health and Safety requirements and possess accreditation in accordance with the Gas Safety Regulations.

Task.Action: Recommendations
Task.Notes: If after servicing the appliance is considered unsafe, the recommendation to the client is that it must be taken out of use. If approval for this action is refused an appropriate label must be attached to the appliance and a written report must be signed by the client/responsible person/clients representative. Both the gas supplier and a supervisor/manager must be informed.

Legislation.Content: Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
Boiler (Efficiency) Regulations 1993
HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)

Introduction.Content:
Can comprise several modules, each having separate controls. Each module must be isolated and work carried out consecutively.

Boiler room ventilation should comply with BS 5440 for boilers not exceeding 70kw and BS 6644 for boilers with a capacity between 70kw and 1.8MW.

Undetected CO is poisonous, life threatening and also causes energy waste. Flames should be bluish and burning in a stable manner. The burner should be quiet in operation, no excessive noise should occur when the burner ignites or shuts down.

In domestic premises, consider the installation of a CO detector that complies with BS EN 50291 and BS EN 50292.

Task.Action: Check security of mechanical parts and secure mounting of appliances.
Task.Notes: A maintenance check should be carried out on this type of burner twice a year but refer to manufacturer's specification.

Task.Action: Note any visible defects.
Task.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations.  Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Action: Carry out and note any visual defects, record results.
Check that all are in accordance with current Codes of Practice.
Test fire and record settings.

Task.Item: Isolate from electricity and gas supply
Task.Action: Switch off, remove fuses and/or lock off and turn off gas supply at main cock.
Task.Notes: Before starting any dismantling of equipment it is essential for safety reasons that the plant be isolated from incoming services.

Task.Item: Fan/mix chamber, gas train and controller assembly
Task.Action:
Remove and thoroughly clean with a soft brush.
Lubricate if necessary.
Clean and check air passages.
Task.Notes: Ensure air passages are clear to pressure switch.

Task.Action: Inspect for soundness.
Task.Notes: If probe is bent or shows signs of oxidation it should be replaced.

Task.Action: Reassemble and fire, check air and gas settings, carry out combustion efficiency test.
Task.Notes: It is important that reference is made to the boiler and burner manufacturer's specifications.

Task.Action: Test under no air conditions.
Test and take probe readings.

Task.Item: Boiler flue ways and connecting flues
Task.Action: Open and remove all soot and scale by brushing and/or vacuuming. Reseal, check for air leaks, make good as required.
Drain down, remove and thoroughly clean with wire brush.
Provide written report which should be signed by the service engineer and kept by client.
Task.Notes: Premature failure and excessive fuel costs will result if satisfactory service is not carried out. All service and maintenance must be carried out by a registered engineer in accordance with Health and Safety requirements and possess accreditation in accordance with the Gas Safety Regulations.

Task.Action: Recommendations.
Task.Notes: If after servicing, the boiler is considered unsafe the recommendation to the client is that it must be taken out of use. If approval for this action is refused an appropriate label must be attached to the appliance and a written report must be signed by the client/responsible person/clients representative and both the gas supplier and a supervisor/manager informed.

Task.Action: Clean and descale module in accordance with manufacturer's instructions.
Task.Notes: Always follow recommendations from manufacturer. Waste Disposal Regulations may apply.

Legislation.Content: Boiler (Efficiency) Regulations 1993
Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995
HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances

Introduction.Content:
The essential feature of a condensing boiler is that to increase the efficiency the flue gases are cooled below their dew point with the result that condensate is produced which has to be removed from the flue via drainage pipework.

Boiler room ventilation should comply with BS 5440 -2: 2009 for boilers not exceeding 70kW and BS 6644:2005 for boilers with a capacity between 70kW and 1.8MW.

Undetected CO is poisonous, life threatening and also causes energy waste. Flames should be bluish and burning in a stable manner. The burner should be quiet in operation, no excessive noise should occur when the burner ignites or shuts down.

In domestic premises, consider the installation of a CO detector that complies with BS EN 50291-1:2010 and BS EN 50292:2002.

Task.Item: 1a. Before proceeding with dismantling of boiler.
Task.Action: Check casing for damage or breakages. Inspect for loose fittings or connections and any sign of leaks.
Record settings.
Task.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations.  Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Action: Check that there is a steady fall back to the boiler from the flue to allow condensate to run back. With the boiler operating at low return, temperature [less than 50C], check that condensate flows freely from the drain pipe.
Task.Notes: Risk Assessment may be required. Waste Disposal Regulations may apply.

Task.Action: Check that all are in accordance with current Codes of Practice.
Task.Notes: Local electrical isolator should be fitted. Supply to the boiler must be direct, i.e. not fed through a time switch.

Task.Action: Switch on, carry out safety check of flame failure.
Carry out and note any visible defects.
Task.Notes: Pay particular attention to carbon monoxide (CO) as presence is poisonous and life threatening and indicates waste energy.

Task.Item: 6. Isolate from electricity and gas supply.
Task.Action: Switch off, remove fuses and turn off gas supply at main cock.
Task.Notes: Before starting and dismantling of equipment it is essential for safety reasons that the plant be isolated from incoming services.

Task.Action: Remove, thoroughly clean, lubricate if necessary.
Task.Notes: Before starting and dismantling of equipment it is essential for safety reasons that the plant be isolated from incoming services.

Task.Action: Clean and check air passages.
Task.Notes: Ensure air passages are clear to pressure switch.

Task.Item: 10. Removal of UV cell and head assembly.
Task.Action: Clean, adjust electrode and if required isolation probe.
Task.Notes: UV cells should be replaced after a life of 10,000 hours.

Task.Action: Inspect for soundness.
Task.Notes: UV cells should be replaced after a life of 10,000 hours.

Task.Action: Reassemble and fire, check air and gas settings, carry out combustion efficiency test. Check high/low flame conditions.
Task.Notes: It is important that reference is made to the boiler and burner manufacturers specifications.

Task.Action: Test under no air conditions.
Test and take probe or UV cell readings.
Check crystal level and top up if necessary.
Check security of mechanical parts and secure mounting of appliance.
Task.Notes: A maintenance check should be carried out on this type of burner twice a year but refer to manufacturer's specification .

Task.Action: Ensure that no products of combustion are entering the area of the building where the boiler is situated.
Task.Notes: Undetected CO is life threatening (poisonous) and also causes energy waste. Flames should be bluish and burning in a stable manner. The burner should be quiet in operation, no excessive noises should occur when the burner ignitor shuts down.

Task.Action: Check electrical installation for safety and that local isolator is fitted.
Task.Notes: If not provide written report to client.

Task.Action: Recommendations.
Task.Notes: If after servicing the boiler is considered unsafe the recommendation to the client is that it must be taken out of use. If approval for this action is refused an appropriate label must be attached to the appliance and a written report must be signed by the client/responsible person representative and both the gas supplier and a supervisor/manager informed.

Legislation.Content: Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)
HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996
Boiler (Efficiency) Regulations 1993

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Forced Draught (Pressure Jet) Oil Condensing Boiler

Introduction.Content:
The essential feature of a condensing boiler is that to increase the efficiency the flue gases are cooled below their dew point with the result that condensate is produced which has to be removed from the flue via drainage pipework.

Boiler room ventilation should comply with BS 5440 -2: 2009 for boilers not exceeding 70kW and BS 6644:2005 for boilers with a capacity between 70kW and 1.8MW.

Undetected CO is poisonous, life threatening and also causes energy waste. The burner should be quiet in operation, no excessive noise should occur when the burner ignites or shuts down.

In domestic premises, consider the installation of a CO detector that complies with BS EN 50291-1:2010 and BS EN 50292:2002.

Task.Item: 1a. Before proceeding with dismantling of boiler.
Task.Action: Check casing for damage or breakages. Inspect for loose fittings or connections and any sign of leaks.
Task.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations.  Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Action: Record settings.

Check that there is a steady fall back to the boiler from the flue to allow condensate to run back. With the boiler operating at low return, temperature [less than 50C], check that condensate flows freely from the drain pipe.
Task.Notes: Risk Assessment may be required. Waste Disposal Regulations may apply.

Task.Action: Check that all are in accordance with current Codes of Practice.
Task.Notes: Local electrical isolator should be fitted. Supply to the boiler must be direct i.e. not fed through a time switch.

Task.Action: Switch on, carry out safety check of flame failure.
Carry out and note any visible defects.
Task.Notes: Pay particular attention to carbon monoxide (CO) as presence is poisonous and life threatening and indicates waste energy.

Task.Item: 7. Isolate from electricity and oil supply.
Task.Action: Switch off, remove fuses and turn off oil supply at main valve.
Task.Notes: Before starting and dismantling of equipment it is essential for safety reasons that the plant be isolated from incoming services.

Task.Action: Remove, clean combustion head, ignition electrodes and inspect HT leads.
Clean filter and inspect nozzle for wear.
Task.Notes: Erosion or surface defects on the nozzle can effect the profile of the emerging jet of oil and lead to a poor flame shape and bad combustion.

Task.Action: Renew.
Reassemble and set heat to manufacturer's requirements.
Remove, clean and lubricate as required, clean fan scroll.
Task.Notes: Inspect oil pump flexible drive coupling before reassembly.  (See also Motors SFG 39)

Task.Action: Remove and clean, inspect pump seals for signs of wear.
Inspect flexible oil line coupling, clean and renew oil line filter, clean photocell and adjust position.
Switch on and check flame shape and appearance if visible.
Test, record oil pressure.
Carry out and check for smoke.
Task.Notes: On larger systems combustion test should be carried out regularly to monitor performance and avoid energy waste.

Task.Action: Test for satisfactory operation.
Clean and inspect.
Clean with water and a soft brush.
Check crystal level and top up if necessary.

Task.Item: 21. Condensate drain pipe and U-siphon trap.
Task.Action: Clean, inspect and flush.
Check security of mechanical parts and secure mounting of appliance.
Task.Notes: A maintenance check should be carried out on this type of burner twice a year but refer to manufacturer's specification .

Task.Action: Provide written report which should be signed by the service engineer and kept by client.
Task.Notes: Premature failure and excessive fuel costs will result if satisfactory service is not carried out. All service and maintenance must be carried out by a registered engineer in accordance with Health and Safety requirements. All service and maintenance works must be carried out by a competent engineer in accordance with BS Codes of Practice (www.bsi-global.com) for oil firing.

Legislation.Content: Clean Air Act 1993
Control of Pollution (Oil Storage) (England) Regulations 2001
Boiler (Efficiency) Regulations 1993
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
Control of Pollution Act 1974
Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 and 2006 amendment

Introduction.Content:
Applies to boilers manufactured by casting or fabrication.

Boiler room ventilation should comply with BS 5440 -2: 2009 for boilers not exceeding 70kW and BS 6644:2005 for boilers with a capacity between 70kW and 1.8MW.

Undetected CO is poisonous, life threatening and also causes energy waste. Flames should be bluish and burning in a stable manner. The burner should be quiet in operation, no excessive noise should occur when the burner ignites or shuts down.

Task.Item: 1. Check operation, in particular safety controls (prv).
Task.Action: Note any visible defects.
Task.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations.  Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.  It is likely that a Permit to Work will be required from the Authorised Person before any works can be undertaken on a pressurised system.  Ensure system is full of water and the circuits are open. It is essential for low water content boilers that flow rates can be maintained at or above manufacturers recommended levels.

Task.Action: Start up system and carry out tests.

Task.Item: 3. Thermostats, pressure sensors & controls, altitude gauges, vacuum breaks.
Task.Action: Check for correct operation and settings.
Shut down, disconnect and lock off or remove fuses.
Task.Notes: Local electrical isolator should be fitted. Supply to the boiler must be direct i.e. not fed through a time switch.

Task.Item: 5. Boiler return temperature and associated controls.
Task.Action: Check if appropriate.
Check interlocks between controls.

Task.Item: 7. Boiler flueways, combustion chamber and connecting flues.
Task.Action: Open and remove by brushing and/or vacuum all soot and scale.
Check condition and report.
Reseal, check for air leaks, seal as necessary.
Carry out smoke test.
Check system water quality and inhibitor type and concentration. Top up if necessary. If water quality check shows regime is incorrect refer to specialist.
Task.Notes: Where system water quality is controlled, water treatment and dosing plant should be maintained according to the manufacturer's instructions.

Task.Action: Check operation and clean blades.
Task.Notes: Build up of deposits on the blades can reduce their efficiency and lead to poor combustion.

Task.Action: Reconnect and test fire, carry out efficiency test, refit casing and thoroughly clean down.
Task.Notes: A boiler is capable of exploding if safety controls fail and blocked flues will cause flue gas to leak into surrounding areas, causing damage and risks to life and to health through carbon monoxide poisoning.

Task.Action: Test for soundness.
Inspect.
Task.Notes: Boiler house cleanliness is important. Concrete floors should be sealed to keep dust down.

Legislation.Content: Pressure Systems Safety Regulations 2000
Pressure Equipment Regulations 1999 and 2002 amendment
BS EN 12952 Water-tube Boilers
BS EN 12953 Shell Boilers parts 1 -13 2001 to 2012

Introduction.Content:
All notes referring to sequence controls apply to individual boilers (not burner modules) in multiple installations.
This task should be issued with the relevant boiler maintenance task

Task.Action: Check operation. Check the set point (and differential).
Task.Notes: Check the frequency of operation if hours run are fitted.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Check operation and confirm the set point.
Task.Notes: The step controller will have mechanical switching using micro- or solid state switching.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Check operation.
Task.Notes: Check valve opening proving circuit and ensure that valve on leading boiler is open at all times.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Confirm operation.
Task.Notes: Is there a water proving circuit? Check operation if part of sequence controls. See Pumps SFG 45-02

Task.Action: Check operation.
Confirm correct.

Legislation.Content: HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996
Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)
Boiler (Efficiency) Regulations 1993

Introduction.Content:
On/Off overall control can be remote from the boiler plant.

Certain common maintenance procedures should be carried out for all controls. These are: -

1. All common items, e.g. thermostats and the like, that have switching contacts where they can be seen ensure contacts make and break easily and that there is no arcing or pitting.

2. Inspect thermostat phial and capillaries for mechanical damage.

3. Inspect thermostat pockets for corrosion and leakage.

4. Ensure immersion thermostats are secure in their pockets (and that the sensor is in contact with the end of the pocket and covered with heat conductive compound).

5. Inspect motorised valves for leakage and damage to linkage.

For more detailed information regarding the maintenance of motorised valves, checking of gland seals, stroking, etc. refer to relevant section.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Check operation. Confirm time settings.
Task.Notes: Time of day. (Keep setting at GMT all year unless specifically requested by client.) Day of week. Manual override.

Task.Item: 3. Boiler control and high limit thermostats Manual - Electronic.
Task.Action: Check operation. Confirm set points and temperatures. Check operation. Confirm set points and temperatures.
Task.Notes: Thermal no longer conforms to current insurance requirements.

Task.Action: Check operation. Confirm set point.
Task.Notes: Ensure correct location and no air movement restrictions. Advise client of any faults.

Task.Action: Check operation. Confirm set point.
Check operation. Confirm set point.
Task.Notes: This may be outside the building on older systems, ideally North facing free from any heat gains.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Check operation. Confirm set point.
Check operation and confirm time settings. Check performance.
Task.Notes: Time of day. Day of week. Manual override. Summer/Winter Calibration } Interrogation } Adjustment }

Task.Action: Check operation. Confirm time setting.
Check operation. Confirm set point.
Check operation. Confirm set point.
Check operation and confirm set point.
Task.Notes: Direct switching of boiler or pump on/off.

Task.Action: Check operation and confirm set point.
Task.Notes: Check if auxiliary switch controls boiler or pump on/off.

Task.Action: Check operation and confirm set point(s).
Confirm operation.
Check operating status.
Task.Notes: Before proceeding with maintenance programme check with client that boiler can be taken off-line. These works to be carried out in accordance with the Pressure Systems Safety Regulations 2000 and Safe Systems of Work.

Task.Action: Check exterior for signs of damage, leakage from valves, manholes and any loose fittings.
Task.Notes: Leakage can lead to corrosion with subsequent costly refurbishment or replacement of equipment.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Task.Notes: Safety system includes low and high level alarms, and pressure relief valves.

Task.Action: Ensure system on load and carry out combustion tests.
Task.Notes: Test should include smoke, draught chamber and flue, flue gas temperature, CO, CO 2 and O 2 . Readings should be checked with boiler instrumentation and noted.

Task.Item: 5. Thermostats, pressure sensors, gauges and thermometers.
Task.Action: Check for correct operation and settings.
Shut off and isolate steam, water, fuel and electrical services.
Task.Notes: Purge fuel lines and vent boiler to ensure safe conditions. Steam line should be isolated with either two separate valves or a single valve and spade.

Task.Action: Check that ventilation fans and louvres are functioning properly.
Task.Notes: Check that there is adequate ventilation in the boiler house and the conditions comply with the relevant regulations and standards. Boiler room ventilation should comply with BS 5440 -2: 2009 for boilers not exceeding 70kW and BS 6644:2005 for boilers with a capacity between 70kW and 1.8MW

Introduction.Content: The yearly tasks shown below are generally carried out at the same time as the Annual Statutory (Insurance) Inspection.
Introduction.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations. Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Notes: Record time test carried out, log results with the operator`s name, date of test plus any corrective action taken.

Task.Action: Manually blow down.
Manually blow down.
Test low water level cut-out and lock-out.
Task.Notes: At no time during a test should the water be lowered to the extent that it disappears from the gauge glass. Record time test carried out.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Record pressure gauge reading.

Check the feed tank level is adequate and there are no contaminants. Check that the chemical dose metering device is functioning and there are adequate chemical stocks in the tanks. Check that the in-house routine sample results are within their given parameters provided by the water treatment specialist and take remedial action when necessary. Check the temperature is above the required level for the treatment doses specified for oxygen scavenging.
Task.Notes: Record time test carried out, log results with the operator`s name, date of test plus any corrective action taken.

Task.Action: Carry out TDS water quality test, record the result and make adjustments where necessary.
Carry out pH water quality test, record the result and make adjustments where necessary.
Record quantity of water blown down.
Test flame failure lock-out. This may not be present on non self monitoring boilers.
Test failure to ignite lock out.
Test by lowering water level to 1st low water level, by evaporation and controlled blowdown, and check burner locks out and the alarm is sounded.
Task.Notes: Discharge temperature to drain should not exceed permissible limits.  Record time test carried out.  At no time during a test should the water be lowered to the extent that it disappears from the gauge glass.

Task.Action: Test by lowering water level to 2nd low water level, by evaporation and controlled blowdown, and check burner locks out and the alarm is sounded.
Task.Notes: Discharge temperature to drain should not exceed permissible limits.  Record time test carried out.  At no time during a test should the water be lowered to the extent that it disappears from the gauge glass.

Task.Item: 15. Boiler flueways, combustion chamber and connecting flue.
Task.Action: Open, remove by brushing and/or vacuum all soot and scale.
Task.Notes: Soot, ash and other fouling deposits impede heat transfer thus wasting energy and putting up costs.

Task.Action: Open boiler end doors and clean fire tubes by brushing or rotary scouring equipment.
Task.Notes: In multipass boilers it is important to clean all passes.

Task.Action: Check condition and report.
Reseal, check for air leaks, seal as necessary.
Carry out smoke test.
Remove manholes, clean out scale and residues. Replace, reseal and ensure bolts are tight.
Task.Notes: If there are considerable deposits of sludge and scale, this indicates poor water treatment which if allowed to continue will lead to boiler failure and energy wastage. Waste Disposal Regulations may apply.

Task.Action: Refill, reconnect and bring on line.
Task.Notes: Refit casing if necessary and thoroughly clean down.

Task.Action: Check for operation and accuracy.
Bring up to full load and carry out tests.
Task.Notes: On larger systems combustion tests should be carried out on a regular basis to monitor performance. The test should include smoke, draught chamber and flue, flue temperature, carbon dioxide, oxygen and carbon monoxide.

Task.Action: For maintenance procedures see Sanitary and waste water plumbing SFG 48-04.

Air Quality (Wales) Regulations 2000 and 2002 amendment
