Boiler (Efficiency) Regulations 1993
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)
HSE Managing and working with asbestos - Control of Asbestos Regulations 2012
Clean Air Act 1993
Control of Asbestos Regulations 2012
Pressure Systems Safety Regulations 2000

Introduction.Content: These boilers provide heat to LTHW and Domestic Hot Water systems. Electricity supply can be off-peak/on-peak or a combination of both.
Introduction.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations. Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Action: Switch and lock off. Remove fuses from both supplies.
Task.Notes: The boilers have two supplies. The permanent large capacity supply and the restricted hours signal supply. Report to the client if not capable of isolation.

Task.Action: Check physical condition of unit.

Task.Item: 3. Heavy current connection in the control box.
Task.Action: Remove control box cover. Check all heavy current connection for tightness and signs of over heating, also check element relay contacts for damage.
Remove top of boiler casing. Check all heavy current connections for tightness & signs of over heating.
Remove button front casing clean duct through casing, remove the rear end fan motor which is exposed when the casing is removed.
Task.Notes: Report if fan motor or pump are noisy. Advise the customer that the louvres on the outside of the casing should be vacuumed at intervals if the environment of the boiler is unclean.

Task.Action: Check for leaks.
Ask if the system has been drained since last visit and if it was retreated with inhibitor.
Task.Notes: If system does not contain inhibitor advise it is treated, as this is part of the manufacturers instructions.

Task.Action: Replace.

Introduction.Content:
In hard water areas maintenance may require to be carried out more frequently.

BEWARE: - High water conductivity in the boiler circulated water can damage the boiler pressure vessel, only work within the boiler manufacturers values of conductivity. See manufacturers information on recommended values.
Introduction.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations. Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Action: Check and isolate by removing fuse links.
Check all electrical connections in the cubicle and on the boiler electrodes for soundness and correct any defects.
Examine for defects and replace if necessary. Clean with non-abrasive material.
Check for free flow of water by operating the valve. Repair any valve gland leaks.
Check for free flow, actuate main drain if necessary.
Clean solenoid, manifold and strainer.
Task.Notes: Modern boilers have the load control driven by an electric motor. (See also Motors SFG 39)

Task.Action: Examine mechanism and lubricate.
Task.Notes: Comply with manufacturers recommendation for lubrication of the gear box, motor and control shaft and nut.

Task.Action: Test for correct conductivity at 20/25 C.
Task.Notes: This is to be within the boiler makers recommendation.

Task.Action: Replace all covers and reinstate electrical supply.
Task.Notes: Ensure all electrical and mechanical covers are in their correct places.

Introduction.Content: Applies to boilers manufactured by casting or fabrication.
Introduction.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations. Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Item: 1. Check operation, in particular safety controls.
Task.Action: Note any visible defects.
Task.Notes: Ensure system is full of water and the circuits are open. It is essential for low water content boilers that flow rates can be maintained at or above manufacturers recommended levels.

Task.Action: Start up system and carry out tests.
Task.Notes: On larger systems efficiency tests should be carried out on a regular basis to monitor performance. The test should include smoke, draught chamber and flue, flue temperature, fuel input and gas analysis including carbon monoxide.

Task.Item: 3. Thermostats, pressure sensors, altitude gauges thermometers.
Task.Action: Check for correct operation and settings.
Shut down, disconnect or remove fuses.
Task.Notes: Locate isolation switch, if not in accordance with IEE regulations report to building owner.

Task.Item: 5. Boiler return temperature and associated controls.
Task.Action: Check if appropriate.

Task.Item: 6. Boiler flueways, combustion chamber and connecting flues.
Task.Action: Open and remove by brushing and/or vacuum all soot and scale.
Check condition and report.
Reseal, check for air leaks, seal as necessary.
Carry out smoke test.
Check system water quality and inhibitor type and concentration. Top up if necessary. If water quality check shows regime is incorrect refer to specialist.
Task.Notes: Where system water quality is controlled, water treatment and dosing plant should be maintained according to the manufacturer's instructions.

Task.Action: Check operation and clean blades.
Task.Notes: Build up of deposits on the blades can reduce their efficiency and lead to poor combustion.

Task.Action: Reconnect and test fire, carry out efficiency test, refit casing and thoroughly clean down.
Task.Notes: A boiler is capable of exploding if safety controls fail and blocked flues will cause flue gas to leak into surrounding areas, causing damage and risks to life and to health through carbon monoxide poisoning.

Task.Action: Test for soundness.
Inspect.
Task.Notes: Boiler house cleanliness is important. Concrete floors should be sealed to keep dust down.

Legislation.Content: The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)
Boiler (Efficiency) Regulations 1993
Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996

Introduction.Content: Is the plant safe? It should be noted that fire prevention and fire alarms are not included in the scope of this document. Any persons working on such equipment should be registered with the Loss Prevention Council (www.bre.co.uk/frs) or should be the Manufacturer's nominated fire prevention provider. It is essential that the operation of all indicator lights should be checked regularly and that any malfunctions should be corrected as soon as possible. Boiler and Plant Room should not contain loose combustible materials.

Task.Action: Check valve and associated couplings for positive oil shut off.
Task.Notes: It is essential that the system will provide a positive shut off of the oil supply in an emergency. The valve should comply with current legislation.

Task.Action: Actuate and check that any dead weight or solenoid valves operate correctly.
Reset.
Task.Notes: Check that all interconnecting tension wire, fusible links fire buttons and pulleys are free for operation.

Task.Action: Check valve action.
Check for operation and sensitivity.
Test sensitivity. Determine if a test is possible if not refer to specifier.
Task.Notes: Determine if a test is possible, if not refer to specifier. It may be necessary to recalibrate, if so carry out strictly according to the manufacturer's instructions.

Task.Action: Actuate and recheck operation of the dead weight valve or solenoid.
Reset.
Task.Notes: Check all interconnecting tension wire, fusible links fire buttons and pulleys for free operation.

Task.Item: fusible links, inter-connecting tension wire and pulleys.
Task.Action: Inspect.
Task.Notes: Check that all are free for operation.

Task.Action: Operate to ensure that fuel feed system stops.

Task.Item: 4. Boiler control and high limit thermostats (thermal or manual reset).
Task.Action: Ensure these are set correctly. Check operation of pressure switches.
Task.Notes: Operation should be within the manufacturer's switching differential. Adjust if necessary. This note should be read in conjunction with item 7 -Smoke/heat detection.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Ensure foam inlet pipes are free from blockage.
Check operation.
Check all fuel supply valves for free operation.
Task.Notes: Ensure that each fuel supply value is complete with own wheel or key.

Task.Item: 9. Combustion air source into plant room.
Task.Action: Check that original provision has been left clear of any obstruction dirt.
Task.Notes: Inadequate combustion air provisions can create a hazard to both the equipment and the occupants of the plant room. Notify responsible person.

Legislation.Content: BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Waste and Wood Burning Appliances (Including Boilers) - Fire and Boiler Safety Circuits

Introduction.Content: Regular cleaning of flues is essential when burning waste and wood because tars and other residues may not be fully burned in the combustion chamber and condensation of combustion products can lead to blockage and fires in the flues
Introduction.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations. Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Item: 2. Fusible links, interconnecting tension wire and pulleys.
Task.Action: Inspect.
Operate to ensure that fuel feed system stops.

Task.Item: 4. Boiler controls and high limit stats.
Task.Action: Ensure these are set correctly.
Task.Notes: Operation should be within the manufacturer's switching differential. Adjust if necessary. This note should be read in conjunction with item 4 - Smoke/heat detection.

Task.Action: Ensure foam inlet pipes are free from blockage.
Check operation.
Task.Notes: Refer to Code of Practice BS 5839 and Fire alarm system SFG 22-01

Task.Action: Check all fuel supply valves for free operation.
Task.Notes: Ensure that each fuel supply valve is complete with its own wheel or key.

Legislation.Content: BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Waste and Wood Burning Appliances (Including Boilers) - Combustion Chamber

Introduction.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations. Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Action: Inspect, check for broken parts and clean conveyors, feeders, etc.
Task.Notes: Waste can be a very variable type of fuel and may contain stones, metal and other materials which can cause damage and breakage of the feed mechanism.

Task.Action: Inspect and check for wear.
Task.Notes: In pneumatic systems wear mainly occurs on the bends and wear plates are usually fitted. Any badly worn plates should be replaced.

Task.Action: Clean of any clinker, report to client if any repairs required.
Task.Notes: Uneven combustion is a feature of waste burning and this can lead to local overheating within the fuel bed. Clinker formation can occur together with distortion or failure of the fire grate bars.

Task.Action: Inspect for wear and where operation automatic reset controls.
Task.Notes: Always follow recommendations from manufacturer. Waste Disposal Regulations may apply.

Task.Action: Check condition and report.
Clean and check operation and reset.
Carry out and adjust primary and secondary and tertiary (if any) air for optimum combustion.
Task.Notes: Because of the variable nature of the fuel, allowance for some excess air is necessary.  With starved air (two phased combustion) tests should be carried out after each stage and should include CO.

Task.Action: Check all fuel supply valves for free operation.
Task.Notes: Ensure that each fuel supply valve is complete with its own wheel or key.

Legislation.Content: Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
BS EN 12170:2002 Heating systems in buildings. Procedure for the preparation of documents for operation, maintenance and use. Heating systems requiring a trained operator
BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.
Clean Air Act 1993

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Waste and Wood Burning Appliances (Including Boilers) - Boiler (if fitted)

Introduction.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations. Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Item: 1. Check operation in particular the safety controls.
Task.Action: Note any visible defects.
Task.Notes: Ensure system is full of water and the circuits are open.

Task.Action: Start up system and carry out tests.
Task.Notes: Because of the variable nature of the fuel, combustion tests should be carried out on a regular basis to monitor performance. The test should include smoke, draught chamber and flue gases which should include CO.

Task.Item: 3. Thermostats, pressure sensors, altitude gauges and thermostats.
Task.Action: Check for correct operation and settings.
Shut down, disconnect or remove fuses.

Task.Item: 5. Boiler flueways and tubes and connecting flue.
Task.Action: Open and remove by brushing and/or vacuum all soot and scale.
Task.Notes: When burning waste, the hot surfaces of fire or water tubes (if water tube boiler) can foul up very quickly and mechanical techniques of removing scale should be used. Waste Disposal Regulations may apply.

Task.Action: Check condition and report.
Reseal, check for air leaks, seal as necessary.

Task.Item: 8. Boiler return temperature and associated controls.
Task.Action: Check if appropriate.
Reconnect and test fire, carry out combustion test, refit casing and thoroughly clean down.
Task.Notes: A boiler is capable of exploding if safety controls fail and blocked flues will cause flue gas to leak into surrounding areas, causing damage and risks to life and health through carbon monoxide poisoning.

Legislation.Content: BS EN 12170:2002 Heating systems in buildings. Procedure for the preparation of documents for operation, maintenance and use. Heating systems requiring a trained operator
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
Clean Air Act 1993

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Atmospheric Gas Burner Boiler - Small and/or Wall Hung for Domestic/Light Commercial Installation

Task.Item: 1a. Before proceeding with dismantling of boiler.
Task.Action: Check casing for damage or breakages. Inspect for loose fittings or connections and any sign of leaks. Record settings.
Task.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations.  Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Action: Observe the main burner. Use a combustion analyser to measure CO & CO 2 content of flue gas. Check Gas pressure.  Record settings.
Task.Notes: Dark mauve flame and excessive lifting off indicate poor combustion.

Task.Action: Check that all are in accordance with current Codes of Practice.
Task.Notes: Local electrical isolator must be fitted. Supply to the boiler must be direct, i.e. not fed through a time switch.

Task.Item: 3. Isolate boiler for gas and electrical supplies.
Task.Action: Record any work which needs rectification or replacement.
Disconnect thermocouple and pilot tube from burners.

Task.Item: 5. Remove burners and pilot assembly and baffles if fitted.
Task.Action: Brush all accessible flueways thoroughly from top to bottom, clean all deposits from the burner box, refit baffles and flue cover - checking cover seal. Check for cracking and wear.
Task.Notes: Cleaning should be thorough and carried out as per the manufacturers instructions.

Task.Action: Remove.
Remove and clean ports.
Remove and clean.
Task.Notes: Clean by blowing through or washing. Do not use pin as this will damage the injector.

Task.Action: Replace/clean with fine wire brush, reassemble pilot.
Task.Notes: Make sure head lines up with the pilot and not the burner.

Task.Action: Replace.
Remove from burners and clean.
Refit.

Task.Item: 9. Burners, Gas valve, thermocouple and pilot tube.
Task.Action: Check adjust and refit along with main burner.
Open gas cock and test for gas soundness, reconnect electrical services. Test controls operation, relight pilot and run up boiler.
Task.Notes: Test flame setting and thermocouple sensitivity and check manifold gas pressure against manufacturer's settings, adjust if required.  If in doubt check gas supply standing pressure at the meter.

Task.Action: Ensure that no products of combustion are entering the area of the building where the boiler is situated.
Task.Notes: Undetected CO is life threatening (poisonous) and also causes energy waste. Flames should be bluish and burning in a stable manner. The burner should be quiet in operation, no excessive noise should occur when the burner ignition shuts down. In domestic premises consider the installation of a BS (www.bsi-global.com) approved CO detector.

Task.Action: Check electrical installation for safety and that local isolator is fitted.
Task.Notes: If not provide written report to client.

Task.Action: Provide written report.
Task.Notes: The report must be signed by the servicing engineer and the client/responsible person/clients representative . Premature failure of the plant will result if a satisfactory service is not carried out, by a competent engineer qualified as required by the Gas Safety Regulations. Depending on the nature/urgency of the fault and the type of premises this report may be verbal.

Task.Action: Recommendations.
Task.Notes: If after servicing the appliance is considered unsafe the recommendation to the client is that it must be taken out of use. If approval for this action is refused an appropriate label must be attached to the appliance and a written report must be signed by the client/responsible person/clients representative and both the gas supplier and a supervisor/manager informed.

Legislation.Content: Boiler (Efficiency) Regulations 1993
HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995

Introduction.Content: These boilers provide central heating and on demand domestic hot water without the need for a hot water storage cylinder (see Atmospheric Gas burner/boiler).

Task.Item: 1a. Before proceeding with dismantling of boiler.
Task.Action: Check Central Heating system for leaks.
Task.Notes: Flame must cover all flame parts and be light blue in colour.

Task.Action: Set appliance to DHW highest flow rate to observe the main burner. Use a combustion analyser to measure CO and CO 2 content of flue gas. Check Gas pressure, Water volume and pressure. Record settings.
Task.Notes: Dark mauve flame and excessive lifting off indicate poor combustion. If appliance is fitted in a hard water area (above 200 ppm), a suitable water treatment device should be fitted.

Task.Action: Check that all are in accordance with current Codes of Practice.
Task.Notes: Local electrical isolator must be fitted. Supply to the boiler must be direct, i.e. not fed through a time switch.

Task.Item: 3. Isolate boiler for gas and electrical supplies.
Task.Action: Record any work which needs rectification or replacement.
Disconnect thermocouple and pilot tube from burners.

Task.Item: 5. Remove burners and pilot assembly and baffles if fitted.
Task.Action: Brush all accessible flueways thoroughly from top to bottom, clean all deposits from the burner box, refit baffles and flue cover - checking cover seal. Check for cracking and wear.
Task.Notes: Cleaning should be thorough and carried out as per the manufacturers instructions.

Task.Action: Examine connections for water leaks and rectify as necessary.
Brush away deposits using a soft brush.
Task.Notes: If in hard water area and water treatment device is not fitted, the HW Heat Exchanger should be descaled.

Task.Action: Check for free running, mechanical drainage and clean with a soft brush.
Remove from burners and clean.
Refit.

Task.Item: 11. Burners, Gas valve, thermocouple and pilot tube.
Task.Action: Check, adjust and refit along with main burner.
Open gas cock and test for gas soundness, reconnect electrical services. Test controls operation, relight pilot and run up boiler.
Task.Notes: Test flame setting and thermocouple sensitivity and check manifold gas pressure against manufacturer's settings, adjust if required. If in doubt check gas supply standing pressure at the meter.

Task.Action: Ensure that no products of combustion are entering the area of the building where the boiler is situated.
Task.Notes: Undetected CO is life threatening (poisonous) and also causes energy waste. This can be achieved in domestic premises - consider the installation of a BS approved CO detector. Flames must be bluish and burning in a stable manner. The burner should be quiet in operation and no excessive noise should occur when the burner ignition shuts down.

Task.Action: Check electrical installation for safety and that local isolator is fitted.
Task.Notes: If not provide written report to client.

Task.Action: Check pressure in system is being maintained and that expansion vessel pressure conforms to the pre charged setting.
Provide written report.
Task.Notes: The report must be signed by the servicing engineer and the client/responsible person/clients representative. Premature failure of the plant will result if a satisfactory service is not carried out, by a competent engineer qualified as required by the Gas Safety Regulations. Depending on the nature/urgency of the fault and the type of premises this report may be verbal .

Task.Action: Recommendations.
Task.Notes: If after servicing the appliance is considered unsafe the recommendation to the client is that it must be taken out of use. If approval for this action is refused an appropriate label must be attached to the appliance and a written report must be signed by the client/responsible person/clients representative and both the gas supplier and a supervisor/manager informed.

Legislation.Content: Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)
Boiler (Efficiency) Regulations 1993
HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996

Introduction.Content:
The essential feature of a condensing boiler is that to increase the efficiency the flue gases are cooled below their dew point with the result that water is produced which has to be removed from the system.

Boiler room ventilation should comply with BS 5440 -2: 2009 for boilers not exceeding 70kW and BS 6644:2005 for boilers with a capacity between 70kW and 1.8MW.

Undetected CO is poisonous, life threatening and also causes energy waste. Flames should be bluish and burning in a stable manner. The burner should be quiet in operation, no excessive noise should occur when the burner ignites or shuts down. In domestic premises, consider the installation of a CO detector that complies with BS EN 50291-1:2010 and BS EN 50292:2002.

Task.Item: 1a. Before proceeding with dismantling of boiler.
Task.Action: Check Central Heating system for leaks.
Task.Notes: Flame must cover all flame parts and be light blue in colour.

Task.Action: Set appliance to DHW highest flow rate to observe the main burner. Use a combustion analyser to measure CO and CO2 content of flue gas. Check Gas pressure, Water volume with the boiler operating at low return temperatures (less than 50 C) check that condensate flows freely from the drain pipe.  Record settings.
Task.Notes: Dark mauve flame and excessive lifting off indicate poor combustion.  If appliance is fitted in a hard water area (above 200 ppm), a suitable water treatment device should be fitted.

Task.Action: Check that all are in accordance with current Codes of Practice.
Task.Notes: Local electrical isolator must be fitted. Supply to the boiler must be direct, i.e. not fed through a time switch.

Task.Item: 3. Isolate boiler for gas and electrical supplies.
Task.Action: Record any work which needs rectification or replacement.
Disconnect thermocouple and pilot tube from burners.

Task.Item: 5. Remove burners, pilot assembly and baffles (if fitted).
Task.Action: Brush all accessible flueways thoroughly from top to bottom, clean all deposits from the burner box, refit baffles and flue cover - checking cover seal. Check for cracking and wear.
Task.Notes: Cleaning should be thorough and carried out as per the manufacturer's instructions.

Task.Action: Examine connections for water leaks and rectify as necessary.
Clean, inspect and flush.
Brush away deposits using a soft brush.
Task.Notes: If in hard water area and water treatment device is not fitted, the heat exchanger should be descaled.

Task.Action: Check for free running, mechanical drainage and clean with a soft brush.
Remove from burners and clean.
Check that condensate flows freely at low boiler return temperatures.
Refit.

Task.Item: 12. Burners, Gas valve, Thermocouple and Pilot Tube.
Task.Action: Check, adjust and refit along with main burner.  Check that condensate flows freely at low boiler return temperatures.
Open gas cock and test for gas soundness, reconnect electrical services. Test controls operation, relight pilot and run up boiler.
Task.Notes: Test flame setting and thermocouple sensitivity and check manifold gas pressure against manufacturer's settings, adjust if required.  If in doubt check gas supply standing pressure at the meter.

Task.Action: Ensure that no products of combustion are entering the area of the building where the boiler is situated.
Task.Notes: Undetected CO is life threatening (poisonous) and also causes energy waste. This can be achieved in domestic premises - consider the installation of a BS approved CO detector. Flames should be bluish and burning in a stable manner. The burner should be quiet in operation, no excessive noise should occur when the burner ignition shuts down.

Task.Action: Check electrical installation for safety and that local isolator is fitted.
Task.Notes: If not provide written report to client.

Task.Action: Check pressure in system is being maintained and that expansion vessel pressure conforms to the pre changed setting.
Provide written report.
Task.Notes: The report must be signed by the servicing engineer and the client/responsible person/clients representative. Premature failure of the plant will result if a satisfactory service is not carried out, by a competent engineer qualified as required by the Gas Safety Regulations. Depending on the nature/urgency of the fault and the type of premises this report may be verbal.

Task.Action: Recommendations
Task.Notes: If, after servicing, the appliance is considered unsafe the recommendation to the client is that it must be taken out of use. If approval for this action is refused an appropriate label must be attached to the appliance and a written report must be signed by the client/responsible person/clients representative and both the gas supplier and a supervisor/manager informed.

These burners operate by mixing air and gas to provide an efficient combustion flame. This principle is used mainly for domestic and small commercial equipment. Introduction.Content:
A fan assisted type in which the gas and air is pre-mixed before the fan. This is not a pressure jet type burner. The air/fuel ration is controlled by an orifice plate and monitored by a pre-set differential pressure switch.

Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations.
Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Action: Check whether plant operating or not.
Task.Notes: For safety and operational reasons the status of the plant should be checked.

Task.Action: Check that all are in accordance with current Codes of Practice.
Switch on, carry out safety check of flame failure.
Carry out and note any visual defects. Arrange for record of test to be sent to the client.
Task.Notes: Pay particular attention to carbon monoxide (CO) as presence is dangerous and life threatening and indicates waste energy.

Task.Item: 5. Isolation from electricity and gas supply.

Task.Notes: Before starting any dismantling of equipment it is essential for safety reasons that the plant be isolated from incoming services.

Clean and check air passages.

Task.Action: Reassemble and fire, check air and gas settings, carry out combustion efficiency test.

Task.Action: Test under no air conditions.
Test and take probe readings.
Check security of mechanical parts and secure mounting of appliance.
Task.Notes: A maintenance check should be carried out on this type of burner twice a year but refer to manufacturer's specification.

Task.Action: Provide written report. The report should be signed by the service engineer and the client/clients representative/responsible person.
Task.Notes: Premature failure and excessive fuel costs will result if satisfactory service is not carried out.  All service and maintenance must be carried out by a registered engineer complying with Health and Safety requirements and possess accreditation in accordance with the Gas Safety Regulations.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Fuel Oil Distribution and Pipework using Medium (220/960 Sec) Oil

Introduction.Content:
There are four basic fuel systems, which can be subdivided into those used for distillate and those for residual oils. The use of residual oils necessitates the inclusion of equipment for pre-heating the fuel oil prior to the burner. This includes preheater coils in the storage tank, line tracing and final preheater either before or right at the burner nozzle. The oil supply temperature at the burner inlet must be sustained at the burner pump inlet as follows:
Class F (960 sec Redwood No 1 - 20cSt @ 100C in SI units) 43C-55C, at burner nozzle 104C
Class E (220 sec Redwood No 1 - 8cSt @ 100C in SI units) 10C-21C, at burner nozzle 82C

Task.Action: Check condition and test action of thermostat.
Task.Notes: Examine condition of wiring and control temperature of thermostat.

Task.Action: Inspect for soundness. Drain water from drain valve at base of tank.
Task.Notes: These tanks should be insulated and should be checked for damage and if outside, attention should be paid to waterproofing and checking for the presence of corrosion of the tank under the damaged insulation. Drain water from tank frequently.

Task.Action: Check thermostat setting, adjust if necessary.
Task.Notes: If electrical, check on current drawn and if different from norm, investigate and report to client. Check and record the transformer output voltage.

Task.Action: Examine and replace or repair as necessary.
Task.Notes: Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations.  Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

Task.Action: Clean and change if necessary.
Task.Notes: Sludge in medium fuel oil can be a major fault in a burner operation and regular checking of filters and cleaning of tanks may be necessary if oil is only used intermittently.

Task.Item: 6. Steam traps and drain valves (steam heated systems).
Task.Action: Check operation, repair or adjust as necessary.
Report on condition.
Task.Notes: Include any recommendations for future action in the report.

Introduction.Content:
A fan assisted nozzle oil air mix fully automatic.

Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations.  Refer to www.hse.gov.uk .

Task.Action: Check whether plant operating or not. A combustion test may be necessary.
Task.Notes: For safety and operational reasons the status of the plant should be checked.

Task.Action: Check that all are in accordance with Codes of Practice.
Switch on, carry out safety check of flame failure.
Carry out and note any visual defects.
Task.Notes: Leakage of all products of combustion (CO, CO² , SO² ) should be sought. Pay particular attention to carbon monoxide (CO) as its presence can be dangerous and wastes energy.

Task.Item: Isolation from electricity and oil supply
Task.Action: Switch off, remove fuses and turn off oil supply.
Task.Notes: Before starting any dismantling of equipment it is essential for safety reasons that the plant be isolated from incoming services.

Task.Action: Remove, clean combustion head, ignition electrodes and inspect HT leads.
Clean filter and inspect nozzle for wear. Renew annually.
Task.Notes: Erosion or surface defects on the nozzle can affect the profile of the emerging jet of oil and lead to a poor flame shape and bad combustion.

Task.Action: Reassemble and set head to manufacturer's requirements.
Remove, clean and lubricate as required, clean fan scroll.
Task.Notes: Inspect oil pump flexible drive coupling before re-assembling.  See Motors (SFG 39-01).

Task.Action: Remove and clean, inspect pump seals for signs of wear.
Inspect flexible oil line coupling, clean and renew oil line filter, clean photo cell and adjust position.
Switch on and check flame shape and appearance if visible.
Test, record oil pressure.
Test for satisfactory operation.
Carry out combustion test and check efficiency of combustion and levels of pollutant gases - adjust burner in accordance with results.
Task.Notes: On larger systems combustion tests should be carried out regularly to monitor performance and avoid energy waste.

Task.Action: Check security of mechanical parts and secure mounting of appliance.
Task.Notes:
A maintenance check should be carried out on this type of burner twice a year but refer to manufacturer's specification.  

All service and maintenance works must be carried out by a competent engineer in accordance with BS Codes of Practice for oil firing.

Legislation.Content: Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
Control of Pollution Act 1974
Clean Air Act 1993

Introduction.Content:
A simple oil burner.

Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations.  Refer to www.hse.gov.uk .

Task.Action: Check whether plant operating or not. A combustion test may be necessary.
Task.Notes: For safety and operational reasons the status of the plant should be checked.

Task.Action: Check that all are in accordance with Codes of Practice.
Switch on, and note level of float chamber.
Carry out and note any visual defects.
Task.Notes: Leakage of all products of combustion (CO, CO², SO² ) should be sought. Pay particular attention to carbon monoxide (CO) as its presence can be poisonous and wastes energy.

Task.Item: Isolation from electricity and oil supply
Task.Action: Switch off, remove fuses and turn off oil supply.
Task.Notes: Before starting any dismantling of equipment it is essential for safety reasons that the plant be isolated from incoming services.

Task.Action: Remove, if possible clean and trim/replace the wick.
Clean filter and set float chamber level in accordance with manufacturer's instructions.
Assemble and switch on in order to check the flame shape.
Provide written report, which should be signed by the service engineer and kept by the client.
Task.Notes:
Premature failure will result if satisfactory service is not carried out.

All service and maintenance must be carried out by a registered engineer in accordance with HSAWA requirements and in accordance with BS Codes of Practice for Oil Firing.

Task.Action: Carry out combustion test and check efficiency of combustion and levels of pollutant gases - adjust burner in accordance with results.
Task.Notes: On larger systems combustion tests should be carried out regularly to monitor performance and avoid energy waste.

Legislation.Content: Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
Clean Air Act 1993
Control of Pollution Act 1974

Introduction.Content:
Burners of this type should be serviced every three months, certain operations require a lesser frequency and this is noted in the frequency column. These units are specialised and should only be serviced by trained personnel. This does not apply to the filters which should be cleaned by the customer at least once per week.

Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations.
Refer to www.hse.gov.uk for detail.

Task.Action: Check whether plant operating or not.
Task.Notes: For safety and operational reasons the status of the plant should be checked.

Task.Item: 2. Oil, gas, electrical and ventilating systems.
Task.Action: Check that all are in accordance with Codes of Practice.
Check.
Carry out leak test of all joints downstream of interlock isolator.
Check operation of leak test equipment.
If practical - check.
Check integrity.
Fire if possible, carry out safety check of flame failure device.
Check and adjust if necessary.
Renew seals and gaskets if necessary.
Lift` bearings.

Task.Item: 5. Atomisers and spray tip if fitted.
Task.Action: Check.
Check.
Carry out and note any visual defects.
Task.Notes: Pay particular attention to carbon monoxide (CO) as its presence can be poisonous and wastes energy.

Task.Action: Check panel, junction box and terminals.
Check rating.
Check settings.
Check security of mechanical parts and secure mounting of appliance.
Should be signed by service engineer and kept by the client.
Task.Notes: Premature failure may result if satisfactory service is not carried out. All service and maintenance must be carried out by a registered engineer in accordance with current HSAWA (http://www.hse.gov.uk) requirements.

Task.Action: Recommendations
Task.Notes: If, after servicing, the burner is considered unsafe the recommendation to the client is that it must be taken out of use. If approval for this action is refused an appropriate label must be attached to the appliance and a written report must be signed by the client/responsible person/clients representative and both the gas supplier and a supervisor/manager informed.

Legislation.Content: Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)
Boiler (Efficiency) Regulations 1993
Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Building Management Systems - Central Operator Station

Introduction.Content: Care should be taken with regard to the system status, where necessary arrange co-ordination with building occupiers.

Task.Action: Perform diagnostic tasks and check computer operation.
Task.Notes: This routine will check all aspects of computer hardware and software.

Task.Action: Check real-time clock and date settings.
Check condition, clean and lubricate if necessary.
Task.Notes: Do not lubricate if sealed for life bearings.  Wipe off any excess lubricant as it will attract dust which will stick to it.

Task.Action: Inspect and clean or change as necessary.

a) Take back up copy of site specific data files

b) Verify operating programmes and functionality.
Task.Notes: Ensure that security is retained and that any updating of files is incorporated.  It is recommended that a copy of the back-up data is stored in a fire proof safe or off-site.

Task.Action: Check security, integrity and for physical damage.
Clean according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Check and replace if necessary.
Task.Notes: Battery disposal should be in accordance with www.hse.gov.uk and Environmental Requirements.

Task.Action: Check for smooth operation and clean ball as necessary.
Task.Notes: Client may ask for more frequent maintenance of mouse.

Task.Action:
Check:

a) focus

b) contrast

c) brightness

d) for correct operation.

Check:

a) focus

b) contrast

c) brightness

d) for correct operation

e) degauss.
Task.Notes: With most VDUs the screen is automatically degaussed when equipment is switched on.

Task.Action: Check for correct operation and clean.
Clean with approved cleanser.
Task.Notes: Treat with anti-static compound.  Depending on use and location more frequent cleaning may be necessary.

Task.Action: Check security, integrity, and for physical damage.
Use recommended cleaning agent.

Check, adjust and replace if necessary:

a) paper feed

b) transport system

c) printer cartridge.
Check stocks.

Introduction.Content: Care should be taken with regard to the system status, where necessary arrange co-ordination with building occupiers.

Task.Action: Check integrity of data flow in both directions.
Task.Notes: If more than one path exists all must be verified.

Task.Action: Check operation and visually inspect.  Check environmental conditions of all equipment are within prescribed limits.
Task.Notes: To include modems, line drivers, telemetry cables and interface units.

Task.Action: Check operation and visually inspect.
Check integrity of data flow in both directions.
Task.Notes: If more than one data path exists, all must be verified.  Caution - there may be interaction with specialist applications.

Task.Action: Check security, integrity, and for damage.
Confirm that all critical alarms are received by the central supervisor.  Check spurious alarms and reported faults (as incurred).
Check generation of alarms from all input and output devices.
Check communications between central supervisory computer and outstations and other networked devices.

Introduction.Content: Care should be taken with regard to the system status, where necessary, arrange co-ordination with building occupiers.

Task.Action: Check mechanical and environmental condition.
Task.Notes: Environmental conditions, e.g. temperature and humidity should be within manufacturer's recommended limits.

Task.Action: Check security, integrity and for damage.
Task.Notes: Includes security of incoming cables, prevention of ingress of moisture, door seals etc.

Task.Action: Carry out voltage check on all power supplies.
Task.Notes: Check automatic restart, re-booting of software programme.

Task.Action: Check against manufacturer's specification.  Replace as necessary.
Interrupt electrical supply to each outstation, reinstate and ensure system restarts satisfactorily.
Check by activating (where from fixed sensing/control device).
Task.Notes: Care should be taken to isolate local operation.

Task.Action: Check operation of output stopping by operating routine (where appropriate).  Check switching by software interlocks.
Task.Notes: Should include starting and stopping operations.  Does not apply to connected devices.

Task.Action: Read and check calibration of analogue inputs.
Check for accuracy of output signal.
Check status.
Check integrity, alarms, interlocks, optimisation.

Introduction.Content: Different manufacturers have adopted different approaches to software development and the tables below show some typical functions and the action which should be taken.

Task.Action: Check integrity of the installed programme.  Check sequence, operation of control, outputs and check stability of plant. Undertake as necessary fine tuning of control loops. Adjust settings in conjunction with the building manager to achieve the required internal environmental conditions.
Task.Notes: Frequency should be agreed with client. This action should be related to the critical nature of the operation.

Task.Action: Verify operation by interrogating software/hardware copy.
Task.Notes: Building layouts and occupational requirements are seldom of a static nature. Therefore control strategies and their suitability need to be reassessed on a regular basis.

Task.Action: Check real time clock and date for accuracy throughout system.
Review current operating parameters according to clients needs.
Review need for existing data logs. Delete/archive logs as required.
Task.Notes: Report to client on the need to review existing arrangements.

Task.Item: Alarms - faults, out of limit alarms
Task.Action: Check that plant alarms and software interlocks with safety implications are operating correctly. Check alarm priorities, routings and reactions. Check alarm priorities are appropriate.
Task.Notes: The checking of possible reactions to certain critical alarms and programmes must be carefully co-ordinated with other trades and building tenants. Where there are safety implications, verify alarm integrity. Review system of reporting outstanding alarm conditions and report discrepancies.

Task.Action: Review frequencies of generated alarms. Review alarm log records for indication of untoward conditions.
Check plant start up sequence.
Check plant start up sequence.
Check sequence and operation.
Check operation.
Verify operation.
Check manual overrides and effect on system, and effect on system operation.
Task.Notes: At client access, level review parameters, lockouts, changes, all points in manual override and forced analogue values. Review findings with client.

Task.Action: Back up all outstation files. Make two copies. Store one on site and one off site.
Advise where control strategy descriptions in operating and maintenance manuals are incorrect. Ensure, where appropriate, additional documentation meets all quality assurance procedures.
Check schematics indicate correctly.
Maintain a log book of all changes made to the system.

Introduction.Content:
Warning Chiller units may be operated remotely and it is essential that the equipment be isolated at source before commencing any maintenance work. These notes should be read in conjunction with the manufacturer's recommended maintenance procedures and in particular supplementary work may be required in the case of larger units above 50kW. Many packaged water chillers have microprocessor controls that can be interrogated using passwords. The password is usually at two levels, level one for interrogation and level two for alterations. For service work, access to level one is required. These processors can be used for diagnostic purposes and coupled to pressure transducers can also give pressure readings.

Where the installed power on the refrigeration system exceeds 25kW, a Written Scheme of Examination may be required to comply with the current Pressure Systems Safety Regulations.

Personnel carrying out leak checking, gas recovery or other refrigerant handling activities such as plant installation and maintenance must have a suitable refrigerant handling qualification. These works are covered under the current F-Gas Regulations on fluorinated gases.

ALWAYS UPDATE RECORDS

Task.Action: Check operating status.
Task.Notes:
Before undertaking the work, check with the building manager that the system does not serve a heat sensitive area such as a computer room. If it does, confirm with the building occupants that they are aware that work is being carried out.

Do not only rely on the microprocessor readouts, always check against calibrated equipment if in doubt.

Task.Action: Check circuit pressures and superheat temperatures. Check alarm and run lights and remote alarm lights associated with packs.
Task.Notes: Refrigeration chillers should be alternated at least every three months by means of the `lead/leg' selector switch. Where operating information is displayed on central console, check that no discrepancies exist between display and master gauges, if these do occur report and change transducer(s). For non electronic systems check installed gauges against master gauges.

Task.Action: Check for refrigerant and all leaks.
Task.Notes:
Refrigeration circuits should be alternated at least every three months by means of the `lead/leg' selector switch. Where operating information is displayed on central console, check that no discrepancies exist between display and master gauges.  If these do occur report and change transducer(s).

For non electronic systems check installed gauges against master gauges.

Systems using R22 can only use reclaimed stocks of gas for topping up purposes only and this shall be prohibited in the maintenance and servicing of refrigeration and air conditioning equipment from 01/01/2015.

Normal systems:
<3 kg no leak test required
3 kg to 30 kg annual leak test required
30 kg to 300 kg half yearly leak test required and
>300 kg quarterly leak test required.

Hermetically sealed systems:
<6 kg no leak test required
6 kg to 30 kg annual leak test required
30 kg to 300 kg half yearly leak test required and
>300 kg quarterly leak test required.

Where a system has a refrigerant charge greater than 300kg, an automatic leak detection system must be installed on the system to comply with the F-Gas Regulations. 

Do no overlook remote condensers and pay particular attention to bolted joints, sight glass stands and atmospheric relief valve vent.

Task.Action: Adjust if necessary.
Check supply and return water temperatures.
Task.Notes: Abnormal temperatures can be a sign of low refrigerant or poor heat rejection.

Task.Action: Check glycol concentration in chilled water.
Task.Notes: If concentration has fallen check pipework for leaks as per item for 'Leakage'.

Task.Action: Check that this is in accordance with the manufacturer's recommended figure.
Check all equipment and pipework for oil and water leaks and rectify.
Task.Notes:
Check for leaks should be part of the routine servicing.

“Checked for leakage” means that the Joints, valves including stems, seals, including seals on replaceable driers and filters, parts of the system subject to vibration, connections to safety or operational devices of the equipment or system is examined for leakage using direct or indirect measuring methods, focusing on those parts of the equipment or system most likely to leak.


The frequency of testing depends on refrigerant charge and system type.

Task.Action: Inspect and check for vibration, chaffing, security and leakage.
Task.Notes: Vibration is usually the result of loose or inadequate fixing of pipe supports and can give rise to leakage of refrigerant.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Check operation.
Task.Notes: If serving computer facilities, check that alarm is not connected to computer shut-down system.

Task.Action: Check operation.

Check operation of temperature control thermostats.
Inspect electrical panel and components for wear especially the compressor contactor(s).
Check operation of safety thermostats and timers.
Check and record.
Check condition and make good any defects however small.
Task.Notes: Poor or faulty insulation can lead to loss of efficiency and energy wastage.

Task.Action: Carry out routine Maintenance.

Check for damage to flexible conduits.
Tighten all terminal connections.
Isolate control panel and inspect for signs of overheating.
Check integrity of electrical insulation.
Check all safety cut-outs including high and low pressure safety cut-outs and the antifreeze thermostat cut-out for operation and correct calibration.
Task.Notes:
Individual machines vary, cut outs could include:
i)  oil differential switches
ii)  oil, high and low temperature
iii)  water temperature differential switches on chillers and evaporators.

Task.Action: Check condition.
Task.Notes: Check waterside pressure drop across the heat exchanger(s) for fouling.

Legislation.Content: F-Gas Regulation No. 517/2014 on fluorinated gases
Pressure Equipment Regulations 1999 and 2002 amendment
Pressure Systems Safety Regulations 2000

Introduction.Content:
This is a specialised field and requires suitably competent engineers to maintain this type of equipment.

The most important feature of an absorption system is the need to maintain as required by the manufacturer, especially the specific gravity. These machines require daily recorded checks of machine performance which are compared with the previous readings. Changes must be noted.

Lithium bromide/water units use water as the refrigerant. The water inside the unit will be boiling at temperatures around 3 deg C, and condensing at temperatures only a little above ambient. To achieve this, the units are under a high vacuum.

If the vacuum degrades, the unit will cease to function properly. Thus it is advisable to monitor the vacuum level closely, and restore it using a vacuum pump when necessary. After any service work that requires the unit to be opened, the vacuum, must always be restored, and the unit resealed.

A Written Scheme of Examination may be required to comply with the Pressure Systems Safety Regulations 2000.

ALWAYS UPDATE RECORDS

Task.Action: Check as per instructions of manufacturer.
Task.Notes: Record and note changes in specific gravity for given conditions.

Task.Action: Determine as per manufacturer`s instructions.
Task.Notes: Note leak rate and compare with manufacturer`s maximum rate. If higher, this indicates that machine has a leak and action must be taken to trace and rectify.

Task.Action: Check as per instructions of manufacturer.
Check as per instructions of manufacturer.
Check as per instructions of manufacturer.
Task.Notes: Record results and check with last reading.

Task.Action: Check operation as per manufacturer`s instructions.
Check for scale, action be determined by findings.
Task.Notes: When chemical cleaning is carried out ensure that competent company and personnel are used.

Task.Action: Take as per manufacturer`s instructions. Add amounts of chemicals as advised by chemist (i.e. inhibitor octyl-alcohol etc.)
Task.Notes: Record results and compare with last set of readings. Record details of action, compare with last report and file.

Task.Item: 11. i. Absorber loss, ii. Decrystallisation, (as required)
Task.Action: Determine as per manufacturer`s instructions. Experience is vital in determining the significance of any loss.
Task.Notes: Recorded loss should not be greater than 3b0 F. Measure and record:- i. refrigerant temperature, ii. temperature and specific gravity of solution iii. temperature at the outlet of the solution pump. Early resolution of any crystallisation problems is important as damage to pumps may occur.

Task.Action: Replace as per manufacturer`s specifications.
Check condition and make good any defects however small.
Task.Notes: Poor or faulty insulation can lead to loss of efficiency, energy wastage and the formation of condensation.

Task.Action: Visually inspect for corrosion, erosion and deformities.
Any pressure relief device should be checked if fitted.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Gas Fired Absorption Chiller Up to 18kw Cooling Capacity

Introduction.Content:
These units are Direct gas fired and maintenance of the gas burners should be carried out in line with the relevant specification. They are available in cooling only or heat pump version. Care should be taken as the refrigeration system contains Ammonia Solutions. Only tools which are capable of handling Ammonia should be used.

There are a number of Laws and British Standards that must be observed when working on ammonia systems.

A Written Scheme of Examination may be required to comply with the Pressure Systems Safety Regulations 2000.

ALWAYS UPDATE RECORDS.

Task.Action: Check that unit is level and on good foundations. Visually inspect for corrosion, erosion and deformities.
Visually check and clean when required the condenser fins.
Check absorber visually.
Check that condenser fan height is at design setting.
Task.Notes: Adjust according to instruction manual. See also Fans SFG 20

Task.Action: Check water level in water pan.
Check and adjust chilled water flow rate (fountain height) see instruction manual.
Check and top up fluid if necessary.
Check or replace if necessary.
Task.Notes: For further maintenance procedures see Belts SFG 04.

Task.Action: Visual check solution pump.
Purge pressure check high side and low side pressure.
Measure and record ammonia charge.
Take a sample of oil for analysis.
Task.Notes: If excessive moisture is found, appropriate action shall be taken to correct the balance. If the oil is PAG (or similar) great care should be taken to ensure that the sample itself is not contaminated during handling.

Task.Action: Undertake maintenance on Compressors.
Task.Notes: For further guidance see Compressors SFG 12, Condensers SFG 13 and Evaporators SFG 19.

Legislation.Content: The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)
Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995
HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996

Introduction.Content:
It should be noted that the frequency of maintenance relates to equipment which is generally in clean surroundings but where the environment is dirty, i.e. dust or fluff, more frequent maintenance may be necessary.

Any maintenance carried out on the equipment should be in accordance with the manufacturers' recommendations.

Consideration should be given to the discharge of secondary energy - i.e. steam, pressurised water, hot oil, hot surfaces etc.

The method statement and accompanying risk assessment should be read, understood and implemented during this task.

Make sure there is a safe system of works in place when undertaking this PPM.

Refrigeration equipment containing 3kg or more of F gas refrigerant must be checked for leakage by certified personnel on a regular basis. The frequency of testing depends on refrigerant charge and system type.

Task.Action:
Check for correct operation.
Clean and check for any damage.
Check operation of evaporator fan.
Task.Notes: Correct operation is indicated by even frost formation on cooler face and/or on distribution lines. Ensure unit is thoroughly defrosted and coils are free of ice before putting back into service.

Task.Action: Check fixing is secure and wiring properly clipped.
Task.Notes: Ensure wiring is clipped away from tray heaters, fan motors and blades.

Task.Action: Check operation, mountings, guards and blades. Check bearings, lubricate if necessary.
Task.Notes: Where excessive end float or bearing wear is found, report on need for replacement.

Check operation and condition.
Check for cleanliness and the operation of pumps, probes and heaters where fitted.
Check for vibration and test for leaks. Check insulation for damage and replace/repair as necessary.

Isolate panel. Check all connections and wiring.

Check all wiring, including lead, plug and terminal connections for signs of overheating and physical damage of insulation (tighten connections where necessary).

Carry out Earth Continuity Test [reading should be less than 0.5 ohms].

Check insulation resistance [reading should not be less than 0.5 M.ohms].
Task.Notes: Ensure correct fuses are fitted and spares are available.

Check for correctness, against calibrated unit.
Check for correct operation and ensure handle is illuminated. Ensure any personnel can exit the cold room safely in an emergency.

Check and clean condenser (air cooled).

Check and report on condition of water cooled condenser.

Check and report on the fabric of the cold room.

Check condition of door, door seal and closures.
Check operation of thermostatic expansion valves.
See Refrigerant Distribution System (SFG 46-01)
Task.Notes:
Check for leaks should be part of the routine servicing by plant attendants.

Where a system has a refrigerant charge greater than 300kg, an automatic leak detection system must be installed on the system to comply with the F Gas Regulations.

It should be noted that the frequency of maintenance relates to equipment which is generally in clean surroundings but where the environment is dirty, i.e. dust or fluff, more frequent maintenance may be necessary.

Any maintenance carried out on the equipment should be in accordance with the manufacturers' recommendations.

Consideration should be given to the discharge of secondary energy - i.e. steam, pressurised water, hot oil, hot surfaces etc.

The method statement and accompanying risk assessment should be read, understood and implemented during this task.

Make sure there is a safe system of works in place when undertaking this PPM.

Refrigeration equipment containing 3kg or more of F gas refrigerant must be checked for leakage by certified personnel on a regular basis. The frequency of testing depends on refrigerant charge and system type.

Introduction.Content:
Ensure that, following all inspection visits, conditional reports shall be submitted to the client, including all specialist reports and test equipment printouts.

In addition, ensure that a Site Logbook is maintained on site containing duplicate copies of all the reports information submitted to the client.

Task.Action: Clean equipment , check leads for breaks, splits and loose connections. Damp wipe leads to remove stickiness check the lead and make repairs if necessary. Check all amplifier connections, knobs and sliders - tighten any that are loose and remove excess dust or foreign objects in those that are sticking. Ensure all leads are neatly coiled to avoid twisting and tangles.
Task.Notes: Any evidence of tampering or damage should be recorded and reported to the client.

Task.Action: Clean the heads on audio cassette decks, cd and minidisc players.
Task.Notes: Leave them to dry for a few minutes before attempting to use the player again.

Task.Action: Check all distribution field wiring and containment. Check to ensure that all leads are plugged in firmly into the correct connectors which should also be tightened if loose. Ensure that sound quality is good and free from crackling. Inspect for damage. Test each speaker and check earthing where appropriate. Check that music and other on-line activities are cut out when announcements are made.
Check the base of the microphone for bent or loose pins. Repair if necessary. Operate speech key and check anode currents.

Undo the screw at the side of the canon plug, carefully remove the centre from the casing to it`s limit (tugging and pulling may disconnect the wires) and check that the wires inside are firmly soldered. Any wire that has become detached should be re-soldered into place.
Unscrew the casing and lower gently, check that the wires are firmly in place and re-solder if necessary.
Check loop is active and is not suffering any `Blind Spots`.
Task.Notes: If any found report to the client.

Task.Action: Check mains power supplies. Examine all plugs and fuses for condition. Measure resistance of installation cables.
Test system is fully operational
Task.Notes: Provide a signed engineers report, one copy to be left in Site Log Book and a further copy to be submitted to the client.

Task.Action: Check functioning of interface.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Compressors Refrigeration - Reciprocal - (Includes Hermetic, Semi-Hermetic and Open)

Introduction.Content:
These machines come in a wide range of sizes, the larger machines can be complex both in terms of operation and maintenance requirements. In the case of compressors serving small air conditioning systems which may only run during the summer months, these may require less frequent maintenance.

For the maintenance of rotary compressors refer to the manufacturer's maintenance instructions.

Where the installed power on the refrigeration system exceeds 25kW, a Written Scheme of Examination may be required to comply with the Pressure Systems Safety Regulations.

Service providers must be registered to an Approved Certified Scheme provider, in accordance with the F Gas and Building Regulations.

Task.Action: Check and record suction and discharge pressure, oil pressure.
Task.Notes: Where gauges are fitted, the plant operator should record the readings every month.

Task.Action: Check and compare with manufacturers recommended figures.
Check whether plant in use.  If meter fitted record hours run.
Task.Notes: For operational and safety reasons the status of the plant should be checked.  To isolate, remove fuses and ensure other services are switched or valved off.

Task.Action:
Personnel carrying out leak checking, gas recovery or other refrigerant handling activities such as plant installation and maintenance must have a suitable refrigerant handling qualification.

These works are covered under the current F-Gas regulations on fluorinated gases.

ALWAYS UPDATE RECORDS.
Task.Notes:
Check for leaks should be part of the routine servicing by Refrigeration Engineers.
 
Where a system has a refrigerant charge greater than 300kg, an automatic leak detection system must be installed on the system to comply with the F-Gas Regulations.

Task.Action: Check for oil and refrigerant leaks. Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks. Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks. Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.

Check for oil and refrigerant leaks. Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check level and condition.
Check operation.
Task.Notes: The control should be in the 'ON' position at all times.

Task.Action: Check condition and alignment.
Task.Notes: If undue noise or vibration report to client. Drive belt replacement intervals need to be established.

Task.Action: Observe and include crankcase, seal housing and cylinder surface temperature.
Test and ensure correct operation.
Task.Notes: Include high pressure cut-outs, low pressure cut-outs and oil pressure cut-outs.

Task.Action: Check quantity and moisture content at liquid level sight glass.
Check for any abnormalities.
Lubricate according to manufacturer's instructions.  Check full load current.

Pressure Systems Safety Regulations 2000

Where the installed power on the refrigeration system exceeds 25kW, a Written Scheme of Examination may be required to comply with the Pressure Systems Safety Regulations.

Service providers must be registered to an Approved Certified Scheme provider, in accordance with the F Gas and Building Regulations.

Task.Action: Dismantle and inspect.
Check that it is functioning correctly.
Inspect at intervals recommended by manufacturer.
Task.Notes: If necessary, take the appropriate corrective action.

Introduction.Content:
More frequent maintenance checks should be carried out by the client and local maintenance personnel.

These machines come in a wide range of sizes, the larger machines can be complex both in terms of operation and maintenance requirements. In the case of compressors serving small air conditioning systems which may only run during the summer months, these may require less frequent maintenance.

For the maintenance of rotary compressors refer to the manufacturer's maintenance instructions.

Where the installed power on the refrigeration system exceeds 25kW, a Written Scheme of Examination may be required to comply with the Pressure Systems Safety Regulations.

Service providers must be registered to an Approved Certified Scheme provider, in accordance with the F Gas and Building Regulations.

Task.Action: Check running conditions, oil pressure, purge unit operation, oil level and oil return system. Look for signs of leakage.
Task.Notes: Note any unusual noises, check cooling tower operation.

Task.Action: Check compressor and motor holding down bolts and tighten if necessary.
Check frequency of discharges.
Task.Notes: Count should be over a minimum of two cycles.

Task.Action: Check oil pressure differential and chilled water temperature and flow rate.
Task.Notes: These should be at the controller set point. Check that condenser water flow rates and temperature levels are within acceptable limits. Examine log to check that there is no evidence of fouled tubes or air on the refrigerant side.

Task.Action: Change in accordance with manufacturer's instructions.
Change both filter and oil drier return system.
Take sample for analysis.

Task.Item: Purge unit valves, valves and associated equipment
Task.Action: Clean and inspect.
Remove and flush shell. Clean the orifices.
Task.Notes:
Orifices are:-

a) liquid supply to cooling coil,

b) gas pressure to pressure switch.

Task.Action: Change.
Change.
Change the filter/drier, check eductor tee is undamaged, clean. Clean dirt leg.
Change.
Task.Notes: Inspect thoroughly for evidence of metallic particles. Their presence would indicate bearing damage.

Task.Action: Check that they are working satisfactorily.
Task.Notes: Pay particular attention to current limiting devices.

Task.Action: Check water pressure drops.
Check settings of cooling tower fan controls.
Task.Notes: See Heat Rejection Systems SFG30-01.  Check water treatment and make up supply.  Clean all water strainers.

Task.Action: Carry out electrical insulation tests. Check air impeller or water cooling coil is clean and efficient. Check motor and compressor alignment.
Task.Notes: Ensure that the liquid supply for cooling the motor is adequate. If appropriate remove filter and renew.  (See also Motors 39-01).

Where a system has a refrigerant charge greater than 300kg, an automatic leak detection system must be installed on the system to comply with the F-Gas Regulations.

Task.Action: Record inlet and outlet temperature on water side.  Pressure drop across condenser, head pressure and condensing temperature.
Task.Notes: Any marked difference to the design figures could indicate internal fouling of the condenser and may require additional work.

Task.Action: Check.

Check and record pressure drop across pump.  
Check for leakage, bearing noise and unusual bearing temperature.  
Lubricate according to manufacturer's instructions.  
Check motor current.
Check external condition, leak tightness of glands and seats, operational spindles and hand wheels.
Check and clean.
Task.Notes:
On open systems more frequent cleaning will be necessary.  
Check that condenser water is sterile before opening any drains and valves.  
System could contain legionella bacterium.  Provider should take suitable precautions.

Task.Action:
Check condition, if dirty open.  If necessary clean with a correctly sized brush through the tubes.  
If brushing does not successfully clean the condenser, consider acid treatment.  Regular use of acid will reduce the working life of the tubes.  
Inspect for alkaline deposits and/or corrosion.
Task.Notes:
If tubes are heavily scaled, refer to water treatment provider for explanation as to why system is not effective.  
Acid can be used for scale removal by specialist if absolutely necessary but can reduce the thickness of the tube walls and hence reduce life expectancy.

Task.Action: Check for presence of non-condensable gases, purge or vent if necessary, but only if legally qualified via approved scheme.
Task.Notes: Presence of non-condensable gases will indicate a possible leak on the vacuum side of the refrigerant circuit.  Do not release refrigerant to atmosphere.

Task.Action: Isolate condensers and drain down.
Task.Notes:
Seek advice from water treatment provider to protect from freezing.

 

Only shut down condensers where the refrigeration and air conditioning system has been shut down for the winter.

Task.Action:
Personnel carrying out leak checking, gas recovery or other refrigerant handling activities such as plant installation and maintenance must have a suitable refrigerant handling qualification.

These works are covered under the current F-Gas regulations on fluorinated gases.

Task.Action: Check pressure and pressure switches using gauges.
Ensure that they do not by-pass.
Task.Notes: Compressor should not cycle on low pressure switch.

Task.Item: 3. Head pressure control devices (fan speed and sequencing).
Task.Action: Check operation.
Check for security and tightness.
Inspect and clean. Test for refrigerant leak and oil staining on the end of the coils.
Task.Notes: Check for damage to fins, comb out. Blow out with dry, oxygen free nitrogen. The unit can be chemically clean if necessary, however, this should be at the last resort as the fins may be damaged further by the acid. Only fully Competent trained staff can do this work.

Task.Action: Clean and secure.
Task.Notes: Remove any rust spots and treat. Check fan guards. Ensure all bolts/screws etc. are in place and tight.

Task.Item: 7. Alignment and wear of belt drives, where applicable.
Task.Action: Check pulley alignment and belt wear.
Task.Notes: Drive belt replacement intervals need to be established.

Task.Action: Lubricate control damper bearings.
Check and repair/replace as necessary.
Check and tighten as necessary. Check condition of flexible conduits, wiring and insulation.
Inspect connections, pipes and supports for damage, loose or missing fittings. Repair as necessary.

Personnel carrying out leak checking, gas recovery or other refrigerant handling activities such as plant installation and maintenance must have a suitable refrigerant handling qualification. These works are covered under EC Regulation 842/2006, Fluorinated Greenhouse Gases Regulations 2009 (FGG Regulations 2009).
