Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Control Panels - Electrical Services (Excluding Electrical Controllers and Pneumatic Relays)

Introduction.Content:
This task does not cover electrical controllers and pneumatic relays.


Before commencing any maintenance work on control panels, read Control Panels and Controllers SFG 14-01 Introductory Procedures, very carefully and follow all the safety procedures.

Task.Action: Check for any physical or mechanical damage. Door locks should be checked.
Task.Notes: Any damaged equipment mounted on the front should be made safe and replaced as soon as possible. Locks should be checked for correct security and locking arrangements.

Task.Action: Inspect for correct mechanical and electrical operation. Lubricate any moving parts as required. Check correct operation of door interlock mechanism and adjust if necessary. Clean out interior.
Task.Notes: Physically check for security all mains connections.  Examine both fixed and moving contacts for wear or 'pitting'.  Use only manufacturer's recommended lubricants.  Redress or replace contacts according to the manufacturer's instructions.  Ensure that any mains 'shrouding' is refitted after the completion of the work.

Task.Item: 3. Fuses. Ensure circuits are dead before carrying out actions.
Task.Action: Inspect fuse carrier/fuse holder for signs of overheating. Check fuse rating and terminations for tightness. Apply grease to fuse holder if required.
Task.Notes: Replace if necessary, establish cause of overheating and rectify.  Value of fuse should be checked against the circuit application and electrical load.

Task.Action: Inspect for signs of overheating and replace if necessary. Inspect connections and tighten if necessary. Check operation by tripping or 'test' facility, if fitted.
Task.Notes: Establish cause of overheating and rectify. Ensure value of breaker corresponds with circuit application and electrical load.

Task.Action: Test operation using test facility.
Check contact for correct mechanical and electrical operation.
Carry out maintenance as for power contactors.

Task.Notes: Direct on line, star delta two speed-dual, wound two speed-pole change reversing auto transformer.

Task.Action: Inspect for signs of overheating.
Task.Notes: Replace if necessary after having established the cause and rectified it.

Task.Action: Inspect for signs of overheating.
Isolate supplies, inspect for signs of overheating, or damage or burnt out cables. Inspect mechanical support systems and adjust fixings if necessary.
Task.Notes: Check all cable crimps for security and fraying. Inspect crimp fasteners for correct torque rating.

Task.Action: Measure each line to earth and each line to neutral.
Task.Notes: Record readings and check that measured values are within electricity supplier`s specification.

Task.Action: Inspect for signs of overheating or burn marks.
Carry out within 1.5kV-3.0kV range to detect potential deterioration of the system.
Task.Notes: CAUTION - Care should be taken to isolate sensitive equipment.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Control Panels - Lamps, Meters, Alarms etc

Introduction.Content: Before commencing any maintenance work on control panels, read Control Panels andCcontrollers SFG 14 Introductory Procedures, very carefully and follow all the safety procedures.

Task.Action: Check and energise to ensure that the indicator is operational. Replace any blown or discoloured bulbs as required.
Task.Notes: Replacement bulbs should be of the correct type and voltage, the power rating must be as per the manufacturer's specification.

Task.Action: Inspect for signs of overheating or electrical burn marks.
Examine for signs of overheating or insulation breakdown.

Task.Item: Low Voltage Power Packs - ac or dc types.

Task.Action: Inspect for signs of overheating.
Carry out and compare with manufacturer's tolerance and operational specifications.
Carry out, record and ensure that the load taken from the unit is within the manufacturer's specification.
Check for correct operation.
Inspect and check for correct mechanical and electrical operation.
Task.Notes: Check actual reading, record and compare with a reference voltmeter applied across the same circuit.

Task.Action: Check for free and correct movement.
Check and adjust if necessary.
Inspect and check for correct mechanical and electrical operation.
Check for free and correct movement.
Check and adjust if necessary.
Inspect and check operation of each input channel.
Check operation and indications including alarm circuits if fitted.
Inspect; check operation by adjusting or operating alarm test facility (if fitted).
Reduce setting and note operation of  'smoke condition'.
Carry out manufacturer's 'testing and maintenance' procedures as required at stipulated frequencies.
The interior of the control panel should be cleaned.
Inspect and check that all grilles are free of any obstructions, clean as required.
inspect and check operation of fan unit; clean and replace filter unit as required.
Task.Notes: All power and control circuits should be checked for functional operation against the wiring diagrams relevant to the installation.

Introduction.Content:
This schedule applies to all types of controllers and requires that all safety precautions and safe working practices be observed.

1. Note all set points found.

2. Check mechanically for security of fixings, incoming cables, pneumatic pipework and terminal connections for tightness.

3. Visually check controller for signs of damage (i.e. ingress of dust or moisture).

Before commencing any maintenance work on control panels, read Control Panels and Controllers SFG 14 Introductory Procedures, very carefully and follow all the safety procedures.

Task.Action: Check outside sensor for calibration and display accuracy.
Task.Notes: This should be on a northerly wall away from any direct or reflected heat gains. Where this is not possible, the sensor should be mechanically shaded to give the best result.

Task.Action: Check inside sensor for calibration and display accuracy.
Task.Notes: This should be placed in the coldest chosen representative location, ensure that it is free from any heat gains or air movement restrictions. The design of the system may incorporate more than one inside sensor where an average temperature is used for the optimiser.

Task.Action: Check programme setting is correct.
Check operation by simulation.
Task.Notes: Refer to manufacturer's simulation procedures.  Any ongoing problems can be highlighted by the use of a thermograph.

Task.Action: Check condition and change as required.
Task.Notes: Note the life expectancy (use by date) and change at manufacturer's recommendation.  All batteries should be disposed of only in accordance with H&S and Environmental regulations.

Task.Action: Check that output devices respond to command signals.
Agree any changes with system operator that may enhance energy savings.

4. Check all power supply tolerances as per manufacturer's recommendation and adjust as necessary.

Check.

Task.Action: Check that settings are correct.
Check output signal and output device operation.
Check and calibrate for correct relationship between outside and flow temperatures.
Check system under control for proper operation.

Task.Action: Inspect and check both mechanical and electrical operation.
Inspect and check each cam setting/switch assembly.
Task.Notes: Adjust if necessary to suit the particular application.

Task.Action: Inspect and check.
Check operation in both directions.
Task.Notes: Where actuators are involved see relevant section Actuators (SFG 01-01).

Task.Action: Inspect and check.
Check any interlocks which disable outputs.
Inspect and check each step throughout its signal range.
Check operation of each step and the differential.

Task.Item: Monthly dial settings e.g. for solar time switches

Task.Notes: Replace battery as per manufacturer's recommendations. Batteries should be disposed of in accordance with H&S Environmental regulations.

Introduction.Content:
Electronic Inverter Type

WARNING:- Due to the very high voltages present within this type of controller it is essential that all safety precautions are strictly followed.  The equipment must only be serviced by competent and qualified personnel.  The manufacturer's testing and maintenance procedures including all safety precautions must be strictly followed.

Before commencing any maintenance work on control panels, read Control Panels and Controllers (SFG 14) Introductory Procedures, very carefully and follow all the safety procedures.

Pre-Maintenance Procedures

This schedule applies to all types of controllers and requires that all safety precautions and safe working practices be observed.

1. Note all set points found.

2. Check mechanically for security of fixings, incoming cables, pneumatic pipework and terminal connections for tightness.

3. Visually check controller for signs of damage (i.e. ingress of dust or moisture).

4. Check all power supply tolerances as per manufacturer's recommendation and adjust as necessary.

Task.Action: Check for signs of overheating.
Task.Notes: Report any signs of over heating to the client with proposed remedial works.

Task.Action: Adjust and note speed variation of the drive in the particular application.
Inspect for signs of overheating and insulation breakdown.
Operate and observe variation in the speed of the drive in the particular application.
Check that they are clear.
Carry out manufacturer's maintenance procedures.
Task.Notes: Frequency may vary according to manufacturer's recommendations.

Task.Action: Inspect for signs of overheating and insulation breakdown.
Adjust variable setting of transformer and observe variation in the speed of the drive in the particular application.
Check that they are clear.
Carry out manufacturer's maintenance procedures.
Task.Notes: Frequency may vary according to manufacturer's recommendations.

Task.Action: Inspect and check for signs of overheating and insulation breakdown.
Task.Notes: Frequency may vary according to manufacturer's recommendations.

Task.Action: Adjust and observe speed change in the drive under the particular application.
Task.Notes: Frequency may vary according to manufacturer's recommendations.

Task.Action: Check for both minimum and maximum settings.  Adjust as required.
Task.Notes: Frequency may vary according to manufacturer's recommendations.

Task.Action: Carry out maintenance procedures strictly in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.
Task.Notes: Frequency may vary according to manufacturer's recommendations.

Task.Action: Inspect and check for any signs of overheating and breakdown of electronic components.
Adjust in either manual or automatic mode and observe speed change of the drive in this particular application.
Check for minimum and maximum speeds, adjust if necessary.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Transducers - Pneumatic to Electronic and Electronic to Pneumatic

Introduction.Content: Before commencing any maintenance work on control panels, read Control Panels and Controllers SFG 14 Introductory Procedures, very carefully and follow all the safety procedures.

Task.Action: Check.
Check output signal and output device operation.
Check and calibrate for correct relationship between input and output signal.

Introduction.Content: Special requirements are necessary in the food and process industries, clean room applications and kitchens.

Task.Action: Inspect for any loose panels and secure.
Check for condition, leaks and secure fittings.
Inspect for any damage or deterioration.
Task.Notes: Report to client if remedial work required.

Task.Action: Inspect for permanent set (in springs).
Task.Notes: If renewal required, report to client. If replaced ensure that the correct type is used.

Task.Action: Check internal condition through sampling points (test points) where fitted.
Task.Notes: Report to client if remedial work required.

Task.Action: Check all ductwork supports and handers to ensure they are secure and not loose.
Task.Notes: Report to client if remedial work required.

Task.Action: Inspect duct run where it runs across or parallel to a personnel access route. Highlight any low points with the appropriate hazard tape or paint.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Ducting - Volume Control Dampers and Fire/ Smoke Dampers

Introduction.Content:
Caution

All volume dampers are set up during commissioning and should not normally be subject to further adjustment unless modifications are made to the ductwork distribution system. If it is essential to move the damper for maintenance purposes extreme care should be taken to ensure that the damper is returned to the position as set when commissioned. In the event of a ductwork modification, the system should then be re-commissioned. Refer to B&ES (the Building & Engineering Services Association, formerly the HVCA) TR/19 Section 3 for access requirements and Section 4 para 4.19 & 4.20 for specific considerations.

Refer to B&ES publication DW145 for Fire Damper detail.

Typically a log of all dampers should be kept to record the results of the inspection, any recommendations and any remedial work carried out.

Task.Action: 1. Visual check on condition. 2. Check position and ease of movement and security of locking devises.
Task.Notes: The dampers should have the `as found` setting marked indelibly to aid re-setting. Ensure that damper opens and closes to desired positions.

Task.Action: 1. Visual check on condition. If damper is shut confirm that this is a requirement of normal operation. (it is possible that the fire damper may have shut during a fire alarm activation and has not been reset) 2. Check action and proper operation. Inspect all dampers, apply a few drops of oil to the mechanism. Replace fusible links if required.
Task.Notes: These may be subject to the requirements of the local fire brigade. Maintain a log of all dampers tested, record faults and any remedial action taken. This will provide proof to the local fire brigade that regular checks are maintained. If any fire dampers are inaccessible advise client. The dampers can accumulate dirt which can affect their operation and may require access panels added to one or both sides to allow full cleaning and surface restoration.

Task.Action: 1. Visual check on condition. 2. Check for wear and lubricate if appropriate.
Task.Notes: Ensure that blades on shaft are secure and are correctly aligned.

Task.Action: Check condition and operation.
Check for damage to flexible conduits. Tighten all terminal connections. Isolate control panel and inspect for signs of overheating. Check integrity of electrical insulation.
Task.Notes: For detailed maintenance information see Control panels and controllers SFG14-01.

Legislation.Content: BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.

Task.Action: Inspect internally where access for inspection is provided. Repair surfaces of sound insulation where necessary.
Task.Notes: The facings should be inspected to ensure that any loose fibre does not enter the system. Report on further action needed.

Task.Action: Check and ensure that all fixings are secure.
Clean, descale and repaint as required.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Ductwork Cleaning - Hygiene, Inspections and Monitoring

Introduction.Content:
A variety of specifically hazardous contaminants may be found in the ventilation systems, especially in industrial or laboratory Local Exhaust Ventilation systems (LEV) whose performance falls under COSHH regulations.

Reference Health and Safety at Work Regulations.

Task.Action: Ascertain age and date of last inspection.
Check internal condition by a Deposit Thickness test or Vacuum Test.
Task.Notes:
Frequency to be determined by risk assessment and testing regime as per B&ES (the Building & Engineering Services Association) 'Cleanliness of Ventilation Systems' ref. TR/19 and BS EN 15780 both of which itemise the testing methods to be adopted.

If inspection indicates a full cleaning regime is required, inform client.

If inspection reveals a build up of moisture, identify the potential source of moisture, inform client and seek additional guidance from a qualified Environmental Specialist.

Task.Action: Clean in accordance with TR/19.
Task.Notes:
This is the minimum cleaning interval:
 
  • heavy use, i.e. 12-16 hours per day will necessitate a 3 monthly clean
  • light use i.e. 2-6 hours per day will necessitate a 12 monthly clean.
The exact timing will depend on a range of factors.

A new system needs to be monitored to establish the suitable minimum period.

Task.Action: Record inlet and outlet temperature on water side. Pressure drop across evaporator, refrigerant pressures or superheat temperatures and evaporator temperature.
Task.Notes: Any marked difference to the design figures could indicate internal fouling of the condenser and may require additional work.

Task.Action: Check for chilled water flow in the system and correct operation.
Check and record pressure drop across pump. Check for leakage, bearing noise and unusual bearing temperature. Lubricate according to manufacturer's instructions. Check motor current.
Check external condition, leak tightness of glands and seats, operational spindles and solenoid.
Task.Notes: Some chillers have the ability to automatically pump down refrigerant to the evaporators in the event of a refrigerant leak or other fault. For further guidance see the manufacturer's instructions.

Task.Action: Check external and internal condition including baffles and covers.
Task.Notes: Liquid level for water cooling, brine or glycol systems should be noted and any leaks investigated and repaired.

Task.Action: Check external condition, leak tightness of glands and seats. Ensure valve caps are tight and secure. Check operation.
Check external condition and leak tightness.
Check for security and tighten as necessary.
Check for damage.
Check regime including cables and thermostats. Where fitted check that the defrost system is operating satisfactorily.
Where fitted replace the filter dryer(s) as required.
Task.Notes: Check in line sight glass for indication of moisture in system.

Task.Action: Check condition and clean fins.
Check and ensure drain clear. Flush and sterilise if necessary.
Check operation.
Task.Notes: Often this equipment may be contaminated, clean and flush, sterilise if necessary.

Task.Action: Check condition and operation.
Check for correct operation and clean fan blades as required.

Personnel carrying out leak checking, gas recovery or other refrigerant handling activities such as plant installation and maintenance must have a suitable refrigerant handling qualification.

These works are covered under the current F-Gas Regulations on fluorinated gases.

ALWAYS UPDATE RECORDS
Task.Notes:
Check for leaks should be part of the routine servicing by Refrigeration Engineers.
 
Where a system has a refrigerant charge greater than 300kg, an automatic leak detection system must be installed on the system to comply with the F-Gas Regulations.

Task.Action: Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.

Legislation.Content: Pressure Equipment Regulations 1999 and 2002 amendment
F-Gas Regulation No. 517/2014 on fluorinated gases
Pressure Systems Safety Regulations 2000

Introduction.Content:
Ensure to read health and safety notes shown on SFG 20-01 before undertaking the following tasks.

The instructions in the table below refer to all air handling fans including exhaust, make up, recirculation and small air handlers. Before working on any moving machinery switch off and ensure that the equipment is isolated electrically in accordance with Health and Safety at Work (www.hse.gov.uk) Regulations.

The isolator should ideally be locked in the off position when maintenance takes place.

Task.Action: 'Sealed for life' bearings should not be serviced.  Inspect and lubricate as necessary.  Where applicable, all set-screws in bearings should be checked and tightened.
Task.Notes:
Check bearings for end play and wear.  Report any faults to the client.  If lubricators are provided, re-lubrication should not exceed a period of two years.  When carrying out re-lubrication it is essential that every trace of water and dirt is removed from around the grease nipple.  If the operating temperature is over 60 C a shorter re-lubricating period will be necessary.  Ensure that the correct oils and/or greases and quantities are used.

 

It is particularly important that lubricants of the correct working range are used.  Oil attracts dust and as a consequence any excess should be wiped clear (e.g. fan blades) see manufacturer's instructions.

Task.Action: Clean and inspect for looseness and corrosion.
Task.Notes: Re-paint with a suitable corrosion resistant paint as required.

Task.Action: Inspect, check condition and alignment of drive and shaft.  Adjust or replace if condition warrants it.  Check all guards are secure and in place.
Task.Notes: When a new belt (or a new fan) has been installed, the belt should be re-tensioned after two weeks in order to take up any slackness resulting from stretching.  Guards should be painted a suitable colour, so that they stand out.

Task.Action: Check and clean.  Inspect for tightness.
Check tightness.
Check and tighten as necessary.
Check effectiveness.
Task.Notes: The rubber/neoprene can degrade with age and use.  Report any faults to the client.

Task.Action: Check operation and adjust as necessary.

Task.Item: 9. Automatic change over control (where standby fan installed).
Task.Action: Check operation of control switch.

Clean and inspect all grilles.

Clean all dirt from the outside of any motor.

Clean fan blades.

Check for excessive imbalance.
Task.Notes:
If dirt builds up on a motor it can act as insulation which causes the motor to operate at elevated temperatures.  This can result in a shortened motor life and motors commonly burn-out.  

An excessive build up of dust or damage to the fan blade can add imbalance causing excessive vibration.  This can lead to fatigue and dangerous failure.  Dirt should be removed by cleaning with suitable equipment.

Fan blades and louvres can be cleaned with a brush and detergent.

The fan motor casing must be totally enclosed to prevent water from damaging motor windings.  If the motor is not totally enclosed, then it must be removed and cleaned separately before the housing is cleaned.  If using a brush or high-pressure washer, care must be taken not to damage the impeller blades.

Task.Action:
Check the electrical and thermal overload protection for the motor, and if the motor has a resettable overload protection.  

Check that it is fully operational.

Check circuit breakers manually each month.

Examine wiring and other electrical system components for signs of deterioration, loose connections and damage.

Check all connections are tight.
Clean any sensors and re-calibrate if found to be inaccurate.

Introduction.Content:
Ensure to read health and safety notes shown on SFG 20-01 before undertaking the following tasks.

The instructions in the table below refer to all air handling fans including exhaust, make up, recirculation and small air handlers. Before working on any moving machinery switch off and ensure that the equipment is isolated electrically in accordance with Health and Safety at Work (www.hse.gov.uk) Regulations.

The isolator should be locked in the off position when maintenance takes place.

Task.Action: Clean and ensure no build up of dirt.
Task.Notes:
In very dusty environments or where contaminants are present, more frequent cleaning may be necessary.  If possible avoid scraping but if necessary carry out lightly.  

With plastic impellers soapy water is the most effective cleaner.

Task.Action: Inspect and check for any loose connections, fixings or cables.

'Sealed for life' bearings should not be serviced.  Inspect and lubricate as necessary.

Where applicable, all set-screws in bearings should be checked and tightened.
Task.Notes:
Check bearings for end play and wear.  Report any faults to the client. 

When carrying out lubrication it is essential that every trace of water or dirt is removed from around the grease nipple.  (See also Motors SFG 39-01).  

Ensure that the correct oils and/or greases and quantities are used.

It is particularly important that lubricants of the correct working range are used.  Oil attracts dust and as a consequence any excess should be wiped clear (e.g. fan blades) see manufacturer's instructions.

Task.Action: Lubricate/grease as necessary.
Task.Notes:
For continuous running, more frequent servicing may be required.  

Do not overpack with grease .

Task.Action:
Check tension and adjust if necessary.

Replace if condition warrants it.

Check all guards are secure and in place.
Task.Notes: Ensure motor, drive and pulley are correctly aligned otherwise excessive wear will occur on the sides of the belt.  Guards should be painted a suitable colour, so that they stand out.

Task.Item: 6. 'Triggering' device, i.e. humidistat or vane type flow switch.
Task.Action: Check for satisfactory functioning.
Task.Notes: Vane type flow switch can be activated by restricting airflow through the motor side inlet of the unit.

Task.Action:
Clean and inspect all grilles.

Clean all dirt from the outside of any motor.

Clean fan blades.

Check for excessive imbalance.

Check the electrical and thermal overload protection for the motor, and if the motor has a resettable overload protection.  

Check that it is fully operational.

Check circuit breakers manually each month.  

Examine wiring and other electrical system components for signs of deterioration, loose connections and damage.

Check all connections are tight.
Clean any sensors and re-calibrate if found to be inaccurate.

Task.Action: Check that there is no excessive movement at the wing root.
Task.Notes: There should be no loss of grease from wing roots.  If there is, dismantle impeller and seals and replace after lubricating bearings.

Task.Action: Check correct operation.
Task.Notes: The impeller should operate with smooth movement over the full pitch angle range with the fan running.  If faulty, report to client for further action.

Task.Action: Check operation.

Clean and inspect all grilles.

The instructions in the table below refer to all air handling fans including exhaust, make up, recirculation and small air handlers. Before working on any moving machinery switch off and ensure that the equipment is isolated electrically in accordance withHealth and Safety at Work (www.hse.gov.uk) Regulations.

The isolator should be locked in the off position when maintenance takes place.

Task.Action: Clean and inspect.
Task.Notes:
Take care not to disturb impeller balance weights.

Cleaning is best carried out with warm soapy water using soft brush.  Other cleaners may be used provided they are not harmful to the paint or galvanised finish.

Task.Action:

Task.Action:
Check tension and examine for wear.

Replace if necessary.
Clean and check shutter blades for ease of action.
Task.Notes:
In dirty or moist laden environments, more frequent inspection and cleaning may be necessary.

Task.Action:

Check integrity of electrical insulation.

Task.Item: 6. Roof cowl intake/wall entry louvre (where applicable).

Task.Notes: Where maintenance requires working at height, ensure all necessary precautions are taken to prevent falls from a height.  Working at Height Regulations apply.

Introduction.Content:
This type of fan, axial with the motor outside of the airstream, is normally used for fume extracts e.g. kitchens, fire and smoke extraction and for fume removal, particularly where corrosive.

Ensure to read health and safety notes shown on SFG 20-01 before undertaking the following tasks.

The instructions in the table below refer to all air handling fans including exhaust, make up, recirculation and small air handlers. Before working on any moving machinery switch off and ensure that the equipment is isolated electrically in accordance withHealth and Safety at Work (www.hse.gov.uk) Regulations.

The isolator should be locked in the off position when maintenance takes place.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Check condition and clean.
Task.Notes:
If handling abrasive or corrosive materials, examine the blades for wear or damage.  

 

In kitchen operations, e.g. fat and oil frying, regular cleaning will be required.

Task.Action:
'Sealed for life' bearings should not be serviced.

Inspect and lubricate as necessary.

Where applicable, all set-screws in bearings should be checked and tightened.
Task.Notes:
Check bearings for end play and wear.  Report any faults to the client.  If lubricators are provided, re-lubrication should not exceed a period of two years.

When carrying out re-lubrication, it is essential that every trace of water and dirt is removed from around the grease nipple.

If the operating temperature is over 60 C a shorter re-lubricating period will be necessary, see manufacturer's instructions. 

Ensure that the correct oils and/or greases and quantities are used.  

It is particularly important that lubricants of the correct working range are used.  Oil attracts dust and as a consequence any excess should be wiped clear (e.g. fan blades) see manufacturer's instructions.

Task.Action: Check and rotate a few turns by hand or electrically.
Task.Notes: Units designed for emergency use should be test operated for no longer than twenty minutes.  (See Motors SFG 39-01).

Task.Action:
Check for soundness and ensure terminal connections are secure.

Check integrity of electrical insulation.

Check wear, alignment and tension.

Check all guards are secure and in place.
Task.Notes:
Replace if cording becomes visible.

Guards should be painted a suitable colour, so that they stand out.

Task.Item: 7. Automatic shutters (usually fitted on roof units).
Task.Action: Clean and check operation.
Task.Notes:
In moist or dirty environments, more frequent servicing may be required.

Where maintenance requires working at height, ensure all necessary precautions are taken to prevent falls from a height.  Working at Height Regulations apply.

Task.Action: Check condition.

Task.Item: 9. Ductwork including fixings and insulation (where fitted).
Task.Action: Inspect external condition and report.
Task.Notes: With kitchen extracts, heavy deposits of grease may be encountered and more frequent inspection will be necessary.  The client should be informed of fire risk and a schedule of cleaning drawn up.  (See Ductwork Cleaning Hygiene SFG 17-01).

Task.Action:
Check full load current and log.

Check the electrical and thermal overload protection for the motor, and if the motor has a resettable overload protection.

Check for wear.

Introduction.Content:
In normal use air filters do not present a health and safety hazard. However used air filters do contain quantities of dust which, unless precautions are taken, may expose maintenance personnel to a `nuisance dust` hazard, as defined by the `Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH (www.hse.gov.uk/hthdir/noframes/coshh/index.htm)) Regulations`. A risk assessment must be carried out before the work starts and a method statement produced.
Used filters should be sealed into plastic bags for disposal. Controlled Waste Regulations apply

Task.Action: Check for correct operation.
Task.Notes: This should be a daily task for the operator.

Task.Action: Check for operation and follow manufacturer`s instructions.
Task.Notes: Rectifiers fail either through filament burn out or loss of vacuum when the current will flow in both directions leading to shorting.

Task.Action: Isolate electrically in accordance with HSAWA (www.hse.gov.uk) recommendations.
Check condition and if broken replace immediately
Task.Notes: Broken wires can cause a short circuit.

Task.Action: Wash according to manufacturer`s instructions.
Task.Notes: Frequency of cleaning will depend upon the dirt picked up, every four to six weeks is suggested. If the cells are not cleaned regularly dust will eventually build up to a thickness where some is dislodged and blown over.

Introduction.Content:
This section should be read in conjunction with the Daily and Weekly testing tasks.

A record of all tests and checks, and any defects remedied, should be maintained in the fire safety manual / log book.

Arrangements should be made for all fire safety equipment, installations and systems (including fire detection systems, automatic suppression systems, door control mechanisms, smoke control systems, evacuation and fire-fighting lifts, emergency lighting, standby power systems, escalators, and all passive fire protection provisions) to be inspected and tested on a regular basis by a competent person. Alterations, additions, repairs or modifications to services and equipment should be carried out only by competent persons.

Although modern fire alarm systems may incorporate a high degree of monitoring, so that faults are indicated automatically, it is still necessary for the responsible person nominated by the user to ensure that fault indications at the panel are identified for appropriate action. It is also vital for a regular test to be carried out to ensure that there has not been any major failure of the entire system, or a significant part of the system.


Routine testing of the system also provides an opportunity for occupants of the building to become, and remain, familiar with the fire alarm signal(s) that the system produces. In systems with staged alarms that incorporate an “Alert” and an “Evacuate” signal, both signals need to be operated on the occasion of each test to ensure that occupants are aware of the existence of both signals and their different meaning.

The period between successive inspection and servicing visits should be based upon a risk assessment, taking into account the type of system installed, the environment in which it operates and other factors that may affect the long term operation of the system. If a risk assessment shows a need for more frequent inspection and servicing visits, then all interested parties should agree the appropriate inspection and servicing schedule. If this recommendation is not implemented, it should be considered that the system is no longer compliant with this part of BS 5839.

All tests on equipment and trigger devices should be recorded in the log book. Due to the variety and complexity of fire alarms and associated systems they are not dealt with in detail in this specification but the table below indicates the minimum requirements. Specialist back up may be required either from the manufacturers or specialist service providers especially in connection with intelligent systems.

For further information see BS 5839 part 1 for fire detection and fire alarm systems, BS EN 54-2 and BS EN 54-4.

Task.Action: The system log book should be examined. It should be ensured that any faults recorded have received appropriate attention.

A visual inspection should be made to check whether structural or occupancy changes have affected the compliance of the system with the recommendations of this standard for the siting of manual call points, automatic fire detectors and fire alarm devices.
Task.Notes:
Particular care should be taken to verify whether:

1) all manual call points remain unobstructed and conspicuous;

2) any new exits have been created without the provision of an adjacent manual call point;

3) any new or relocated partitions have been erected within 500 mm horizontally of any automatic fire detector;

4) any storage encroaches within 300 mm of ceilings;

5) a clear space of 500 mm is maintained below each automatic fire detector and that the ability of the detector to receive the stimulus that it has been designed to detect has not been impeded by other means;

6) any changes to the use or occupancy of an area makes the existing types of automatic fire detector unsuitable for detection of fire or prone to unwanted alarms;

7) any building alterations or extensions require additional fire detection and alarm equipment to be installed. 

The building occupier should inform the maintenance engineer of any structural or occupancy changes which might affect the siting or operation of the detector.

Task.Action: The records of false alarms should be checked in accordance with section 30.2i) of BS5839 part 1. The rate of false alarms during the previous 12 months should be recorded. Action taken in respect of false alarms recorded should comply with the recommendations of 30.2j) of BS5839 part 1
The standby battery should be disconnected and full load alarm should be simulated

Batteries and their connections should be examined and momentarily load tested with the mains disconnected (other than those within devices such as manual call points, detectors and fire alarm sounders of a radio-linked system), to ensure that they are in good serviceable condition and not likely to fail before the next service visit.

Task.Item: 6. Fire Alarm Control and Indicating Equipment
Task.Action: The fire alarm functions of the control and indicating equipment should be checked by the operation of at least one detector or manual call point on each circuit.
Task.Notes: An entry should be made in the log book indicating which initiating devices have been used for these tests.

Task.Action: The operation of the fire alarm devices should be checked.
All controls, visual indicators at control and indicating equipment should be checked for correct operation.
The operation of any facility for automatic transmission of alarm signals to an alarm receiving centre should be checked.
Task.Notes: Where more than one form of alarm signal can be transmitted (e.g. fire and fault signals), the correct transmission of each signal should be confirmed.

Task.Action: All ancillary functions of the control and indicating equipment should be tested.
All fault indicators and their circuits should be checked, where practicable, by simulation of fault conditions.
All printers should be tested to ensure that they operate correctly and that characters are legible.
Task.Notes: It should be ensured that all printer consumables are sufficient in quantity or condition to ensure that the printer can be expected to operate until the time of the next service visit.

Task.Action: Radio systems of all types should be serviced in accordance with the recommendations of the manufacturer.
All further checks and tests recommended by the manufacturer of the control and indicating equipment and other components of the system should be carried out.
On completion of the work, any outstanding defects should be reported to the responsible person, the system log book should be completed and a servicing certificate should be issued.
The work described may be carried out over the course of two or more service visits during each twelve month period

The switch mechanism of every manual call point should be tested, either by removal of a frangible element, insertion of a test key or operation of the device as it would be operated in the event of fire.

All automatic fire detectors should be examined, as far as practicable, to ensure that they have not been damaged, painted, or otherwise adversely affected. Thereafter, every detector should be functionally tested. The tests used need prove only that the detectors are connected to the system, are operational and are capable of responding to the phenomena they are designed to detect.
Task.Notes:
General :

Connections check condition and make good if necessary.

Mounting Check security

Task.Action: Every heat detector should be functionally tested by means of a suitable heat source, unless operation of the detector in this manner would then necessitate replacement of part or all of the sensing element (e.g. as in fusible link point detectors or non-integrating line detectors).  Special test arrangements will be required for fusible link heat detectors. The heat source should not have the potential to ignite a fire; live flame should not be used, and special equipment might be necessary in explosive atmospheres

Point smoke detectors should be functionally tested by a method that confirms that smoke can enter the detector chamber and produce a fire alarm signal (e.g. by use of apparatus that generates simulated smoke or suitable aerosols around the detector).  It should be ensured that the material used does not cause damage to, or affect the subsequent performance of, the detector; the manufacturers guidance on suitable materials should be followed.
Optical beam smoke detectors should be functionally tested by introducing signal attenuation between the transmitter and receiver, either by use of an optical filter, smoke or simulated smoke

Task.Item: 21. Aspirating Fire Detection Systems, VESDA System
Task.Action:
Aspirating fire detection systems should be functionally tested as described in 45.4d of BS5839 part 1, with each sampling point, or group of sampling points, in the pipework of the system treated as a point detector.

45.4d "Point smoke detectors should be functionally tested by a method that confirms that smoke can enter the detector chamber and produce a fire alarm signal (e.g. by use of apparatus that generates simulated smoke or suitable aerosols around the detector)".

It should be ensured that the material used does not cause damage to, or affect the subsequent performance of, the detector; the manufacturers guidance on suitable materials should be followed.
Task.Notes: Not all test products may be appropriate for the purpose.

Task.Action: Carbon monoxide fire detectors should be functionally tested by a method that confirms that carbon monoxide can enter the detector chamber and produce a fire alarm signal (e.g. by use of apparatus that generates carbon monoxide or a gas that has a similar effect on the electro-chemical cell as carbon monoxide.
Task.Notes: It should be ensured that any test gas used does not cause damage to, or affect the subsequent performance of, the detector; the manufacturers guidance on suitable test gases should be followed.

Task.Action: Flame detectors should be functionally tested by a method that confirms that the detector will respond to a suitable frequency of radiation and produce a fire alarm signal. The guidance of the manufacturer on testing of detectors should be followed.

In fire detection systems that enable analogue values to be determined at the control and indicating equipment, it should be confirmed that each analogue value is within the range specified by the manufacturer.

Multi-sensor detectors should be operated by a method that confirms that products of combustion in the vicinity of the detector can reach the sensors and that a fire signal can be produced as appropriate
Task.Notes: The guidance of the manufacturer on the manner in which the detector can be functionally tested effectively should be followed

Task.Action: All fire alarm devices should be checked for correct operation. It should be confirmed that visual fire alarm devices are not obstructed from view and that their lenses are clean.
All unmonitored, permanently illuminated filament lamp indicators at control and indicating equipment should be replaced.
Radio signal strengths in radio-linked systems should be checked for adequacy.
A visual inspection should be made to confirm that all readily accessible cable fixings are secure and undamaged.
The cause and effect programme should be confirmed as being correct.
The standby power supply capacity should be checked to establish it remains suitable for continued service.

Operation - Check and ensure action responds to appropriate signals.

Indicator lights - Check operation and replace any faulty lamps.

Condition Check for mechanical damage.

Operation - Check operation and control mechanisms.

Condition Check for mechanical damage.

Operation - Check operation and control mechanisms.

Task.Item: 35. Smoke Relief Vents - Fireman's control for vent plant
Task.Action: Check operation and log operation of fans and dampers.

Condition Check for mechanical damage.

Operation - Check operation and control mechanisms
Test Operation
Task.Notes: These devices should be tested frequently by the clients operators

Task.Action:
Condition Check for mechanical damage.

Operation - Check operation and control mechanisms.
Task.Notes: Interlocks will be with heating, ventilating and cooling equipment and with fire extinguishing and other systems , i.e. Smoke curtains SFG 52-04

Introduction.Content:
TESTING

The client should carry out tests on equipment on a weekly basis in accordance with the local fire regulations. When carrying out maintenance any defects must be reported to the client.

Task.Action:
Check mounting of casing and replace if cracked.

Check operation.
Check (see notes).
Task.Notes: The time period for checking sounders should be agreed with the client.  Refer to BS 5839.

Task.Action: Check exterior and clean.
Task.Notes:
Check and monitor according to manufacturer's instructions.
See Sensors and Switching Devices (SFG 50).

Task.Action: Check condition and make good if necessary.
Check condition and clean.
Task.Notes: Frequency will depend upon environmental conditions and should be agreed with the client.

Task.Action: Check security.
Check condition and life.

Legislation.Content: Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document B 2007 edition Fire Safety
BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.
BS 5839 Part 1 Fire detection and fire alarm systems for buildings. Code of practice for the system design, installation, commissioning and maintenance of systems in non-domestic premises: 2013
