Fire Precaution (Work Force) Regulation 1997 and 1999 amendment
BS 5839-6:2013 Fire detection and fire alarm systems for buildings. Code of practice for the design, installation and maintenance of fire detection and fire alarm systems in domestic premises
BS 9991:2011 Fire safety in the design, management and use of residential buildings
DD CEN/TS 54-14:2004 Fire detection and fire alarm systems. Guidelines for planning, design, installation, commissioning, use and maintenance

Introduction.Content: Where, due to unforeseen difficulties, it is necessary to leave an installation not available for use, the fire and rescue service should be informed immediately in order that alternative arrangements can be made to cover this deficiency should the need arise. In addition a suitable notice to indicate that the installation is not available for use should be placed in a prominent position.

Task.Action: Ensure pump base is level and pipework not strained.
Task.Notes: Check that anti-vibration mountings are satisfactory and vibration is not being transferred to the pipework.

Task.Action: Clean.
Check and adjust if necessary, ensure pump shafts are free to rotate.
Oil or grease where external nipples or lubricators are fitted.
Task.Notes: Use recommended grade of lubricant. Motor should be overhauled annually, see Motors SFG 39.

Task.Action: Clean and ensure that all blockages are cleared.
Check for security and safety.
Open the highest hose reel nozzles on each rising main to ensure that set starts automatically. Check hand override controls. Rectify any faults.
Task.Notes: Report any defects to client and fire brigade. This test should be carried out at least once per month by the operator or caretaker.

Task.Action: Check to ensure that all pumps reach their design closed valve pressure and all pump isolating valves are left in the open position.
Inspect and check gas cushion pressure.

Task.Item: 10. Test run pressure booster sets, pressurising units, and filling pump.
Task.Action: Carry out adjustments to ensure satisfactory operation.
Task.Notes: Check operation of all automatic controls and change-over switches, including signal to 'Building Management Systems' (BMS) - SFG 06.  If operating any booster set pumps in the Hand Position, there is a danger that if there is NO FLOW in the pipe work, damage to the mechanical seals and/or impellers of the pumps could occur.  The Hand Position should only be used for testing the pumps or in an emergency situation.

Task.Action: Simulate duty pump failure.
Task.Notes: Reset after test, ensure that alarm is transmitted to authorised recipient.

Legislation.Content: BS EN 671 part 3: 2009 Hose Reels
BS 5306-1:2006 Code of Practice-fire extinguishing installations, Hose Reel, Foam inlets
Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005
BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.

Introduction.Content:
Where, due to unforeseen difficulties, it is necessary to leave an installation not available for use, the fire and rescue service should be informed immediately in order that alternative arrangements can be made to cover this deficiency should the need arise. In addition a suitable notice to indicate that the installation is not available for use should be placed in a prominent position.

Maintenance should be carried out in accordance with BS EN 671-3:2009.

Leave the hose reel and hose system ready for immediate use; if any extensive maintenance is necessary the hose reel or hose system shall be labelled "OUT OF ORDER" and the competent person shall inform the user/owner.

Task.Action: Completely run out reel, inspect and subject to operational water pressure test. Check that it is unobstructed, that there is no damage, components are not corroded and that there are no leaks.
Task.Notes: The full length of hose must be inspected for signs of cracking, distortion, wear or damage; if the hose shows any signs of defect it must be replaced or proof-tested to maximum working pressure.

Task.Action: Check that the brackets for wall mounting are secure.
If fitted with a cabinet, check that the doors open freely and that there is no sign of damage.
Check the condition of the water supply pipework and any couplings.   Pay particular attention to any flexible pipework for corrosion, damage or wear.
Check they are of the correct type, functioning and easy to operate.
Check they are securely fastened.
Check hose drum rotates freely in both directions.
Task.Notes: If it is not possible to test every reel, at least the highest reel on each rising main should be tested.

Task.Action: Check gauges (if fitted) are working within their operating range and working satisfactorily.
Task.Notes: Hose reels and any associated equipment should be accessible at all times.

Task.Action: Check that the movement is free and that the reel swings minimum required angles shown in BS EN 671 parts 1 & 2.  Check condition of O rings.
Check the manual stop valve is of correct type and that it operates easily and correctly.
Check the correct operation of the automatic valve and check for the correct operation of the isolating service valve.
Check operation.
Check that the location is clearly marked and that the operating instructions are clear.
Check that the flow of water is steady and sufficient.
All hoses shall be pressurised to maximum working pressure in accordance with BS EN 671 parts 1 & 2.

Legislation.Content: Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005
BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.
BS EN 671 part 3: 2009 Hose Reels
BS 5306-1:2006 Code of Practice-fire extinguishing installations, Hose Reel, Foam inlets

Introduction.Content: Where, due to unforeseen difficulties, it is necessary to leave an installation not available for use, the fire and rescue service should be informed immediately in order that alternative arrangements can be made to cover this deficiency should the need arise.  In addition a suitable notice to indicate that the installation is not available for use should be placed in a prominent position.

Task.Action:
Check:

a) inlets

b) landing valves

c) drain valves

d) door hinges

e) locking arrangements.

Report any defects.
Task.Notes: Special attention should be given to all valves, spindles, glands and washers, to ensure that they are in satisfactory condition so that all equipment is ready for immediate use. When defective valve assemblies are removed, they should be immediately replaced either with the replacement valve, or plugged or blanked off so that the system remains operative.

Task.Action:
a) Check earthing arrangement and ensure continuity between joints

b) Carry out physical check of the system

c) Static pressure test flush riser by turning on water and allow to flow out of topmost outlet

d) Charge system to 10 bar measured at the inlet for 15 minutes minimum. Check system during this period for leaks etc.

e) Flow test after static pressure test a flow test should be carried out if considered necessary

f) Water should be passed through system under pressure and flow gauge readings recorded.
Task.Notes: If it is not possible to sustain an effective fire-fighting jet from the topmost outlet, or any undue pressure loss in the rising main (after allowing for the height involved) should be investigated

Task.Action:
Check

a) inlets

b) landing valves

c) drain valves

d) door hinges

e) locking arrangements.

Report any defects.
Check cleanliness and condition.
Thoroughly check pumps and associated mechanical and electrical equipment.
Task.Notes: For more detailed instructions see Pumps SFG 45.

Task.Action: Check for visible damage, or signs of corrosion.
Task.Notes: Report to client if remedial work necessary.

Task.Action: Check for ease of movement.
Task.Notes: See notes above in respect of landing boxes.

Legislation.Content: Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005
BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.
BS 9990:2006 non - automatic fire-fighting systems fire mains

Introduction.Content:
HALON is a chlorofluorocarbon and as such has been phased out of general use and has been replaced by various other inert gases such as INERGEN because of the damaging effect HALON has on the upper atmosphere.

All extinguishant removed from containers during service or maintenance procedures shall be collected and recycled, or disposed of in an environmentally sound manner, and in accordance with existing laws and regulations.

Inert gas mixtures based on those gases normally found in the earth's atmosphere are exempted from this requirement.

Weekly, the client/user of the system should Visually check the hazard and the integrity of the enclosure for changes which might reduce the efficiency of the system. Carry out a visual check that there is no obvious damage to pipework and that all operating controls and components are properly set and undamaged. Check pressure gauges and weighing devices, if fitted, for correct reading and take the appropriate action specified in the users` manual.

Monthly, the client/user of the system should check that all personnel who may have to operate the equipment or system are properly trained and authorised to do so and, in particular, that new employees have been instructed in its use.


Such systems must only be maintained and tested by qualified engineers and in accordance with BS 5306-0:2011 and BS EN 15004 part 1:2008.


This task is applicable to the extinguishants listed below:
FK-5-1-12, HCFC Blend A, HCFC-123, HCFC-22, HCFC-124, HFC 125, HFC 227ea, HFC 23, IG-01, IG-100, IG-55, IG-541.


Where, due to unforeseen difficulties, it is necessary to leave an installation not available for use, the fire and rescue service should be informed immediately in order that alternative arrangements can be made to cover this deficiency should the need arise.  In addition a suitable notice to indicate that the installation is not available for use should be placed in a prominent position.

Task.Action: Test and service in accordance with appropriate manufacturers standards.
Check generally for mechanical damage.
Externally examine pipework to determine its condition. Examine nozzles for blockages and clean as necessary.
Task.Notes: Replace or pressure test and repair as necessary pipework showing corrosion or mechanical damage.

Task.Action: Check all control valves for correct manual function and automatic valves additionally for correct automatic function.
Where possible, remove cylinder valve and replace action caps.
Task.Notes: Carry out procedure in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations.

Task.Action: Check labels are securely fixed and legible, check security of brackets and fixings, check liquid level, check pressure in cylinder(s).  Externally examine containers for signs of damage or unauthorized modification, and for damage to system hoses.  If the visual examination shows any defect, the hose(s) shall be replaced.
Task.Notes:
For liquefied gases, check weight or use a liquid level indicator to verify correct content of containers.  If weight loss exceeds 5%, cylinder should be replaced or recharged.

Pressure gauges - liquefied gas should be within 10% and non-liquefied gases within 5% of correct pressure; replace or recharge any showing a greater loss.

The date of inspection and the name of the person performing the inspection shall be recorded on a tag attached to the container.  As required by statutory regulations remove cylinders and pressure test when necessary.

Task.Action: Where container pressure gauges or weight-monitoring devices are used for this purpose, they shall be compared to a separate calibrated device.
Task.Notes: Operational test to be carried out in accordance with manufacturer's recommended procedure.

Task.Action: Check slave actuation system including pistons in pneumatic valve actuators.

Task.Item: 9. Auxiliary electric device/alarm, door closures, etc.
Task.Action: Test operation.
Task.Notes: Operational test to be carried out in accordance with manufacturer's recommended procedure.

Task.Action: Check the enclosure for any boundary penetrations or other changes to it that could affect leakage of gas on operation.  If this can not be visually determined, an integrity test should be carried out.  Test should be carried out in accordance with Annex E BS EN 15004-1:2008.
Task.Notes: Where the integrity test reveals increased leakage that would result in an inability to retain the extinguishant for the required period, remedial action shall be carried out.

Legislation.Content: Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005
Pressure Equipment Regulations 1999 and 2002 amendment
BS EN 15004-1:2008 Fixed fire fighting systems - gas extinguishing systems. Design, installation and maintenance
BS 7273-1:2006 Code of Practice for the operation of fire protection measures. Electrical actuation of gaseous total flooding extinguishing systems
Pressure Systems Safety Regulations 2000
BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Carbon Dioxide total Flooding Fire Extinguishing System

Introduction.Content:
Such systems must only be maintained and tested by qualified engineers and in accordance with BS 5306-4:2001 and BS EN 15004 part 1:2008.

 
During servicing every care and precaution shall be taken to avoid release of extinguishant.


Where, due to unforeseen difficulties, it is necessary to leave an installation not available for use, the fire and rescue service should be informed immediately in order that alternative arrangements can be made to cover this deficiency should the need arise.  In addition a suitable notice to indicate that the installation is not available for use should be placed in a prominent position

Task.Action: Test and service in accordance with appropriate manufacturers standards.
Check generally for mechanical damage.
Externally examine pipework to determine its condition.  Examine nozzles for blockages and clean as necessary.
Task.Notes: Replace or pressure test and repair, as necessary, pipework showing corrosion or mechanical damage.

Task.Action: Check all control valves for correct manual function and automatic valves additionally for correct automatic function.
Where possible, remove cylinder valve and replace action caps.
Task.Notes: Carry out procedure in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations.

Task.Action: Check labels are securely fixed and legible, check security of brackets and fixings, check liquid level, check pressure in cylinder(s).  Externally examine containers for signs of damage or unauthorized modification, and for damage to system hoses.  If the visual examination shows any defect, the hose(s) shall be replaced.
Task.Notes: Carbon Dioxide containers - check weight or use a liquid level indicator to verify correct content of containers.  If weight loss exceeds 10%, cylinder should be replaced or recharged.  Check contents of pilot containers.  Liquefied gas type should be within 10% and non-liquefied within 5% of correct charge.  Replace or recharge any showing a greater loss.  The date of inspection and the name of the person performing the inspection shall be recorded on a tag attached to the container.  As required by statutory regulations remove cylinders and pressure test when necessary.

Task.Action: Where container pressure gauges or weight-monitoring devices are used for this purpose, they shall be compared to a separate calibrated device.
Task.Notes: Operational test to be carried out in accordance with manufacturer's recommended procedure.

Task.Action: Check slave actuation system including pistons in pneumatic valve actuators.

Task.Item: 9. Auxiliary electric device/alarm, door closures, etc.
Task.Action: Test operation.
Task.Notes: Operational test to be carried out in accordance with manufacturer's recommended procedure.

Task.Action: Check the enclosure for any boundary penetrations or other changes to it that could affect leakage of gas on operation.  If this can not be visually determined an integrity test should be carried out.  Test should be carried out in accordance with Annex A BS 5306-4:2001.
Task.Notes: Where the integrity test reveals increased leakage that would result in an inability to retain the extinguishant for the required period, remedial action shall be carried out.

Legislation.Content: BS 5306-4: 2001 - Fire extinguishing installations CO2 systems plus amendment A1:2012
BS 5839 Part 1 Fire detection and fire alarm systems for buildings. Code of practice for the system design, installation, commissioning and maintenance of systems in non-domestic premises: 2013
Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005
BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.

Introduction.Content:
Maintenance shall consist of measures necessary for ensuring that all parts of the foam system remain in operating condition. The availability and reliability of the foam systems shall be assured.

Inspection and maintenance by an approved competent organisation is recommended.  Such systems must only be maintained and tested by qualified engineers and in accordance with BS EN 13565-2:2009 and BS EN 15004 part 1:2008.

Where, due to unforeseen difficulties, it is necessary to leave an installation not available for use, the fire and rescue service should be informed immediately in order that alternative arrangements can be made to cover this deficiency should the need arise.  In addition a suitable notice to indicate that the installation is not available for use should be placed in a prominent position.

Task.Action: Check the correct function of the pumps and their drives (except foam concentrate pumps). The test run shall last for a period in which the normal operation conditions of the drive like power consumption, oil and cooling water temperature have been reached.  At the end of the test run power consumption in the case of electrical drives and revolutions, oil and cooling water temperature in the case of diesel engine drives shall be measured.  Test run diesel engines to reach operating temperatures (minimum 10 min).
Function test of automatic and manual pump start devices of foam concentrate pumps.
Check of oil level of pumps, compressors and diesel engines.
Check of the flow pressure in case of systems feed directly from public or factory mains.
Check of batteries concerning the maintenance instructions given by the battery manufacturer as well as function of the battery charger.
Check of minimum fuel supply of diesel engines.
Visual check of pipework, foam outlets, nozzles and pipe supports for damage or deterioration.
Task.Notes: If visual indication of normally dry pipework indicates questionable strength due to corrosion or mechanical damage, hydraulically pressure test.

Task.Action: Check frost protection for the permanently charged pipework system.
Test automatic refill devices of water tanks.
Check of alarm signalling to a permanent manned location in the case of automatic released extinguishing systems.
Check the air inlet opening of foam generating devices/nozzles are free from obstruction.
Check and clean strainers.
Functionally test the foam concentrate proportioner using water without the use of foam concentrate (where specified by the manufacturer.
Test the free movement of all valves and mechanically operated components.  Check for free operation of stop valves.
A check of the foam concentrate properties shall be carried out by competent and trained foam laboratory personnel.  The sampling shall be carried out according to the manufacturers instructions.
Task.Notes:
The checks shall include; foam type, specific gravity, PH, undissolved solids/sediment, drain time, foam expansion rate, spreading coefficient - film formation (on Cyclohexane) film forming foams only, alcohol burnback test (AR foams only).

The results, and 'pass' or 'fail' conclusions, shall be given in a report.

If the foam concentrate report does not give a 'pass' i.e. fit for use, as a result of its quality check tests, it shall be replaced immediately using foam concentrate of the same type which is passed fit for use.

Task.Action: A test of the proportioner and associated fittings shall be carried out. The test shall be carried out at the maximum and minimum system design flow rates.  The accuracy of foam proportioning shall be in accordance with the tolerance given in EN 13565-1.  These tests should, where possible, be carried out with environmentally compatible foam substitutes.

A discharge test should be carried out on each system to verify:

correct function of the system,

nozzles are free from blockage,

correct functioning of valves,

required discharge coverage is achieved.

A check of the premixed foam solutions properties shall be carried out by competent and trained foam laboratory personnel.  If the premixed foam solution report does not give a 'pass' i.e. fit for use, as a result of its quality check tests, it shall be replaced immediately using foam concentrate of the same type which is passed fit for use.
Check the foam concentrate tanks and components permanently in contact with foam concentrate for signs of external defects, e.g. leakage, debris on seals.
Inspect integrity of vapour seals on tank foam pourers and burst discs in subsurface systems.

Legislation.Content: Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005
BS 9999:2008 Code of Practice for fire safety in the design, management and use of buildings.
BS 5839 Part 1 Fire detection and fire alarm systems for buildings. Code of practice for the system design, installation, commissioning and maintenance of systems in non-domestic premises: 2013
BS 5306-1:2006 Code of Practice-fire extinguishing installations, Hose Reel, Foam inlets
BS EN 13565-2:2009 fixed fire fighting systems - foam systems. Design, construction and maintenance (incorporating corrigenda July 2009, April 2010 and September 2010)

Introduction.Content:
When removing parts from extinguishers, competent persons should ensure that they are clear of any parts which might be ejected. Under no circumstances should any attempt be made to remove the valves of high pressure extinguishers or cartridges under field conditions. Extreme caution should be used when opening any extinguisher.

Such devices must only be maintained and tested by qualified engineers and in accordance with current Statutory Requirements, Regulations and Manufacturers' Recommendations.  Service of this type of extinguisher may only be carried out if the extinguisher meets the criteria of the “critical uses” in the EC Regulations.

As this type of equipment is pressurised it can be opened for inspection only after discharge. This should be carried out after 10 years if the following annual maintenance has been carried out.

Task.Action: Check operation and pressure.  If pressure loss more than 10%, recharge ensuring no vapour loss to atmosphere.
Task.Notes: If device inoperative or pressure is below specified lower limit refer to manufacturer's instructions. If no device fitted use connection, if provided, to verify pressure.

Task.Action: Examine for corrosion or damage.
Weigh and check against records.
Examine and clean as necessary.  Check hose for wear or damage and replace if necessary.
Check operating mechanism and discharge control (where fitted) for free movement. Clean, rectify or replace as necessary.
Replace after maintenance activity or renew wire seal as appropriate.
Empty the extinguisher and strip the components down completely.  Reassemble and recharge the extinguisher with new headcaps and valves.
Task.Notes: Selected halon alternative agents have superseded halon usage in fixed fire suppression system and portable fire extinguisher applications.

Legislation.Content: BS EN 3-8:2006 Portable extinguishers
BS 5306-3:2009 Fire extinguishing installations and equipment on premises. Commissioning and maintenance of portable fire extinguishers. Code of practice
Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005
BS EN 3-7:2004+A1:2007 Portable fire extinguishers - Part 7: Characteristics, performance requirements and test methods

Introduction.Content:
When removing parts from extinguishers, competent persons should ensure that they are clear of any parts which might be ejected.  Under no circumstances should any attempt be made to remove the valves of high pressure extinguishers or cartridges under field conditions.  Extreme caution should be used when opening any extinguisher.

Such devices must only be maintained and tested by qualified engineers and in accordance with BS 5306-3:2009.

Task.Action: Check the safety clip and indicating devices to determine whether the extinguisher might have been operated.
Examine the exterior for corrosion, dents, gouges or damage that could impair the safe operation of the extinguisher paying particular attention to any plastics headcap for signs of degradation.

Weigh the extinguisher after removal of the discharge horn/hose assembly.  Check the mass against that recorded when first put into service or when last recharged and record this on the maintenance label.  In the event of a loss of content of more than 10%, discharge and recharge .
Check the operating instructions for correctness and legibility, ensuring that the text is in English.
Open the extinguisher by unscrewing the headcap. Remove the gas cartridge.

Remove the safety pin and check that the operating lever is undamaged and its movement is unobstructed.  Safety precautions should be taken to avoid inadvertent operation.  Return the safety pin or, where necessary, a replacement pin to the extinguisher.
Ensure that all seals for the discharge horn, the hose, the nozzle and the valve body are in place, as prescribed in the extinguisher manufacturers instructions.
Complete the details on the maintenance label.
Check any mounting bracket or stand if accessible and rectify any problems.
Write an inspection report advising the responsible person of the state of maintenance of the extinguisher.

a) Discharge the extinguisher.  Remove the swivel horn/hose assembly, the valve and the valve assembly, and remove the diptube from the valve assembly. Destroy the valve.

b) Pressure-test the body shell in accordance with the test pressure indicated on the body.  Do not overhaul the body if it is unmarked.  Permanently mark the body shell with the retest date and the identification of the organization performing the test.  (Attention is drawn to the Carriage of Dangerous Goods and Use of Transportable Pressure Equipment Regulations 2007).

c) Reassemble and recharge the extinguisher with new headcaps/valves.

Legislation.Content: BS EN 3-8:2006 Portable extinguishers
BS 5306-3:2009 Fire extinguishing installations and equipment on premises. Commissioning and maintenance of portable fire extinguishers. Code of practice
BS EN 3-7:2004+A1:2007 Portable fire extinguishers - Part 7: Characteristics, performance requirements and test methods
Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005

Introduction.Content:
When removing parts from extinguishers, competent persons should ensure that they are clear of any parts which might be ejected. Under no circumstances should any attempt be made to remove the valves of high pressure extinguishers or cartridges under field conditions. Extreme caution should be used when opening any extinguisher.

Such devices must only be maintained and tested by qualified engineers and in accordance with BS 5306-3:2009.

Task.Action: Check the safety clip and indicating devices to determine whether the extinguisher might have been operated.

Check the pressure-indicating device where fitted. If it is not operating freely or if the indicated pressure is outside the specified limits, refer to the extinguisher manufacturers instructions to ascertain the appropriate action to be taken.

Check that any dust covers needed on pressure-indicating or pressure-relief devices are in place and are of a size that does not obscure the reading of the gauge.  Where a pressure-indicating device is not fitted, verify, by means of the connection provided for this purpose, that the internal pressure is correct. If it is not correct, refer to the extinguisher manufacturers instructions to ascertain the appropriate action to be taken.
Examine the exterior for corrosion, dents, gouges or damage that could impair the safe operation of the extinguisher paying particular attention to any plastics headcap for signs of degradation.

Weigh the extinguisher after removal of the discharge horn/hose assembly.  Check the mass against that recorded when first put into service or when last recharged and record this on the maintenance label.  In the event of a loss of content of more than 10%, discharge and recharge.
Check the operating instructions for correctness and legibility, ensuring that the text is in English.

Where the extinguisher is designed to have the operating mechanism removed without the discharge of contents or loss of pressure, remove and check the operating mechanism and discharge control (where fitted) for free movement.  Clean and lubricate the operating mechanism, rectify any problems, or replace with a new operating mechanism as necessary.

Remove the safety pin and check that the operating lever is undamaged and its movement is unobstructed. Safety precautions should be taken to avoid inadvertent operation. Return the safety pin or, where necessary, a replacement pin to the extinguisher.

The seals for the discharge horn, the hose, the nozzle and the valve body should be replaced with new seals when these components are removed from the extinguisher. If the hose is fitted with a diaphragm, this should always be replaced with a new diaphragm.

Check the condition and fitness for use of the discharge nozzle, horn and hose, and ensure that the nozzle, horn and hose, if fitted, are not obstructed, cracked, worn, or damaged.

Replace with a new nozzle, horn and/or hose if necessary.

Reassemble the extinguisher in accordance with the instructions of the extinguisher manufacturer. Replace with new any safety clip and indicating device designed to show whether the extinguisher might have been operated.
Complete the details on the maintenance label.
Check any mounting bracket or stand if accessible and rectify any problems.
Write an inspection report advising the responsible person of the state of maintenance of the extinguisher.

Prior to performing the test discharge, the extinguisher should be examined externally for any obvious signs of damage to the body or operating mechanism. If a plastics headcap is coated in such a way as to disguise degradation (e.g. by painting), replace with a new headcap before proceeding to action 2.  In the case of stored pressure extinguishers, additional safety precautions should be observed.
Perform the test discharge on the extinguisher.

Examine the body internally and in detail for corrosion, dents, cuts, gouges or lining damage. Pay special attention to the welds. Follow the extinguisher manufacturers instructions where there are any doubts about the welds.
Examine and check all closures for thread wear, damage and corrosion as applicable.

Return the extinguisher to operational condition. If the extinguisher was fitted with a plastics headcap, it should be fitted with a new headcap.  If this has not already been fitted in action 1 (above), reassemble and recharge the extinguisher in accordance with the extinguisher manufacturers instructions.

Legislation.Content: Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005
BS EN 3-7:2004+A1:2007 Portable fire extinguishers - Part 7: Characteristics, performance requirements and test methods
BS EN 3-8:2006 Portable extinguishers
BS 5306-3:2009 Fire extinguishing installations and equipment on premises. Commissioning and maintenance of portable fire extinguishers. Code of practice

Introduction.Content:
When removing parts from extinguishers, competent persons should ensure that they are clear of any parts which might be ejected. Under no circumstances should any attempt be made to remove the valves of high pressure extinguishers or cartridges under field conditions. Extreme caution should be used when opening any extinguisher.

Such devices must only be maintained and tested by qualified engineers and in accordance with BS 5306.

Task.Action: Check the safety clip and indicating devices to determine whether the extinguisher might have been operated.
Examine the exterior for corrosion, dents, gouges or damage that could impair the safe operation of the extinguisher paying particular attention to any plastics headcap for signs of degradation.

Weigh the extinguisher after removal of the discharge horn/hose assembly.  Check the mass against that recorded when first put into service or when last recharged and record this on the maintenance label.  In the event of a loss of content of more than 10%, discharge and recharge.
Check the operating instructions for correctness and legibility, ensuring that the text is in English.
Open the extinguisher by unscrewing the headcap.  Remove the gas cartridge.

Examine the powder of the extinguisher.  Agitate the powder by inverting and shaking the extinguisher, taking care to avoid spillage.  If there is any evidence of caking, lumps, or foreign bodies, or if the powder is not free flowing, or if there is any doubt at all about the condition of the powder, discard all the powder and recharge.

The use of sieves or machines to remove foreign bodies or caked or lumpy material is not recommended since this will involve considerable exposure of the powder to atmospheric humidity with a risk of subsequent caking.

Clean if necessary and pass air through the air passages, paying particular attention to the vent holes (or other venting device) in the headcap.  Check that the strainer (where fitted), internal discharge tube and breather valve (where fitted) are unobstructed.  

Rectify any problems or replace with a new tube or valve if necessary. 

Renew gas-band, where fitted.  Check the operating mechanism and discharge control (where fitted) for free movement. 

Rectify any problems or replace with a new operating mechanism or discharge control as necessary.  

Protect moving parts and threads against corrosion with a lubricant as recommended by the extinguisher manufacturer.

Where the extinguisher is designed to have the operating mechanism removed without the discharge of contents or loss of pressure, remove and check the operating mechanism and discharge control (where fitted) for free movement.

Clean and lubricate the operating mechanism, rectify any problems, or replace with a new operating mechanism as necessary.

Remove the safety pin and check that the operating lever is undamaged and its movement is unobstructed.  Safety precautions should be taken to avoid inadvertent operation.  Return the safety pin or, where necessary, a replacement pin to the extinguisher.

Examine the gas cartridge externally for corrosion or damage.  If the gas cartridge has suffered mechanical damage or is corroded, replace as recommended by the extinguisher supplier.

Weigh the gas cartridge and check the mass against that marked on the gas cartridge.  If the gas cartridge has sustained a loss of content greater than 10% (15% for cartridges with a content mass of less than 30g) of the original content, withdraw it from service and replace it with a gas cartridge as recommended by the extinguisher manufacturer.

Check the date marked on the cartridge.

The seals for the discharge horn, the hose, the nozzle and the valve body should be replaced with new seals when these components are removed from the extinguisher.  If the hose is fitted with a diaphragm, this should always be replaced with a new diaphragm. 

Check the condition and fitness for use of the discharge nozzle, horn and hose, and ensure that the nozzle, horn and hose, if fitted, are not obstructed, cracked, worn, or damaged.

Replace with a new nozzle, horn and/or hose if necessary.
Examine the interior with the aid of an inspection light. Check for corrosion and deterioration of lining, if fitted.

Reassemble the extinguisher in accordance with the instructions of the extinguisher manufacturer. Replace with new any safety clip and indicating device designed to show whether the extinguisher might have been operated.
Complete the details on the maintenance label.
Check any mounting bracket or stand if accessible and rectify any problems.
Write an inspection report advising the responsible person of the state of maintenance of the extinguisher.

Prior to performing the test discharge, the extinguisher should be examined externally for any obvious signs of damage to the body or operating mechanism. If a plastics headcap is coated in such a way as to disguise degradation (e.g. by painting), replace with a new headcap before proceeding to action 2. In the case of stored pressure extinguishers, additional safety precautions should be observed.
Perform the test discharge on the extinguisher.

Examine the body internally and in detail for corrosion, dents, cuts, gouges or lining damage. Pay special attention to the welds. Follow the extinguisher manufacturers instructions where there are any doubts about the welds.
Examine and check all closures for thread wear, damage and corrosion as applicable.

Return the extinguisher to operational condition. If the extinguisher was fitted with a plastics headcap, it should be fitted with a new headcap, if this has not already been fitted in action 1 (above).  Reassemble and recharge the extinguisher in accordance with the extinguisher manufacturers instructions.

Legislation.Content: Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005
BS EN 3-7:2004+A1:2007 Portable fire extinguishers - Part 7: Characteristics, performance requirements and test methods
BS 5306-3:2009 Fire extinguishing installations and equipment on premises. Commissioning and maintenance of portable fire extinguishers. Code of practice
BS EN 3-8:2006 Portable extinguishers

Introduction.Content:
When removing parts from extinguishers, competent persons should ensure that they are clear of any parts which might be ejected. Under no circumstances should any attempt be made to remove the valves of high pressure extinguishers or cartridges under field conditions. Extreme caution should be used when opening any extinguisher.

Such devices must only be maintained and tested by qualified engineers and in accordance with BS 5306.

Task.Action: Check the safety clip and indicating devices to determine whether the extinguisher might have been operated.
Examine the exterior for corrosion, dents, gouges or damage that could impair the safe operation of the extinguisher paying particular attention to any plastics headcap for signs of degradation.

Weigh the extinguisher after removal of the discharge horn/hose assembly.  Check the mass against that recorded when first put into service or when last recharged and record this on the maintenance label.  In the event of a loss of content of more than 10%, discharge and recharge.
Check the operating instructions for correctness and legibility, ensuring that the text is in English.
Open the extinguisher by unscrewing the headcap. Remove the gas cartridge.

Pour the original charge into a clean container and, if it is to be reused, check it in accordance with the extinguisher manufacturers instructions. Where the additive is in a separate container, remove this container and check it for leakage. If the container has been leaking, discard the container and charge.  Rinse out the body.

Clean if necessary and pass air through the air passages, paying particular attention to the vent holes (or other venting device) in the headcap.  Check that the strainer (where fitted), internal discharge tube and breather valve (where fitted) are unobstructed.

Rectify any problems or replace with a new tube or valve if necessary.

Renew gas-band, where fitted.  Check the operating mechanism and discharge control (where fitted) for free movement.

Rectify any problems or replace with a new operating mechanism or discharge control as necessary.

Protect moving parts and threads against corrosion with a lubricant as recommended by the extinguisher manufacturer.

Where the extinguisher is designed to have the operating mechanism removed without the discharge of contents or loss of pressure, remove and check the operating mechanism and discharge control (where fitted) for free movement.  Clean and lubricate the operating mechanism, rectify any problems, or replace with a new operating mechanism as necessary.
Task.Notes: Note any special precautions, e.g. anti-freeze or corrosion inhibitor.

Task.Action: Remove the safety pin and check that the operating lever is undamaged and its movement is unobstructed. Safety precautions should be taken to avoid inadvertent operation. Return the safety pin or, where necessary, a replacement pin to the extinguisher.

Examine the gas cartridge externally for corrosion or damage.  If the gas cartridge has suffered mechanical damage or is corroded, replace as recommended by the extinguisher supplier.

Weigh the gas cartridge and check the mass against that marked on the gas cartridge.  If the gas cartridge has sustained a loss of content greater than 10% (15% for cartridges with a content mass of less than 30g) of the original content, withdraw it from service and replace it with a gas cartridge as recommended by the extinguisher manufacturer.

Check the date marked on the cartridge.

The seals for the discharge horn, the hose, the nozzle and the valve body should be replaced with new seals when these components are removed from the extinguisher.  If the hose is fitted with a diaphragm, this should always be replaced with a new diaphragm.  Check the condition and fitness for use of the discharge nozzle, horn and hose, and ensure that the nozzle, horn and hose, if fitted, are not obstructed, cracked, worn, or damaged.  Replace with a new nozzle, horn and/or hose if necessary.
Examine the interior with the aid of an inspection light.  Check for corrosion or lining deterioration.  Check separate containers for additives and replace if they are leaking or damaged.
Return the original charge to the extinguisher, or replace with new charge according to the instructions of the extinguisher manufacturer.

Reassemble the extinguisher in accordance with the instructions of the extinguisher manufacturer. Replace with new any safety clip and indicating device designed to show whether the extinguisher might have been operated.
Complete the details on the maintenance label.
Check any mounting bracket or stand if accessible and rectify any problems.
Write an inspection report advising the responsible person of the state of maintenance of the extinguisher.

Prior to performing the test discharge, the extinguisher should be examined externally for any obvious signs of damage to the body or operating mechanism. If a plastics headcap is coated in such a way as to disguise degradation (e.g. by painting), replace with a new headcap before proceeding to action 2. In the case of stored pressure extinguishers, additional safety precautions should be observed.
Perform the test discharge on the extinguisher.

Examine the body internally and in detail for corrosion, dents, cuts, gouges or lining damage. Pay special attention to the welds. Follow the extinguisher manufacturers instructions where there are any doubts about the welds.
Examine and check all closures for thread wear, damage and corrosion as applicable.

Return the extinguisher to operational condition.  If the extinguisher was fitted with a plastics headcap, it should be fitted with a new headcap, if this has not already been fitted in action 1 (above).  Reassemble and recharge the extinguisher in accordance with the extinguisher manufacturers instructions.

BS EN 3-8:2006 Portable extinguishers
BS EN 3-9:2006 Portable extinguishers co2
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document B 2007 edition Fire Safety
Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005

Examine the body internally and in detail for corrosion, dents, cuts, gouges or lining damage. Pay special attention to the welds. Follow the extinguisher manufacturers instructions where there are any doubts about the welds.
Examine and check all closures for thread wear, damage and corrosion as applicable.

Introduction.Content:
These notes should be read in conjunction with relevant sections Boilers - Heat generators SFG 05-01 to 05-33 . Only GAS SAFE registered service providers are permitted to work on flues. Ensure that flues conform to relevant guidance and BS/EN and boiler manufacturers recommendation. External dampers/economisers can infringe manufacturers guarantees and also HASAWA (www.hse.gov.uk).

Soot can be found in flues burning oil and coal. Soot is classified as a Hazard and disposed of on accordance with the Hazard Waste and COSHH Regulations.

It is essential to ensure that any discharge point does not endanger others, these must be proved safe.

Task.Item: 1. Drain plugs at the base of the flue.
Task.Action: Remove, allow any accumulated condensate to drain away and replace.
Task.Notes: This should be part of the routine maintenance carried out by in-house staff.

Task.Action: Inspect security of supports and condition of paintwork. Treat any signs of rust or corrosion.
Task.Notes: Particular attention should be paid to the condition of the base of the supports.

Task.Action: Where possible, check flue terminals at roof level.
Task.Notes: It is very important that flue terminals must be undamaged and free from any obstruction.

Task.Action: Clean thoroughly with custom made flue brushes and tools.
Task.Notes: Use access doors provided and reseal after operation. Remove all soot, fly ash and scale. N.B. when burning wood, coal, heavy oil and volatile waste, more frequent cleaning will be necessary and two monthly checks are advised.

Task.Action: Check for obstruction, corrosion and if fan assisted check safety circuit .
Task.Notes: Obstruction of the flueways can be caused by leaves and any other airborne debris.

Task.Action: Check for obstruction and condition of bearings.
Check pressure/vane switch action for correct operation. Check pressure/boiler interlock for correction operation.
Check action and control switches interlocks.
Check for obstruction and corrosion. If fan assisted check safety circuit .
Check condition and ensure movement is free.
Check condition and if free standing examine condition of guy ropes.
Task.Notes: After periods of severe weather examine the chimney structure and supports for damage.

Task.Action: Check for flue pull and deterioration.

Legislation.Content: HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996

BS 5440-1:2008 Flueing and ventilation for gas appliances of rated input not exceeding 70 kW net (1st, 2nd and 3rd family gases). Specification for installation of gas appliances to chimneys and for maintenance of chimneys
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995

BS 5440-2:2009 Flueing and ventilation for gas appliances of rated input not exceeding 70 kW net (1st, 2nd and 3rd family gases). Specification for the installation and maintenance of ventilation provision for gas appliances
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)

Introduction.Content:
Precautions in respect of Legionellosis and legionnaires' disease apply.

Approved Code of Practice - Legionnaires disease: The control of legionella bacteria in water systems: Approved Code of Practice, L8, 2013 sets out certain statutory requirements. In particular each water system, limitations detailed in ACOP L8, 2013 and HSG274 part 3 must be identified and assessed for legionellosis risk. Once a risk has been identified and assessed, a scheme must be prepared for preventing or controlling it, precautions implemented and managed records kept. The L8 has a special legal status, part 1 being regulatory and HSG274 parts 1, 2 and 3 being the guidance documents.

The frequency of the tasks are to be set in relation to the condition of the fountain and in line with the description in L8.

Task.Action: Clean and check spray pattern.
Task.Notes: Frequency will depend upon location and use and should be detailed in the risk assessment.

Task.Action: Check for gland leakage and satisfactory operation.
Task.Notes: For more detailed information on the maintenance see relevant section of Pumps (SFG 45-01).

Task.Action: Check condition and clean as necessary.
Task.Notes: Frequency will depend upon location and use and should be detailed in the risk assessment.

Task.Action: Check for cracks and signs of leakage. Report to client if remedial work is required.
Task.Notes: Failure of the waterproof lining or membrane is the most likely source of leakage. Frost damage to concrete is another cause.

Task.Item: 5. Water treatment plant. This does not apply when fish present.
Task.Action: See Water Treatment Introductory Procedures (SFG 65-01)
Task.Notes: Presence of fish will require special consideration.

Task.Item: 6. Automatic water make-up - float operated (ball valve)
Task.Action:
Check operation, water level and shut off.
Replace washer if necessary.
Check float for leakage and security.

Also See Storage Tanks Introductory Procedures (SFG 56-01)

Operate and check for correct linear travel.
a)  Check for solenoid noise i.e. buzzing
b)  Check that valve is not letting by excessively
c)  Inspect for gland leakage, refer to manufacturer's maintenance instructions
d)  Inspect for external deterioration.

Also See Valves - Automatic Control - Solenoid Valves (SFG 62-05)

Clean and check for:
a)  Physical damage
b)  Signs of water ingress or condensation, check seals and report to client
c)  Check integrity of electrical wiring and earth continuity
d)  Check for failed or blackened tubes or lamps. Replace as necessary.

Also See - Lighting Introductory Procedure (SFG 36-01)
Clean and disinfect ponds and make-up tanks including all wetted surfaces, descaling as necessary.
Task.Notes: Frequency will be indicated by the Risk Assessment and will depend on condition.

Legislation.Content: HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems
HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems
HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems
HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)

Introduction.Content:
Where possible these should be removed for cleaning.  Washing to remove grease and staining may be required.


Diffuser/grille locations and orientation should be marked or recorded if they are to be taken away for washing, so that they can be returned to the correct location.  Opposed blade dampers should have the as found setting marked to aid resetting.


Certain grille and diffuser arrangements may be installed such that they cannot be practicably removed for cleaning e.g. linear diffusers or those trapped by partition walls.  In situ cleaning by air line and extraction to capture dislodged deposits may be used.


Diffusers may have plenum boxes, possibly containing dampers behind them, which also require cleaning.  Access will be required to permit cleaning or air jetting and extraction methods.

Task.Action: Examine, check mountings and clean. Replace if holed.
Task.Notes: Where significant bird contamination or mould problems are encountered, a preliminary disinfection before starting work may be required and appropriate protection provided for cleaning operatives.

Task.Action: Examine, check fitting and clean.
Examine, check fitting and clean.
Clean and remove any debris, check for damage.
Task.Notes: Where significant bird contamination or mould problems are encountered, a preliminary disinfection before starting work may be required and appropriate protection provided for cleaning operatives.

Task.Action: Clean and check for any damage. Replace if holed.
Clean and check for any damage. Replace if holed.
Task.Notes: When cleaning, care should be taken to avoid damage to the fine mesh.  A low pressure water jet from behind should clear insect remains.

Introduction.Content:
Before commencing any maintenance work on Flame proof equipment, read Hazardous area (electrics) introductory procedures SFG 27-01 very carefully and follow all the safety procedures.

Replacement parts shall be in accordance with the safety documentation. Alterations to equipment shall not be carried out without appropriate authorisation where they adversely affect the safety of the equipment as stated in the safety documentation. Repairs and reclamation of equipment shall be carried out in accordance with IEC 60079-19.

Definition - flameproof enclosure d enclosure in which the parts which can ignite an explosive gas atmosphere are placed and which can withstand the pressure developed during an internal explosion of an explosive mixture, and which prevents the transmission of the explosion to the explosive gas
atmosphere surrounding the enclosure

Task.Action: Check for mechanical damage or signs of corrosion.
Task.Notes: Where bolts or other types of fastenings are used check that numbers are correct and that they are secure.

Task.Action: Check integrity.
Check for damage.
Task.Notes: Report to client if damage to faces requires replacement of equipment.

Task.Action: Check condition and replace as necessary.
Check condition of seals.
Task.Notes: Ensure compliance with requirements of BSEN 60079 Part 10.

Task.Action: Test the tripping operation.
Task.Notes: Responsibility for this check should be agreed with the client.

Task.Action: Check.
Task.Notes: This applies to every socket outlet, lighting switch and luminaire.

Task.Action: Check for presence, clean and check security of fixing.
Ensure that any seals are correctly in place and the correct number and type of cover bolts are used.

Legislation.Content: BS EN 60079-17:2014 Explosive atmospheres. Electrical installations inspection and maintenance

Introduction.Content:
Before commencing any maintenance work on Flame proof equipment, read Hazardous area (electrics) introductory procedures SFG 27-01 very carefully and follow all the safety procedures.


Replacement parts shall be in accordance with the safety documentation. Alterations to equipment shall not be carried out without appropriate authorisation where they adversely affect the safety of the equipment as stated in the safety documentation. Repairs and reclamation of equipment shall be carried out in accordance with IEC 60079-19.

Task.Action: Check installation for mechanical damage.
Task.Notes: The etching, painting or screening of light transmitting parts or the incorrect positioning of the luminaires may lead to excessive temperatures

Task.Action: Clean and check condition. Examine for incipient cracks in glass or retaining cement.
Task.Notes: Where the glass is cracked or broken no attempt should be made to re-cement a new glass in place. A replacement unit should be obtained from the original manufacturer.

Task.Action: Replace on a planned basis as appropriate.
Task.Notes: When replacing lamps the correct rating and type ONLY should be used, or excessive temperatures may result. Maintenance contract should be specific with regard to the responsibility for the provision and replacement of lamps and also for the disposal of spent lamps, as per statutory regulations.

Task.Action: Check condition of sealing rings etc. Ensure that any seals are correctly in place
Task.Notes: Any cable gland, stopping gland or plug, reducer or adapter must be BASEEFA (www.hse.gov.uk/eecs/eecshome.htm) approved for use with the apparatus.

Task.Action: Ensure that any seals are correctly in place and the correct number and type of cover bolts are used.
Task.Notes: Labels shall be inspected to ensure that they are legible and to ensure that the equipment actually fitted is that Specified and the source of supply

Legislation.Content: BS EN 60079-17:2014 Explosive atmospheres. Electrical installations inspection and maintenance

Introduction.Content:
Before commencing any maintenance work on Flame proof equipment, read Hazardous area (electrics) introductory procedures SFG 27-01 very carefully and follow all the safety procedures.

Replacement parts shall be in accordance with the safety documentation. Alterations to equipment shall not be carried out without appropriate authorisation where they adversely affect the safety of the equipment as stated in the safety documentation. Repairs and reclamation of equipment shall be carried out in accordance with IEC 60079-19

Task.Item: 1) Fault loop impedance or earthing resistance
Task.Action: The integrity of the earthing shall be checked at the initial inspection by measurement of resistance. The measurement may be made using an intrinsically safe resistance measuring instrument (within the procedure specified by the manufacturer). Subsequent sample inspections may also be carried out using an intrinsically safe resistance measuring instrument
Task.Notes: Non-intrinsically safe measuring equipment may be used if a safe work procedure (see IEC 60079-14) has been conducted and if the locations where potentially incendive sparking could occur, in case of dust hazards, can be guaranteed to be free from an explosive dust atmosphere and dangerous dust layers by those responsible for the area.

Task.Action: Earth connections to maintain the integrity of the intrinsic safety safe system (such as transformer screen earth, barrier relay frame earth) shall be measured. There is no requirement to measure the earth loop impedance of mains powered equipment associated with intrinsically safe circuits other than that required for normal control room instrumentation to protect against electric shock. Since, in some equipment, the intrinsic safety earthing is internally connected to the equipment frame, any impedance measurements (such as between the earth pin of the plug and the equipment frame, or the equipment frame and the control panel) shall be made using a tester specifically designed for use on intrinsically safe circuits

Intrinsically safe circuit earthing and/or insulation The insulation testing of intrinsically safe circuits is necessary to confirm that they are earthed or insulated from earth throughout, whichever of these conditions is required by the original design. This requirement may be unnecessary if an earth fault is self revealing, for example, if a circuit "fails safe" as result of an earth fault or the circuit uses an earth leakage monitoring device. Insulation testing of intrinsically safe systems or circuits shall only be carried out using a test device specifically approved for connection to such circuits. Where, in order to carry out these tests, the common earth connection to a group of barriers is disconnected, the tests can only be made if either the plant is free from hazard, or if power is removed completely from all the circuits which depend upon that common earth connection. This test is only required on a sample basis.

Legislation.Content: BS EN 60079-17:2014 Explosive atmospheres. Electrical installations inspection and maintenance

Introduction.Content:
Fan Convectors, Unit Heaters and Perimeter (skirting) Heating.

Maintenance of heat emitters can be divided into two main areas, namely the fixtures and fittings directly associated with the supply of heat and the grilles, the heat exchange surfaces through and over which the air passes. The efficiency of the grilles and heat exchange surfaces can be affected by fluff and fibres, the severity of which depends upon the location and the environment. Thus a dusty carpeted room with perimeter skirt heating will require much more frequent cleaning of grilles and heating surfaces than a lino covered floor in a clean environment. The frequencies shown in the table below refer to a clean environment but in extreme cases it may be necessary to clean grilles and heat exchangers as often as once a fortnight.

Correct combustion entails the adequate mixing of the fuel with air to ensure that the fuel is completely burnt without producing excessive smoke or diluting the combustion gases with excess air both of which cause energy wastage. With all fossil fuels, insufficient air produces carbon monoxide, a safety and health hazard, as undetected CO is poisonous.

Task.Action: Examine condition of casing, access panels and grilles. Check unit is secure.
Task.Notes: Check parts are securely fastened and free from 'rattles'.  Check condition of access panels. Clean inside of casing. If unit has loose grilles, check seal between unit and grilles to ensure no air leakage or short circuiting occurs.

Task.Action: Check all thermostats and other controls operate satisfactorily and are set in accordance with specification.
Task.Notes: If heater battery is fitted with a low temperature cut out (LTC) and hot water is not available, it may be necessary to insert a temporary link in the electrical control circuit to operate the unit.

Task.Action: When fitted remove, examine and check for damage. Clean or replace.
Task.Notes: Check if filter is cleanable or disposable type. The frequency of cleaning depends upon the dirtiness of the air. Normally cleaning should be every three months but more frequent cleaning may be necessary.

Task.Action: Inspect and clean. Purge air from hot water units.
Task.Notes: Clean using an industrial vacuum cleaner. Draw air through the heat exchanger in the opposite direction to the normal air flow. In exceptional cases a high pressure air hose may be required. In a dirty environment more frequent cleaning will be needed, e.g. quarterly, six weekly or even monthly.

Task.Action: Remove from heater casing if practical. Inspect and lubricate fan bearings and resilient mounts where applicable. Clean fans and motor. Examine wiring and connectors.
Task.Notes: Check fans are secure, motors operate silently and that bearings are in good order.

Task.Item: 6. Pipework, valves, steam traps and associated equipment.
Task.Action: Examine for corrosion or leaks. Where applicable clean steam traps, strainers, non return valves and scale pockets.

Check air temperature calibration against surface temperature of heat emitter. Advise client if air flow around sensor is restricted or affected by any reflected or other thermal gains. Check operation of thermostatic radiator valves.
Task.Notes: Low temperature surfaces for heat emitters are desirable in homes for senior citizens/disabled.

Task.Action: Leave unit in good working order.
Task.Notes: Report on any further work considered necessary.

Task.Action: Examine condition of casing, access panels and grilles. Check unit is secure, free from dust and dirt especially at air inlet and discharge grilles.
Check all thermostats and other controls operate satisfactorily and are set in accordance with specification.
Inspect air circulation fan set(s), check fan/motor assembly for damage and for correct alignment. Check for wear at any resilient mounts.
Examine heater battery/element, clean and comb as required.

Examine condition of casing, discharge louvres and inlet guards.  Check unit is secure and that all bolts, nuts, setscrews etc. are secure.  Check and clean surfaces of unit casing, check for corrosion, repair and treat as found necessary.  Ensure all access doors for fit and can be made secure.  When shut, ensure for air tight seal.
Task.Notes: Where applicable, check condition of any flexible ducting connections. Check security of mounting brackets or drop rods. Check that any discharge louvres are correctly set to give the desired air spread pattern.

Task.Action: Check all thermostats and other controls operate satisfactorily and are set in accordance with the specification.
Task.Notes: If heater battery is fitted with a low temperature cut out (LTC) and hot water is not available, it may be necessary to insert a temporary link in the electrical control circuit to operate the unit. Where applicable, check starter overloads are set to suit full load current.

Task.Action: Inspect and clean. Purge air from hot water units.
Task.Notes: Clean using an industrial vacuum cleaner. Draw air through the heat exchanger in the opposite direction to the normal air flow. In exceptional cases a high pressure hose may be required. In a dirty environment more frequent cleaning will be needed, e.g. quarterly, six weekly or even monthly. Vent coil at local air vent. If automatic air vent provided, check for correct operation.

Task.Action: When fitted remove, examine and check for damage. Clean or replace.
Task.Notes: Check if filter is cleanable or disposable type. The frequency of cleaning depends upon the dirtiness of the air. Normally cleaning should be every three months but more frequent cleaning may be necessary.

Task.Action: Check fan/motor bearings for abnormal wear.  Clean all surfaces, particularly fan impeller and motor casing vents.  Lubricate fan/motor bearings where grease nipples/lubricators are fitted, taking care not to over-grease.  Lightly grease fan motor slide rails.
Task.Notes: Check security of fans and condition of resilient mounts.  If applicable:  Check condition, tension and alignment of drive belts and pulleys.  Renew drive belts as necessary.  Check drive guard is in good repair and securely fixed, providing correct cover of all moving parts.

Task.Item: 6. Pipework, valves, steam traps and associated equipment.
Task.Action: Examine for corrosion or leaks. Where applicable clean steam traps, strainers, non-return valves and scale pockets.

Heater Unit.  Check function & operation of local isolation device (stoplock/isolator). Examine and report condition of all associated wiring, ensure security of all terminal connections and check for satisfactory condition of any flexible cables/conduits. Ensure plant has adequate earth conductor and bonding is secure. Take and log motor current and compare with nameplate details. Check all temperature control devices for correct operation and function.
Leave unit in good working order. After maintenance, carry out a general operational check, and check for excessive noise, vibration and temperature.
Task.Notes: Report on any further work considered necessary.

Task.Action: Examine condition of casing, access panels and grilles. Where applicable, check condition of damper seal. Check unit is secure.
Task.Notes: Check parts are securely fastened and free from `rattles`. Check condition of access panels. Clean inside of casing. If unit has loose grilles, check seal between unit and grilles to ensure no air leakage or short circuiting occurs.

Task.Action: Inspect and clean. Purge air from hot water units. Where applicable, examine condition of expansion joints, guides and anchors.
Task.Notes: Clean using an industrial vacuum cleaner. Draw air through the heat exchanger in the opposite direction to the normal air flow. In exceptional cases a high pressure hose may be required. In a dirty environment more frequent cleaning will be needed, e.g. quarterly, six weekly or even monthly.

Task.Item: 3. Pipework, valves, steam traps and associated equipment.
Task.Action: Examine for corrosion or leaks. Where applicable clean steam traps, strainers, non return valves and scale pockets.
When fitted examine condition of damper seals.

Check air temperature calibration against surface temperature of heat emitter. Advise client if air flow around sensor is restricted or effected by any reflected or other thermal gains. Check operation of thermostatic radiator valves.
Task.Notes: Low temperature surfaces for heat emitters are desirable in homes for senior citizens/disabled.

Task.Action: Leave unit in good working order.
Task.Notes: Report on any further work considered necessary.

Task.Action: Examine condition of panels and insulation.
Task.Notes: Clean panels and insulation, check that insulation is fitted and secured.

Task.Item: 2. Pipework, valves, steam traps and associated equipment.
Task.Action: Examine for corrosion or leaks. Where applicable clean steam traps, strainers, non return valves and scale pockets. Examine condition of expansion joints.
Check condition and security of drop rods, hangers and related equipment.
Leave unit in good working order.
Task.Notes: Report on any further work considered necessary.

Task.Action: Cleaning and maintenance.
Task.Notes: Due to possible difficulties of access, cleaning and maintenance should only be undertaken by a competent person.  When applicable, isolate units(s) from electrical supply by removing fuses or locking main switch in OFF position.  Always refer to the manufacturer's instructions/recommendations before undertaking any cleaning or maintenance.

Legislation.Content: Pressure Systems Safety Regulations 2000
Pressure Equipment Regulations 1999 and 2002 amendment

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Gas Fired Ceramic Plaque Infra Red Heaters

Introduction.Content:
These heaters are usually placed high up in a building and consequently are not easily accessible. A risk assessment and method statement should be carried out. Access by stepladders is not recommended. Regular maintenance is essential and whilst annual maintenance may be adequate in a clean environment, dusty conditions will require more frequent maintenance. In very dusty environments, e.g. textile factories, it may be more desirable to duct a direct combustion air line to the heater.

Correct combustion entails the adequate mixing of the fuel with air to ensure that the fuel is completely burnt without producing excessive smoke or diluting the combustion gases with excess air both of which cause energy wastage. With all fossil fuels, insufficient air produces carbon monoxide, a safety and health hazard, as undetected CO is poisonous.

Task.Action: check unit is secure and that all bolts, nuts, setscrews etc. for security. Check and clean surfaces of unit, check for corrosion, repair and treat as found necessary.
Clean using an air supply.
Task.Notes: The direction of air flow should be opposite to that of the gas flow.

Task.Action: Clean with wire brush, replace if there are any signs of corrosion. Check spark electrode gap for satisfactory setting, refer to manufacturer`s manual.

Check for satisfactory operation of local electrical isolation switch. Check function and operation of all control switches and temperature controls. Examine and report condition of all associated wiring, ensure security of all terminations and check for satisfactory condition of any flexible cables/conduits. Ensure plant has adequate earth conductor and bonding is secure.

Task.Item: 5. Gas pressure, gas pipework and cocks
Task.Action: Check with rated value and adjust if necessary. Check gas cocks are free to turn, lubricate as necessary. Inspect gas pipework system, check for leaks, loose brackets and supports, repair as necessary, report all findings.
Task.Notes: The rated value will be found on the identification plate or in the operating instructions.

Task.Action: Switch on and when stable plaque should present a uniform cherry red appearance.
Task.Notes: If the unit does not perform correctly the plaques should be cleaned. If the specified output is not obtained the unit should be replaced and returned to the manufacturer. Under certain conditions, e.g. broken plaque, the heater may light back, i.e. gas may ignite at the injector resulting in flames being vented from the exhaust of the heater. Apart from the lack of radiant effect light back will cause blockage of the plaque with carbon.

Legislation.Content: Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995
HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)

Introduction.Content:
These heaters are usually placed high up in a building and consequently are not easily accessible. A risk assessment and method statement should be carried out. Access by stepladders is not recommended. Regular maintenance is essential and whilst annual maintenance may be adequate in a clean environment, dusty conditions will require more frequent maintenance. In very dusty environments, e.g. textile factories, it may be more desirable to duct a direct combustion air line to the heater.

Correct combustion entails the adequate mixing of the fuel with air to ensure that the fuel is completely burnt without producing excessive smoke or diluting the combustion gases with excess air both of which cause energy wastage. With all fossil fuels, insufficient air produces carbon monoxide, a safety and health hazard, as undetected CO is poisonous.

Task.Item: 1. General and Isolation of heater from electrical and gas supply
Task.Action: Switch off, remove fuses and turn off gas supply. Inspect emitter tube and brush any dust from the exterior of the emitter tube. Inspect the emitter tube internally, clean with a vacuum cleaner as found necessary. Inspect and clean injector using a soft brush. Inspect and clean as necessary the burner fresh air duct (where fitted) and air inlet terminal. Inspect radiant tubes and fittings internally. If there is any appreciable build up of dust or deposits the tubes should be cleaned internally. If corrosion is present replace as necessary. Inspect for evidence of holes and cracks to tube couplers and replace if necessary.
Task.Notes: For safety reasons it is essential that the equipment is isolated from electricity and gas before servicing.

Task.Action: Disconnect gas union and remove complete burner unit.
Task.Notes: Clean the combustion chamber, inspect for damage and corrosion.

Task.Action: Remove, clean and refit.
Task.Notes: Only the manufacturer`s approved seals or jointing compounds must be used.

Task.Action: Remove, clean, inspect and refit.
Task.Notes: A competent engineer qualified as required by the Gas Safety Regulations must be used for this work.

Task.Action: Remove, clean and refit.
Task.Notes: Cleaning should be carried out using a soft brush or blowing with air. Use new gaskets and renew filter if necessary.

Task.Item: 6. Spark plug spark plug and burner electrode assembly
Task.Action: Remove, clean and refit. Check spark electrode gap for satisfactory setting, refer to manufacturer`s manual. Inspect burner electrode assembly, check electrodes for build up of carbon or cracks. Check the spark distance and position of electrodes relative to the burner head. Renew electrode assembly if not in good condition.
Task.Notes: Check ceramic for cracks or breakage. Renew if necessary.

Task.Action: Inspect and clean.
Inspect and clean, removing all dust on back of ceramic block.
Task.Notes: Check ceramic block and fireclay for signs of cracking. Renew if necessary.

Task.Action: Clean combustion chamber viewing window.
Examine and check switching differentials for correct operation.
Inspect acoustic joints for damage and replace if necessary.
Inspect condensate trap for blockages, dirt and scale, clean if necessary.
If fitted, examine mountings. Inspect vacuum fan and flue ductwork for any contamination.
Inspect to ensure correct fitting and Clean with soft cloth and detergent in water.

Task.Item: 15. Gas pressure, gas pipework and cocks
Task.Action: Pressure drop test back to nearest gas cock to ensure soundness. Check gas cocks are free to turn, lubricate as necessary. Inspect gas pipework system, check for leaks, loose brackets and supports, repair as necessary, report all findings
After cleaning and adjustment, re-assemble, cleaning the reflector plate. Check all auxiliary controls/ gas shut-off devices. Undertake heat test.
Task.Notes: With heater(s) switched on and system stabilised carry out a heat test in accordance with the manufacturer s recommendations. Check all burner units for correct ignition sequence pilot and main burner flames for stability and correct aeration, adjust if necessary. The following readings are to be taken and the system adjusted to meet the manufacturer s recommendations: - -vacuum at each end vent - -maximum and minimum pressure - -gas consumption

Task.Action: Check for satisfactory operation of local electrical isolation switch. Check function and operation of all control switches and temperature controls. Examine and report condition of all associated wiring, ensure security of all terminations and check for satisfactory condition of any flexible cables/conduits. Ensure plant has adequate earth conductor and bonding is secure

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Gas Fired Natural and Fan Assisted Heaters - Conventional and Balanced Flue

Introduction.Content:
These heaters are usually placed high up in a building and consequently are not easily accessible. A risk assessment and method statement should be carried out. Access by stepladders is not recommended. Regular maintenance is essential and whilst annual maintenance may be adequate in a clean environment, dusty conditions will require more frequent maintenance. In very dusty environments, e.g. textile factories, it may be more desirable to duct a direct combustion air line to the heater.

Correct combustion entails the adequate mixing of the fuel with air to ensure that the fuel is completely burnt without producing excessive smoke or diluting the combustion gases with excess air both of which cause energy wastage. With all fossil fuels, insufficient air produces carbon monoxide, a safety and health hazard, as undetected CO is poisonous.

Task.Action: Remove internal guard.
Task.Notes: Check the condition of both internal and external guards.

Task.Action: Remove and inspect for damage.
Clean grille.
Disconnect gas union, remove burner assembly complete.
Task.Notes: Clean the combustion chamber internally and externally, inspecting closely for signs of corrosion.

Task.Action: Check operation of ignition assembly.
Clean with fine wire brush reassemble pilot and test.
Task.Notes: Renew with manufacturers approved thermocouple if necessary

Task.Action: Check operation and condition of all burner controls including combustion fan if fitted.
Task.Notes: Check gas pressure to burner and pilot, adjust if required. Lubricate diaphragms to manufacturers specification. Check safety interlocks associated with combustion fan. A competent engineer qualified as required by the Gas Safety Regulations must be used for this work.

Task.Action: Inspect flue and flueways.
Renew flue gaskets, O-rings and joints.
Inspect for corrosion.

Task.Item: 10. Room air distribution fan assembly (if fitted).
Task.Action: Inspect fan bearings, fan wheel(s) or blades and check speed.
Task.Notes: Examine for cleanliness and freedom of operation.

Task.Item: 11 Gas pressure, gas pipework and cocks
Task.Action: Check with rated value and adjust if necessary. Check gas cocks are free to turn, lubricate as necessary. Inspect gas pipework system, check for leaks, loose brackets and supports, repair as necessary, report all findings.
Task.Notes: The rated value will be found on the identification plate or in the operating instructions.

Task.Action: Check for satisfactory operation of local electrical isolation switch. Check function and operation of all control switches and temperature controls. Examine and report condition of all associated wiring, ensure security of all terminations and check for satisfactory condition of any flexible cables/conduits.
