Ensure plant has adequate earth conductor and bonding is secure.
Check settings and correct operation of thermostats and time clocks.

Legislation.Content: The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)
Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996

Introduction.Content: When cleaning, ensure that system fans are off to avoid dirt disturbed during cleaning entering into the system.

Task.Action: Inspect for corrosion and clear obstructions (if any) in condensate drain piping on cooling side.
Task.Notes: Check that condensate traps on cooling coils are filled with water.

Task.Action: Clean coils by blowing through with dry, oxygen free, nitrogen from the opposite side to the air flow. Comb out fins. Where Nitrogen is used, a Risk Assessment must be done prior and suitable training given.
Task.Notes: Where necessary clean with appropriate sterilising solution, especially when coils operated under moist air conditions or act as a dehumidifier. Particularly dirty coils should be reported to the client as the filter changing regime may need to be amended.

Task.Action: Flush out coils to remove sediment.
Task.Notes: On heating coils, any scale build up which restricts water flow should be reported for further action.

Task.Action: Inspect for rust and clean and repaint as required.
Check for tightness and secure if necessary.
Check operation, condition of filters and sight glasses.
Inspect connections, pipes and supports for damage, loose or missing fittings.  Repair as necessary.

Clean coils by blowing through with dry, oxygen free, nitrogen from the opposite side to the air flow. Comb out fins. Where Nitrogen is used, a Risk Assessment must be done prior and suitable training given.
Task.Notes: Where necessary clean with appropriate sterilising solution. Particularly dirty coils should be reported to the client as the filter changing regime may need to be amended.

Task.Action: Inspect for rust and clean and repaint as required.
Check for tightness and secure if necessary.
Check operation, condition of filters and sight glasses.
Task.Notes: Full details of maintenance requirements steam services - see Pipework Systems SFG 40-11.

Task.Action: Inspect connections, pipes and supports for damage, loose or missing fittings.  Repair as necessary.

Clean coils air-side surfaces by blowing through with dry, oxygen free, nitrogen from the opposite side to the air flow. Where Nitrogen is used, a Risk Assessment must be done prior and suitable training given.
Task.Notes: Comb fins if appropriate. Where necessary clean with appropriate sterilising solution. Particularly dirty coils should be reported to the client as the filter changing regime may need to be amended.

Task.Action: Clean surfaces where access is provided.
Task.Notes: Report to client any deterioration of heating surface which requires further attention.

Task.Action: Inspect for rust and clean and repaint as required.
Check for tightness and secure if necessary.
Task.Notes: Corroded bolts should be replaced and any leaking joints between the heat exchanger and discharge of products of combustion must be rectified before the heater is put back into service.

Task.Action: Service.
Task.Notes: For detailed information on maintenance of gas fired heater see relevant gas burner (Burners SFG 07).

Task.Action: Service.
Task.Notes: For detailed information on maintenance of Flues, see Flues SFG 24-01.

Legislation.Content: Pressure Systems Safety Regulations 2000
Pressure Equipment Regulations 1999 and 2002 amendment

Introduction.Content: When cleaning ensure that system fans are off to avoid dirt disturbed during cleaning entering into the system.

Task.Action: Clean coils air-side surfaces by blowing through with dry, oxygen free, nitrogen from the opposite side to the air flow. Where Nitrogen is used, a Risk Assessment must be done prior and suitable training given.
Task.Notes: Comb fins if appropriate. Where necessary clean with appropriate sterilising solution. Particularly dirty coils should be reported to the client as the filter changing regime may need to be amended.

Task.Action: Inspect for rust and clean and repaint as required.
Check for tightness and secure if necessary.
Check that terminal screws are tight. Check the integrity of the internal wiring.
Task.Notes: Before opening lid isolate electrical supply in accordance with HSAWA requirements.

Task.Action: Check insulation resistance of each element. Check continuity.
Task.Notes: Replace if below 1 meg ohm resistance. Replace if open circuit.

Task.Action: Clean elements (comb out if finned type).
Task.Notes: Where necessary clean with appropriate sterilising solution.

Task.Action: Inspect for rust and clean and repaint as required.
Check for tightness and secure as necessary.
Task.Notes: Examine casing mounting flanges for air tightness where appropriate.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Task.Notes: For detailed maintenance see relevant section (Sensors and Switching Devices SFG 50).

Introduction.Content: The frequency of cleaning will depend upon the working environment.

Task.Action: Inspect for rust and clean and repaint as required.
Check and remove any dirt, inspect for rust and repaint as necessary.
Task.Notes: Do not use wire brush for dirt removal, blow off with dry nitrogen or compressed air. Where Nitrogen is used, a Risk Assessment must be done prior and suitable training given.

Task.Action: Check for both internal and external leaks.
Task.Notes: Cross leakage between the two air streams is undesirable as cross contamination could occur.

Task.Action: Check for tightness and secure as necessary.
Service and lubricate.
Check operation.
Check operation.
Task.Notes: Check action of thermostat in air supply side.  Setting should be 'air to room' at room temperature.

Task.Action: Check operation, clean and sterilise.
Clean or replace as necessary.
Task.Notes: Filters are fitted on both inlet and extract to keep the heat exchangers clean.  In normal use, air filters do not present a health and safety hazard.  However used air filters do contain quantities of dust which, unless precautions are taken, may expose maintenance personnel to a 'nuisance dust hazard', as defined by the Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH ) Regulations.  A risk assessment must be carried out before the work starts and a method statement produced.  Used filters must be regarded as Controlled Waste and appropriate safeguards taken for their disposal.

Task.Action: Lubricate according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Task.Notes: Sealed for' life' bearings should not need any maintenance.

Task.Action: Clean and check for rust. If necessary prepare and repaint rusty areas.
Clean, examine and treat any rusty areas and repaint.
Task.Notes: Note: do not scrape as surfaces may have special coatings.

Task.Action: Clean, taking care not to damage the mesh.
Task.Notes: Low pressure hot water containing detergent is the best cleaning agent but if the system is designed with a hygroscopic surface to recover latent heat refer to manufacturer for cleaning instructions.

Task.Action: Check condition and renew if necessary.
Inspect bearings for wear. Check flow rates/speed and leak tightness. Check electrical connections.
Task.Notes: Frequency should be in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.  Observe correct safety procedures as required under the Electricity at Work Regulations.  For further guidance see Pumps SFG 45.

Task.Action: Check that concentration is correct for the application.
Check for leaks.
Task.Notes: Remedy if possible, if major problem, refer to client .

Task.Action: Check and record.
Task.Notes: Confirm pressure vessel operating conditions. A written scheme of examination may be required for the system.

Task.Action: Clean with recommended cleaning compound and flush with water.
Check for leaks.
Task.Notes: Rectify as required providing new seals etc.

Task.Action: Inspect for rust, clean and clear any debris. Recoat. Check traps are filled with water on return to service.
Inspect the plate pack for deformed or damaged edges or for leakage.
Task.Notes: Gaskets extruding from the plate pack normally indicate a damaged plate or failed gasket. The most common cause of such failure is working at excess pressure which has to be corrected. A major overhaul is necessary if the pack is deformed.

Task.Action: The exterior finish of the heat exchanger frame (not the plate pack) should be washed down and rubbed dry, then a thin film of cleaner applied.
Task.Notes: The correct type of cleaner as recommended by the manufacturer should be used and this will normally provide lasting protection provided the treated services are not subject to high temperature.

Task.Action: Clean all surfaces, check tightness of fixing screws.
Task.Notes: Depending upon the make of heat exchanger, lubricate plate and follower hanger surface each time the plate is opened.

Task.Action: Check tightness of fixing screws.
Task.Notes: Depending upon the type of exchanger, smear surfaces with a thin film of grease when plate pack is open.

Task.Action: Check tightness of flanged or pipe union fittings on header.
Check for splits, signs of cracking or other deterioration.
Check for collapsed peaks, splits or hardening.
Check security of connector grid boss fixings when plate pack is exposed.
Coat all exposed threads with appropriate lubricant.
Grease threads with maker's recommended grease or paste.
Clean, apply maker's recommended grease.
Task.Notes: Inspect for serious wear and replace as necessary.

Task.Action: Always ensure that these are properly attached when the heat exchanger is operating.

Task.Item: 13. Exchanger operation (where suitable gauges have been fitted).
Task.Action: Check temperatures on inlet/outlet and pressure drop.
Task.Notes: Fluctuating outlet temperatures could indicate a perforated plate, allowing intermixing of primary and secondary fluids. Low output pressure could possibly be due to scale deposits on the plates, a blockage in the plate pack or inlet pipeline, all of which cause energy waste. If de-scale or hygienic cleaning is necessary, it should be carried out strictly in accordance with the heat exchanger manufacturer's recommended procedure.

Task.Action: Check Safety valve operation.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Water to Water Plate Heat Exchangers
Cooling Towers - Precautions against Legionnaires Disease (Legionella Pneumophila)

Introduction.Content:
Approved Code of Practice - Legionnaires disease:

The control of legionella bacteria in water systems: Approved Code of Practice, L8, 2013 sets out certain statutory requirements. In particular each water system must be identified and assessed for legionellosis risk. Once a risk has been identified and assessed a scheme must be prepared for preventing or controlling it, precautions implemented and managed records kept. The ACOP L8, 2013 has a special legal status, guidance is now given in HSG274 part 1 for cooling towers.

If you are prosecuted for breach of Health & Safety law, and it is proved that you did not follow the relevant provisions of the code, you will need to show that you have complied with the law in some other way or a court will find you at fault. Health and Safety inspectors seek to secure compliance with the law and may refer to the ACOP L8, 2013 and accompanying Guidance Documents as illustrating good practise. It is therefore important to comply with it.

Action to be taken prior to the visit.

1.  Notify appropriate local and/or water authority/company, prior to discharging water drained from the cooling tower as the contaminated water could enter sewers.

2.  Advise client that cooling tower will be out of action during period of visit.
Introduction.Notes:
Towers that have not been regularly maintained must be treated as HAZARDOUS and must not be maintained by personnel who may be susceptible to LEGIONELLA.

Appropriate Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), as detailed in the Method Statement, must be worn at all times. All PPE must be selected by a competent person as suitable for the purpose and must fit the individual operative properly (Health & Safety (PPE) Regulations).

Task.Action:
Ensure Competent fully trained maintenance personnel read ACOP L8, 2013 and HSG274 part 1 (www.hse.gov.uk).

a)  Select personnel who are less susceptible to the disease.
b)  Protective clothing and positive pressure respirators.
c)  Cooling water analysis.
Task.Notes:
Before starting work on cleaning cooling towers it is essential that certain preliminary safety precautions are taken. These are listed under 'Action'. 

Personnel must wear positive pressure respirators when contamination is suspected or the condition is not known.
Note:- respirator seal may not work with beards.

Sample and send to a UKAS (www.ukas.com) accredited laboratory for total viable colony count (TVC).  Dipslides should be taken weekly.

Disinfection, cleaning and manual desludging of cooling towers should be undertaken at least twice a year, but more frequent cleaning may be necessary depending on local environmental conditions such as dirty atmospheres and the conclusions reached in the risk assessment.

Cooling systems that have a short operating period may only need to be cleaned at the beginning and end of that period.

If on inspection the system shows signs of a significant build-up of deposits or slime, then disinfection and cleaning should be carried out.

Task.Action: Advise client that you are on site.
Task.Notes: Report to security personnel where appropriate.

Task.Action: Post at approaches to cooling tower and enclosure.
Task.Notes: It is essential that anyone approaching the cooling tower is warned and notices must state:  'Restricted Area - Do Not Enter'.

Task.Action: Close any in the vicinity of the work.
Isolate chillers(s), cooling towers and circulating pumps.
Task.Notes: If this involves entering vicinity of cooling tower and if tower is not regularly maintained, don protective clothing including positive pressure respirators.

Task.Action: Ensure that all electrical equipment is isolated except pumps and fans.

Task.Item: 6. Automatic dosing equipment, continuous drains and water supply.
Task.Action: Close water supply, circulate for fifteen minutes, isolate pumps and drain to waste.
Add at a recommended concentration.
Task.Notes: Use of the bio-dispersant breaks down the bio-film which is usually present on most surfaces.

Task.Action: Check pH which should be between 7 and 8. If higher, contact water treatment specialist for advice.
Task.Notes:
If chlorine is used as the disinfectant, its efficacy is reduced if the system pH value is greater than pH 8.  To achieve the same disinfection effect, its residual needs to be increased 3-4 times, ie in place of 5mg/l for 5 hours, 15-20 mg/l is required for the same period.

Generally this is not recommended, so if the system water is above pH 8 adopt one of the following procedures to compensate, without increasing the chlorine residual:

a)  introduce a heavy bleed-off for several hours to both reduce the pH of the system water and its chlorine demand before carrying out disinfection;
b)  reduce system pH by adding an acid;
c)  augment chlorine dosage with sufficient sodium bromide to change the disinfectant from chlorine to bromine.

Task.Action: Add oxidising biocide such as chlorine, bromine or chlorine dioxide in conjunction with a suitable bio-dispersant.
Task.Notes:
Any action taken must conform to the requirements of CIBSE TM13, HSE ACOP L8, HSG274 part 1 and other H&S (http://www.hse.gov.uk/hthdir/noframes/coshh/index.htm) regulations.

At 5 mg/l the system should be run for at least five hours, at 25mg/l for 2 hours and at 50mg/l for 1 hour.

If chlorine is used as the disinfectant, its efficacy is reduced if the system pH value is greater than pH 8.  To achieve the same  disinfection effect, its residual needs to be increased 3–4 times, ie in place of 5 mg/l for 5 hours, 15–20 mg/l is required for the same period.

Generally, this is not recommended, so if the system water is above pH 8 adopt one of the following procedures to compensate, without increasing the chlorine residual:

a)  introduce a heavy bleed-off for several hours to both reduce the pH of the system water and its chlorine demand before carrying out disinfection;
b)  reduce system pH by adding an acid;
c)  augment chlorine dosage with sufficient sodium bromide to change the disinfectant from chlorine to bromine.

If bromine or chlorine dioxide is used in systems where the pH is above 8, the reserves do not need to be increased or the pH adjusted, as these disinfectants remain effective at higher pH.

Task.Action:
Replace fuses to pumps, switch on and run to allow the required concentration of the free disinfectant to be established and circulated throughout the cooling system for an initial period with the fans off to ensure thorough mixing of the disinfectant throughout the system.

Once this is achieved, (usually after 15 minutes) the fan(s) should be switched on for the remainder of the process to ensure that disinfectant reaches all internal surfaces that become wet during normal operation of the tower and which potentially could be contaminated.
Task.Notes:
The disinfecting solution is to be monitored periodically and maintained in the cooling system throughout the disinfection period by adding more disinfectant as required.

The normal disinfectant level required depends on the minimum circulation period adopted.

A continuous minimum residual of 5 mg/l as free chlorine, for a minimum period of 5 hours, should be maintained, but if time available to conduct the operation is limited, using a higher disinfectant concentration for a shorter time may be acceptable. This will, however, increase the risk of damage to the fabric of the system. Excessive disinfectant levels should be avoided.

Task.Action: Switch off pumps, remove fuses and drain complete system.
Task.Notes: When starting to drain, open water supply to assist in neutralising system, then shut off water supply and allow to drain. It is essential that the whole system is completely drained. Check for drain cocks on pipework serving chiller.

Task.Item: 12. Tower packing and drift eliminators, etc.
Task.Action:
Dismantle so far as is practicable and clean.

See comment in next action (13. All surfaces).
Task.Notes: If packing shows signs of deterioration - replace.  When replacing drift eliminators, ensure that these are correctly fitted and secured.

Task.Action: All accessible surfaces to be cleaned with a wire brush.  To remove all deposits thoroughly, chemical cleaning may be necessary.
Task.Notes:
Accessible areas of the tower and its pack should be adequately washed but cleaning methods that create excessive spray, for example high-pressure water jetting, should be avoided.  If this is not possible, the operation should be carried out when the building is unoccupied or, in the case of permanently occupied buildings, windows in the vicinity should be closed, air inlets blanked off and the area that is being water-jetted should be tented. 

The area should be isolated and consideration should also be given to other occupied premises in the immediate areas as well as members of the public who may be in the vicinity during cleaning. 

Ensure all scale, rust and other mineral and organic deposits are removed. Any rust areas should be treated and repainted.

Task.Action: Every part of the system must be cleaned ie. feed tank, ball valve, softener etc.
Task.Notes: If any part of the system is left uncleaned, contamination of the whole system may result.

Task.Action: Sweep out all loosened deposits and place in plastic sacks with the tops securely fastened.
Task.Notes: Ensure safe removal of sacks from site. Waste Disposal Regulations may apply.

Task.Action: Clean with low pressure hose.
Task.Notes: If possible close valves from tower to chiller during wash down. If a high pressure hose has to be used, tent tower to prevent any spray drift.

Task.Action:
Close drain valves, open water supply, fill system and chlorinate to 5 ppm. Replace pump fuses, switch on pumps and run system for six hours. The use of a bio-dispersant will enhance the effectiveness of this chlorination.

If the system volume is greater than 5m3, the water should be dechlorinated, drained, flushed and refilled with fresh water and dosed with the appropriate start-up level of treatment chemicals, including the biocides.
Task.Notes:
While the maintenance of a continuous minimum residual of 5 mg/l of free chlorine for a minimum period of 5 hours is considered the best practice, if the downtime to conduct such a lengthy operation is not viable, some compromise may be necessary.

Under such circumstances it may be acceptable to shorten the pre- and post- chlorination times and to increase the free chlorine level, eg. 50 mg/l for 1 hour or 25 mg/l for 2 hours.

This should only be done if the operators are trained in this process because, at these levels, there is a greater risk of damaging the fabric of the system.

Task.Action: Repeat actions detailed above for draining the system (item 11).
Task.Notes:
If returning the system to immediate service, the disinfectant level can be allowed to decay over the first few hours of operation and a start-up level of the normal water treatment chemicals added. If, however, the system is going to be left idle before restarting, dechlorinate the water, drain and flush the system and leave it empty.

On start-up, the system should be refilled with fresh water and the water treatment programme immediately reinstated with a dosage of the appropriate start-up level of treatment chemicals, including biocides. 

Before water containing high residuals of chlorine, bromine, chlorine dioxide etc is discharged to drain, neutralise the disinfectant. The usual procedure is to add sodium thiosulphate, sodium sulphite or sodium bisulphite as a neutraliser.

The effluent from any disinfection and/or chemical cleaning process, neutralised or not, may be regarded by the effluent receiver as trade effluent and may require a ‘consent to discharge’. Therefore, permission to discharge may be required from the effluent receiver.

Task.Action: Re-fill the system.
Task.Notes: If chlorine concentration exceeds 2 ppm prior to activating water treatment regime, drain and refill.

Task.Action: Clean, derust and repaint as required.

Task.Item: 21. Activation of water treatment and dosing.
Task.Action: Contact water treatment organisation.
Task.Notes: Water treatment organisation will activate system and take samples for analytical tests.

Task.Action: Remove and bag before returning through occupied parts of the building.
Restart. Check frost protection is operational.
Re-open windows and restart ventilation fans.
Record all activities carefully in the form of duplicate job sheets.
Task.Notes: Give client one copy of the report and retain the other.

Task.Action: Advise client on completion of work.
Take sample for TVC count.
Task.Notes:
Note:  Weekly dip slides will indicate bacteria levels.  A high bacterial level does not necessarily mean the Legionella bacteria are present. 

Bacterial checks should be undertaken weekly.  The water treatment analysis should be undertaken on a 3 monthly basis as a minimum, not 6 monthly.

Task.Action: Check the condition of the fan motor through temperature or vibration analysis and compare to baseline values. Assure that all bearings are lubricated per the manufacturer's recommendation. Check for excessive wear and secure fastening. Aligning the motor coupling allows for efficient torque transfer.
Physically clean screen(s) of all debris.
Check that drain and overflow are clear from blockage.
Operate switch manually to ensure proper operation.
Check for excessive vibration in motors, fans and pumps. Check for loose fill, connections, leaks, etc.
Check that water treatment automatic dosing equipment is functional.
Task.Notes: For Further Guidance see Water Treatment (SFG 65).

Task.Action: Test for proper concentrations of dissolved solids, and microbiological quality of the pond water by undertaking a dip slide test. Adjust blowdown and chemicals as necessary. Record the result. Undertake additional water quality tests such as pH, conductivity and tests for hardness salts as determined by risk assessment.
Task.Notes: Refer to ACOP L8, 'Table 1 - Typical on-site monitoring checks recommended for good operating practice'.

Task.Action: Test for proper concentrations of dissolved solids, and microbiological quality of the pond water by undertaking a dip slide test. Adjust blowdown and chemicals as necessary. Record the result. Undertake additional water quality tests such as pH, conductivity and tests for hardness salts as determined by risk assessment.
Task.Notes: Refer to ACOP L8, 'Table 1 - Typical on-site monitoring checks recommended for good operating practice'.

Task.Action: Check internal surfaces for algae, scale, rust and limescale accumulation.

Task.Item: 10. Drift eliminators, louvres, tubes and fill.
Task.Action: Look for proper positioning and scale build up.  Clean as needed.
Task.Notes: The frequency of the task can vary depending on the water quality. The Risk Assessment may give greater or lesser frequencies for this task.

Task.Action: Make sure water is flowing through nozzles to ensure even distribution over the fill.
Inspect bearings and drive belts for wear. Adjust, repair, or replace as necessary.

Undertake annual maintenance.

For further guidance see Motors (SFG 39-01).

Legislation.Content: HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems
HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems
HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)
HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems
Local Act

Task.Action: Isolate from electrical and other services.
Task.Notes: Isolate electrical supply in accordance with H&S requirements.

Task.Action: Clean fan blades and lubricate if required.  'Sealed for life' bearings should not be serviced.  See Fans (SFG 20).
Task.Notes: Ensure that the correct oils and/or greases and quantities are used. It is particularly important that lubricants of the correct working range are used. Oil attracts dust and as a consequence any excess should be wiped clear (e.g. fan blades) see manufacturer's instructions.

Task.Action: Clean by blowing through with dry, oxygen free nitrogen.
Task.Notes: Do not use refrigerant for cleaning tubes, use dry nitrogen or compressed air. Sterilisation may be required. Where Oxygen Free Nitrogen is used, a Risk Assessment must be carried out prior to use and suitable training given. Any discharged refrigerant must be recovered and not released to atmosphere. Any persons working on these systems must be registered to an approved Certified Scheme provider, in accordance with the "F" Gas and Building Regulations.

Task.Action: Blow through with dry, oxygen free nitrogen.
Task.Notes: Do not use refrigerant for cleaning fins, use dry nitrogen or compressed air. Where Oxygen Free Nitrogen is used, a Risk Assessment must be carried out prior to use and suitable training given.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Check - visual condition - effectiveness.
Task.Notes: There should be no transfer of vibration or visible deterioration.

Task.Action: Check for satisfactory operation of local electrical isolation device (stoplock/isolator). Examine and report condition of all associated wiring, ensure security of all terminal connections and check for satisfactory condition of any flexible cables/conduits. Ensure plant has adequate earth conductor and bonding is secure.
Check condition.  Repair and reseal as necessary.
Clean surfaces and components of unit particularly fan impeller and motor casing.  Check and clean surfaces of unit casing, check for corrosion, repair and treat as found necessary.
Task.Notes: Remove any dirt or rubbish from vicinity of plant.

Task.Action: Check function and operation of all automatic sensors/detectors (flow/temperature). Check for correct operation/shut-down of plant. Ensure all devices are returned to their correct settings. Clean air inlet & discharge grilles. Check all access doors for fit and can be made secure. When shut, ensure for air tight seal.
Task.Notes: i.e. Start/stops and capacity regulators should be in accordance with externally applied control systems if applicable.

Introduction.Content: A log book describing these services should be maintained and details entered about the various maintenance activities and results of all the tests.

Task.Action: Check for corrosion, sludge and slime/algae.
Task.Notes: Frequency to be agreed with client who should be advised of any remedial work.

Task.Item: 2. Cold water temperature (at outlet of cistern or tank and farthest outlet from cistern).
Task.Action: Monitor to ensure compliance with HSG274 part 2 (www.hse.gov.uk) & HTM 04-01 part B requirements.
Task.Notes: Responsibility for this test should be agreed with client. Advise client if temperature outside HSG274 part 2 requirements for any remedial work to be put in hand.

Task.Item: 3. Hot water temperature (at outlet of calorifier).
Task.Action: Monitor to ensure compliance with HSG274 part 2 requirements.
Task.Notes: Responsibility for this test should be agreed with client. Advise client if temperature outside HSG274 part 2 requirements for any remedial work to be put in hand.

Task.Action: Open to ensure blow down of collected sediment. To be carried out in a safe manner. Requires method statement for minimal aerosolation.
Task.Notes: This is particularly applicable in vacant buildings where services are left running and more frequent opening of drain valves is recommended.

Task.Action: If there is a need to disinfect whole system, advise client.
Task.Notes:
Refer to HSG274 part 2.
Frequency is indicated by Risk Assessment.

Task.Action: Flush little used outlets to remove stagnant water.
Task.Notes: To be carried out in a safe manner ensuring that aerosols do not occur.

Legislation.Content: Local Act
HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)
HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems
HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems
BS EN 806-5:2012 Specifications for installations inside buildings conveying water for human consumption. Operation and Maintenance
HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems

Introduction.Content:
Warning – Insulation may contain Asbestos.

Low temperature hot water systems (LTHW or LPHW) are heating systems operating up to 95°C.

Prior to carrying out the planned maintenance of the calorifier, the pre-maintenance procedure detailed in SFG 32-04 should be followed:

(a) Check equipment operating status (i.e. whether in operation or not in use, whether isolated from system) including safety;
(b) Inspect calorifier insulation and/or shell for signs of damage;
(c) Inspect all manholes, mounting and joints for signs of leaks;
(d) Report any necessary remedial work where repairs, adjustment or replacement will be required during routine maintenance.

Domestic Hot Water Calorifiers

All secondary systems used to provide a hot water service must be disinfected after a period of shutdown or standby over a one week period in accordance with HSG274 part 2 and HTM 04-01 Parts A & B.  This includes shutdown to inspect calorifiers.

Task.Action: Check, note and report any visible defects. Ensure an Anti-stratification pump has been fitted on the secondary side of the calorifier and it is operational.
Task.Notes: Ensure both secondary and primary circuits are full of water and circuits are open.

Task.Action: Check operation of safety.
Task.Notes: If manually operated for test purposes, leakage could occur after test.

Task.Item: 3. Thermostats, pressure sensors, altitude gauges and thermometers.
Task.Action: Check for correct operation and settings; set against Certified masters.
Task.Notes: N.B. Temperature settings should be in accordance with HSE (www.hse.gov.uk) guidance note HSG274 part 2 for Hot Water Services.

Task.Action: Shut down primary heat source.
Task.Notes: Check operation of temperature controls and high limit cut-outs.

Task.Item: 5. Drain valve/drain cock on secondary side.
Task.Action: Ensuring secondary valves are closed, draw off a small quantity of water to remove any sediment.
Task.Notes: N.B. If calorifier was in use, the secondary water will be hot so care must be taken in carrying out this item of the schedule.  If the secondary side of the calorifier is at a high temperature, the system must be allowed to cool before drain is opened.

Task.Item: 6. Heating surface and internal surfaces of shell.
Task.Action: Drain down secondary side, remove manholes and inspect for scale formation and corrosion and report. Remove sludge.
Task.Notes: The formation of scale reduces heat transfer and causes energy wastage. Corrosion will cause metal failure and leakage. Remember Waste Disposal Regulations. If scale is extensive refer to client for further instructions.

Task.Action: Check condition.
Check status.
Refit all manholes, refill secondary side. Hydraulic pressure test. Put primary side into operation.
Task.Notes: Check operation of all temperature controls.  Carry out item 3.

Task.Action: Carry out a full disinfection of the calorifier.
Task.Notes: Procedure as laid down in BS 8558:2011 paragraph 5.2.3.9 and HTM 04-01 Part B.

Legislation.Content: HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)
Local Act
BS EN 806-5:2012 Specifications for installations inside buildings conveying water for human consumption. Operation and Maintenance
HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems
HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems
HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Hot Water Calorifiers - Heated by MTHW, HTHW or Steam

Introduction.Content:
Most MTHW, HTHW and Steam Calorifiers will be under the control of an Authorised Person.  A permit to Work must be issued by the Authorised Person before any work can commence on a Calorifier

WARNING - If insulation looks damaged - STOP WORK - this may be Asbestos - Appropriate action must be taken prior to further works.  If the insulation is known or CERTIFIED not to be Asbestos, continue as follows: 

In the interests of safety and the prevention of scalding, water temperatures and the operation of blending valves should be checked at least once a month by the caretaker or operator.  See Introductory Procedures - Hot Water Supply (SFG 32-01) for further information on temperatures etc.

WARNING - WATER AND STEAM LEAKS ARE DANGEROUS

Prior to carrying out the planned maintenance of the calorifier, the pre-maintenance procedure detailed below should be followed:

(a) At the entrance to the Plant room, Stop and Listen for a steam leak (High Pressure steam will be invisible and only the sound of a leak may be present);
(b) Check equipment operating status (i.e. whether in operation or not in use, whether isolated from system) including safety;
(c) Inspect calorifier insulation and/or shell for signs of damage;
(d) Inspect all manholes, mounting and joints for signs of leaks;
(e) Report any necessary remedial work where repairs, adjustment or replacement will be required during routine maintenance.

Disinfection - Domestic Hot Water Calorifiers

All secondary systems used to provide a hot water service must be disinfected after a period of shutdown or standby over a one week period in accordance with HSG274 part 2 (www.hse.gov.uk) and HTM 04-01 Parts A & B.  This includes shutdown to inspect calorifiers.

Frequencies should be confirmed on ALL tasks in conjunction with written scheme of examination.

Task.Item: 1. Check operation, in particular safety controls.
Task.Action: Check, note and report any visible defects. Ensure an Anti-stratification pump has been fitted on the secondary side of the calorifier and it is operational.
Task.Notes: Ensure secondary is full of water and circuits are open. If safety controls are defective take equipment out of service.

Task.Action: Check for corrosion and manually operate.
Task.Notes: NB:  If calorifier was in use, the secondary water will be hot and can be under pressure, so care must be taken in carrying out this item of the schedule.

Task.Item: 3. Thermostats, pressure sensors, altitude gauges and thermometers.
Task.Action: Check for correct operation and settings, set against Certified masters.
Task.Notes: Temperature settings for Hot Water Services should be in accordance with HSE ACOP L8, 2013 (www.hse.gov.uk).

Task.Action: Shut down primary heat source taking all necessary precautions to prevent unauthorised use.
Task.Notes: Check safe operation of temperature controls and high limit cut-outs. This may include obtaining a Permit to Work from an Authorised Person.

Task.Item: 5. Drain valve/drain cock on secondary side.
Task.Action: Draw off a small quantity of water to remove any sediment.
Task.Notes: NB:  If calorifier was in use, the secondary water will be hot, and can be under pressure, so care must be taken in carrying out this item of the schedule.

Task.Item: 6. Heating surface and internal surfaces of shell.
Task.Action: Drain down secondary side, remove manhole covers and inspect for scale formation and corrosion.
Task.Notes:
The formation of scale reduces heat transfer and causes energy wastage.  Client's attention should be drawn to the presence of excessive scale which indicates the need for water treatment.  Corrosion will cause metal failure and leakage. 

Remember Waste Disposal Legislation. 

If scale is extensive, refer to client for further instructions.

Task.Action: Check gaskets on steam chest for leakage, replace as necessary.
Task.Notes: Steam leaks are dangerous to personnel and cause wastage of energy.

Task.Action: Check status.
Check operation and service as appropriate.
Clean and overhaul steam trap.
Task.Notes: Faults can lead to steam and energy wastage.

Task.Action: Remove strainer, clean and refit.
Arrange for an internal inspection to be carried out by a Competent Person as required by the Written Scheme of Examination.
After completion of maintenance, refit all manhole covers, refill secondary side and put primary side back into operation.
Task.Notes:
Check that all controls are working correctly.

Carry out item 6.

Task.Action: Carry out a full disinfection of the calorifier.
Task.Notes: Procedure as laid down in BS 8558:2011 paragraph 5.2.3.9 and HTM 04-01 Part B.

Task.Action: Check condition.
Repair or renew as necessary.
Task.Notes:
Damaged lagging reduces efficiency, wastes heat, and if the calorifier is in the open air, can become waterlogged and lead to hidden corrosion.

Asbestos Regulations may apply.

Task.Action: If a pressurised system, test to 110% of working pressure.

Legislation.Content: HSE Managing and working with asbestos - Control of Asbestos Regulations 2012
HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)
Control of Asbestos Regulations 2012
Pressure Equipment Regulations 1999 and 2002 amendment
Pressure Systems Safety Regulations 2000
HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems
BS EN 806-5:2012 Specifications for installations inside buildings conveying water for human consumption. Operation and Maintenance
HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems
HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems

Introduction.Content:
Prior to carrying out the planned maintenance of the calorifier, the pre-maintenance procedure detailed in SFG 32-04 should be followed:

(a) Check equipment operating status (i.e. whether in operation or not in use, whether isolated from system) including safety;
(b) Inspect calorifier insulation and/or shell for signs of damage;
(c) Inspect all manholes, mounting and joints for signs of leaks.

Hot Water Calorifiers

All secondary systems used to provide a hot water service must be disinfected after a period of shutdown or standby over a one week period in accordance with HSG274 part 2 and HTM 04-01 Parts A & B.  This includes shutdown to inspect calorifiers.

Task.Action: Check and record the calorifier water storage temperature.
Task.Notes:
It is recommended that the hot water should be stored at 60ºC (HSG274 part 2). 

Where temperatures are recorded below 60ºC, increase set point to achieve the desired temperature.  If the temperature cannot be maintained, report to Client.

Task.Action: Check, note and report any visible defects.  Ensure an Anti-stratification pump has been fitted on the secondary side of the calorifier, where it is required, and it is operational and does not run continuously.
Task.Notes: Ensure both secondary and primary circuits are full of water and circuits are open.

Task.Action: Check for corrosion and manually operate.
Task.Notes: If calorifier was in use, the secondary water will be hot and can be under pressure, so care must be taken in carrying out this item of the schedule.

Task.Item: Thermostats, pressure sensors, altitude gauges and thermometers
Task.Action: Check for correct operation and settings, set against Certified masters.
Task.Notes:
Temperature settings for Hot Water Services should be in accordance with HSG274 part 2.

With direct acting valves hot water storage temperatures should not exceed those laid down in the above guidance notes or scalding could occur.

Task.Action: Shut down primary heat source.
Task.Notes: Check operation of temperature controls and high limit cut-outs.

Task.Item: Drain valve/drain cock on secondary side
Task.Action: Draw off a small quantity of water to remove any sediment.
Task.Notes: If calorifier was in use, the secondary water will be hot and can be under pressure, so care must be taken in carrying out this item of the schedule.

Task.Action: Check status.
Carry out a full disinfection of the calorifier.
Task.Notes: Procedure as laid down in BS 8558 and HTM 04-01 Part B.

Task.Item: Heating surface and internal surfaces of shell
Task.Action: Drain down secondary side, remove manhole covers and inspect for scale formation and corrosion and report.
Task.Notes: The formation of scale reduces heat transfer and causes energy wastage. In hard water areas scale can be very difficult to remove if left to build up and more frequent maintenance is recommended. Corrosion will cause metal failure and leakage.

Task.Action: Check condition.
Refit all manhole covers, refill secondary side.  Put primary side back into operation.

Legislation.Content: HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)
HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems
HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems
HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems

Introduction.Content:
Certain common maintenance procedures should be carried out for all controls. These are:


1.  All control items, e.g. thermostats and the like, that have switching contacts ensure contacts make and break easily and that there is no arcing or pitting;
2.  Inspect thermostat phial and capillaries for mechanical damage;
3.  Inspect thermostat pockets for corrosion and leakage;
4.  Ensure immersion thermostats are secure in their pockets (and that the sensor is in contact with the end of the pocket);
5.  Inspect motorised valves for leakage and damage to linkage

For more detailed information regarding the maintenance of motorised valves, checking of gland seals, stroking, etc. refer to relevant section.

Task.Action: Check operation and confirm set point.
Task.Notes: Thermostat in-built as part of calorifier or installed in/on secondary pipework.

Task.Action: Check operation and confirm set point.
Check operation and confirm set point(s).
Task.Notes: For guidance on Motorised valves see Valves - Automatic Control SFG 62.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Task.Notes:
Ensure valve shuts off supply to calorifier and does not have let-by.

See Actuators SFG 01-07 and 01-08.

Task.Action: Check operation and confirm set point.
Task.Notes: For guidance on Motorised valves see Valves - Automatic Control SFG 62.

Task.Item: 6. Direct acting control valve - high limit.
Task.Action: Check operation and confirm set point.
Task.Notes: For guidance on Motorised valves see Valves - Automatic Control SFG 62.

Task.Item: 7. Temperature sensor. Controller. Motorised valve. Power fail return motor.
Task.Action: Check performance.

Introduction.Content:
Prior to carrying out the planned maintenance of the cylinder, the pre-maintenance procedure detailed in SFG 32-04 should be followed:

(a) Check equipment operating status (i.e. whether in operation or not in use, whether isolated from system) including safety.
(b) Inspect calorifier insulation and/or shell for signs of damage.
(c) Inspect all manholes, mounting and joints for signs of leaks.
(d) Report any necessary remedial work where repairs, adjustment or replacement will be required during routine maintenance.

DISINFECTION

All secondary systems used to provide a hot water service must be disinfected after a period of shutdown or standby over a one week period in accordance with HSG274 part 2 (www.hse.gov.uk) and HTM 04-01 Parts A & B.  This includes shutdown to inspect calorifiers.

Task.Action: Check and record the calorifier water storage temperature.
Task.Notes:
It is recommended that the hot water should be stored at 60ºC (HSG274 part 2). 

Where temperatures are recorded below 60ºC, increase set point to achieve the desired temperature.  If the temperature cannot be maintained, report to client.

Task.Item: Integral Cold Water Storage (if Combination Cylinder)
Task.Action: Inspect cold water storage, clean as necessary.
Task.Notes:
See Storage Tanks - Cold Water Storage Tanks and Cisterns (SFG 56-02) for detailed maintenance schedule of cisterns. Where these units are used infrequently or low usage the cold water storage is likely to rise above 20ºC therefore promoting the likelihood of Legionella proliferation.

For this reason integral cisterns should be kept clean and conform to the Water Supply (Water Fittings) Regulations. 
HTM 04-01 for health care recommends that these units are not used.

Task.Action: Inspect visible seams and bosses for leaks or signs of corrosion.
Check connecting pipe unions for leaks.
Task.Notes: If found, drain down, clean and remake joint.

Task.Action: Inspect for deterioration.
Task.Notes: Refer to client if repairs or renewal required.

Task.Action: Check operation and examine for scale on element.
Task.Notes: Client's attention should be drawn to the presence of excessive scale, which indicates the need for water treatment.

Task.Item: Cold Water Storage Cistern (if Combination Cylinder)
Task.Action: Inspect seams and bosses for leaks.

Task.Item: Float Operated Valve and Float (if Combination Cylinder)
Task.Action: Check operation and adjust water level to maximum storage level. Check float for leakage and security.
Carry out a full disinfection of the calorifier.
Task.Notes: Procedure as laid down in BS 8558 and HTM 04-01 Part B.

Task.Action: Check water outlet temperature and operation of auto-temperature controls.
Task.Notes: Temperature setting for Hot Water Services should be in accordance with HSG274 part 2 and HTM 04-01 Part A.

Task.Action: Ensure that the temperature sensor has a good surface to surface contact with the cylinder.

Legislation.Content: HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)
HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems
HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems
HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems

Task.Action: Check temperature setting.
Task.Notes: Temperature settings for Hot Water Services should be in accordance with HSG274 part 2 and HTM 04-01 Part A.

Task.Action: Manually operate.
Task.Notes: Check that the valve seats satisfactorily, water flow ceased on valve closure and water runs through tun dish and discharge pipes.

Task.Action: Manually operate.
Check operation.
Task.Notes: Should be non self-setting. Thermal cut out should be 85C.

Task.Action: Examine water storage vessel, expansion vessel, pipework and fittings.
Task.Notes: Check for any signs of corrosion and water leaks. Reseal pipework joints if necessary.

Task.Action: Examine discharge pipes, ensure that air gap is clear and that there is no blockage in the pipes.
Task.Notes: Discharge pipe should be visible and in a safe place. It should be of metal and connected to the tun dish.

Task.Action: Check pressure.
Task.Notes: See Hot Water Supply - Expansion Vessels (SFG 32-12).

Task.Action: Check operation.
Task.Notes: Ensure no water flows through valves during shut down part of the cycle. For further guidance see Valves - Automatic Control (SFG 62).

Task.Action: Inspect and clean as required.
Check operation and ensure that non-return valve is seating properly.
Task.Notes: The operation can be checked by observing any changes in the upstream level of a vessel preceding the device when the incoming supply is isolated.

Task.Action: Check for scale on element.
Task.Notes: Client's attention should be drawn to presence of excessive scale which indicates a possible need for water treatment or water conditioning.

Legislation.Content: HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems
HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems
HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems
HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Thermal Storage Cylinder (Individual Dwellings for DHWS)

Introduction.Content:
DISINFECTION

All secondary systems used to provide a hot water service must be disinfected after a period of shutdown or standby over a one week period in accordance with HSG274 part 2 and HTM 04-01 Parts A & B.  This includes shutdown to inspect calorifiers.

Task.Action: Check and record the calorifier water storage temperature.
Task.Notes:
It is recommended that the hot water should be stored at 60ºC (HSG274 part 2).

Where temperatures are recorded below 60ºC, increase set point to achieve the desired temperature.

If the temperature cannot be maintained, report to client.

Task.Action: All secondary systems used to provide a hot water service must be disinfected after a period of shutdown or standby over a one week period in accordance with HSG274 part 2 and HTM 04-01 Parts A & B.  This includes shutdown to inspect calorifiers.
Check connecting pipe unions for leaks.
Task.Notes: If found, drain down, clean and remake joint.

Task.Action: Inspect for deterioration.
Task.Notes: Refer to client if repairs or renewal required.

Task.Action: Check operation and examine for scale on element.
Task.Notes: Clients attention should be drawn to the presence of excessive scale which indicates the need for water treatment.

Task.Action: Inspect seams and bosses for leaks.
Task.Notes: Report adverse findings. Ensure tanks meet the requirements of BS 8558 regarding cleanliness, lids, screens etc.

Task.Item: Float operated valve and float (if fitted)
Task.Action: Check operation and adjust water level to minimum make up level. Check float for leakage.
Task.Notes: Re-washer or replace if necessary. Water level adjustments should only be carried out when the heating system and cylinder are cold. Replace if necessary.

Task.Action: Carry out a full disinfection of the calorifier.
Task.Notes: Procedure as laid down in BS 8558 and HTM 04-01 Part B.

Task.Action:
Check operation.
Check water outlet temperature and operation of auto-temperature controls.
Task.Notes: NB:  Temperature settings for Hot Water Services should be in accordance with HSG274 part 2 and HTM 04-01 Part A.

Task.Action: Ensure that the temperature sensor has a good surface to surface contact with the cylinder.

Legislation.Content: HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems
HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems
HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)
HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems

Task.Action: Examine for damage or corrosion.
Check condition and pressure.
Task.Notes: Ensure diaphragms are sound and cushion pressure is correct. Top up as necessary, preferably with oxygen free nitrogen.

Task.Action: Check.
Task.Notes: Ensure gas cushion pressure is correct, if necessary top up, preferably with oxygen free nitrogen. Remove diaphragm from shell, check and report on condition of both. Ensure cushion pressure is correct when re-commissioned. A risk Assesment must be done prior to its use, suitable training must also be given prior.

Task.Item: 2. Non-return valve. (Cold water service (CWS) to calorifier).
Task.Action: Check.
Discharge by flushing.
Task.Notes: In most installations the vessel will be a source of contamination by acting as a dead leg.

Introduction.Content:
Heater generation may be by electricity, light oil pressure jet burners, forced draught but usually atmospheric gas burners. For specific maintenance instructions on heat generator see appropriate Boilers/Heat Generators (SFG 05).

Special note:

Certain heaters called 'Energy saver water heaters' will have an electrically operated damper in the flue to reduce ventilation losses through the heater. The operation sequence is when the thermostat calls for more heat the damper opens, changing the contacts on a microswitch. This then provides power to the heat generation equipment.

WARNING: To avoid the possible risk of scalding, Thermostatic Mixing Valves (TMV’s) must be considered in line with a risk assessment where vulnerable persons are likely to use the outlets. All other outlets not blended should have hot water warning signs.  Client should carry out monthly checks of the outlet temperature where blended.

Department of Health, HTM 04-01 Part A sets out the safe water temperatures and appropriate delivery devices (TMV`s) over a range of areas/activities.

Task.Action: Remove and carry out necessary maintenance.
Remove at slip collar and clean.
Remove and clean.
Remove and clean.
Task.Notes: Note: All debris should be removed with a vacuum cleaner.

Task.Action: Clean with suitable brush.
Reassemble in reverse order.
Task.Notes: Ensure that on reassembly, the flue is sealed in an air tight manner.

Task.Action: Carry out a smoke test on flue.

Task.Notes: It is recommended that this operation is carried out at the same time as flueway maintenance.

Task.Action: Turn off, isolate and remove heat generator. Where applicable, switch off electricity and remove fuses. Turn off water supply.
Drain down using drain valve on side of heater.
Remove to gain access to inspection plate.
Remove inspection plate, check for scale build up.
Task.Notes: If scale build up is excessive, chemical descaling will be necessary.

Task.Action: Check for condition, replace if necessary.
Task.Notes: Do not replace copper and aluminium anodes but replacement of magnesium anodes may be necessary in steel vessels.

Task.Action: After inspection of internal surfaces a new gasket should be fitted to inspection plate before reassembly.
Task.Notes:
Note:  Ensure that the heater is thoroughly flushed out and that any deposits are removed. 
Waste Disposal Regulations may apply.

Task.Action:
Fill up and test for soundness. Refit heat generator in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.
Test fire.
Carry out a full disinfection of the calorifier.
Task.Notes: Procedure as laid down in BS 8558:2011 paragraph 5.2.3.9 and HTM 04-01 Part B.

Legislation.Content: HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems
HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems
Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)
HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)
HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems
HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Instantaneous Electric Water Heaters (Non Drinks Type)

Task.Action:
Check water outlet temperature and operation of auto-temperature controls.
OR
Check that the installation has a high turnover.
Task.Notes:
NB:  Temperature settings should be in accordance with HSG274 part 2 for Hot Water Services, ie 60°C.

Frequencies are Monthly/Six Monthly or as indicated by the Risk Assessment.

Task.Item: Visual inspection for leaks and damage
Task.Action: Report any remedial work needed to client and isolate if unsafe.
Task.Notes: If switched off, the unit is classed as a deadleg if still connected to the supply. In this case (weekly) flushing should be carried out and logged, (twice weekly) in health care establishments.

Task.Action: Isolate electric supply, turn off water inlet drain unit, remove filter/strainer and clean filter as necessary.
After a filter replacement, check operation of heater and set flow as appropriate.
In hard water areas descale.

Legislation.Content: HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems
BS EN 806-5:2012 Specifications for installations inside buildings conveying water for human consumption. Operation and Maintenance
HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)
HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems
HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Packaged Electric Water Heaters - Cistern Type (Non Drinks)

Task.Notes: The exact maintenance procedure will depend upon the make and configuration as most packaged units have different design arrangements.

Task.Action: Measure temperature, check against thermostat settings. Adjust thermostat as necessary.
Task.Notes: Temperature settings should be in accordance with HSG274 part 2 for Hot Water Services, ie.  60°C.

Task.Action: Inspect cold water storage, clean and disinfect as necessary.
Task.Notes:
Where these units are used infrequently or low usage the cold water storage is likely to rise above 20°C therefore promoting the likelihood of Legionella proliferation. For this reason integral cisterns should be kept clean and conform to the Water Supply (Water Fittings) Regulations.

If evidence shows that the unit regularly overflows hot water into the integral cold water header tank, instigate a temperature monitoring regime to determine the frequency and take precautionary measures as determined by the findings of this monitoring regime.

Task.Action: Check, if unit out of service ask client for reasons.
Task.Notes: If electrically defective, ensure equipment is left disconnected and isolated. Ensure water supply is isolated at spur to avoid deadlegs.

Task.Action: Visual inspection for leaks and damage.
Check temperature setting.
Task.Notes: Check operation of temperature controls and high limit cut-outs.

Task.Action: Isolate, remove fuse and check rating is correct.
Task.Notes: Units must not be left with electrical element if incoming water supply is isolated.

Task.Action: Check, if ball valve needs re-washering, isolate water supply and repair ball valve. Check for leakage and security.
Task.Notes: A defective ball valve will cause the cistern to overflow.

Task.Action: Drain down unit, remove inspection covers and inspect for scale and corrosion. De-scale as appropriate or replace heating element.
Task.Notes: The formation of scale affects heat transfer and increases energy consumption. It also causes overheating of the electrical element leading to failure. Corrosion will cause the bare electrical element to be exposed to water and hence will be unsafe.

Task.Action: Refit all inspection covers, refill heater and cistern. Turn on water supply to unit and check for leaks. Fit fuse and turn on electrical supply.
Task.Notes: Check operation of all temperature controls and leave in full operation. Thermal disinfection to be carried out, logged and certificated as per L8 Part 2 guidance if having been out of action, unused for over 1 week or is new.

Task.Action: Prior to reinstatement, carry out a full disinfection of the calorifier.
Task.Notes: Procedure as laid down in BS 8558 and HTM 04-01 Part B.

Legislation.Content: HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems
HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)
HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems
HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems
BS EN 806-5:2012 Specifications for installations inside buildings conveying water for human consumption. Operation and Maintenance

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Humidifier - Cold Water Evaporator, Drum Type

Introduction.Content:
Any action taken must conform to HSE requirements, the control of Legionella bacteria in water systems – ACOP L8, 2013 and HSG274 part 3 (www.hse.gov.uk) and HEVAC Association code of best practice 4 commissioning and planned maintenance.

Persons responsible for maintenance should record who the competent persons responsible for maintenance are, tests and results, routine maintenance, cleaning and disinfection dates, as per the HSE’s Code of Practice L8.

In hard water areas more frequent maintenance may be required.

All monitoring and maintenance activity should be recorded in a log, particularly that relating to Legionella monitoring and control.

Task.Action: Isolate electrically and hydraulically.
Closely inspect. Replace filter pads as necessary. On reassembly use new gaskets where necessary.
Task.Notes: Report condition. If filter pads need replacement it is necessary to first clean the rotor.

Task.Action: Flush and clean if necessary.
Task.Notes: Flush and clean in accordance with BS 8558:2011.

Task.Action: Check for leakage and make good any defects.
Check for soundness.
Check for correct functioning.
Clean up and remove.
Task.Notes: Any sludge solids removed should be in sealed bags and any solutions used for cleaning must be flushed away before returning the unit to operation. Waste Disposal Regulations apply.

Task.Action: Check that all moving parts can move freely.
Change oil.
Lubricate.
Check operation.
Task.Notes: Ensure compliance with HSC ACOP L8, 2013 (www.hse.gov.uk).

Introduction.Content:
Any action taken must conform to HSE requirements.  The control of Legionella bacteria in water systems – ACOP L8, 2013 and HSG274 part 3 (www.hse.gov.uk) and HEVAC Association code of best practice 4 commissioning and planned maintenance.

Persons responsible for maintenance should record who the competent persons responsible for maintenance are, tests and results, routine maintenance, cleaning and disinfection dates, as per the HSE’s Code of Practice L8.

Note:- When in operation, there is intermittent live steam injected from manifold within. DO NOT ATTEMPT TO SERVICE WITHOUT ISOLATING STEAM AND ELECTRICITY SUPPLIES FIRST.

If the system has been out of operation for more than 3 months then the system should undertake a yearly maintenance and then be subject to a re-commission.

All monitoring and maintenance activity should be recorded in a log, particularly that relating to Legionella monitoring and control.

Task.Action: Isolate electrically.

Check any flange bolts for tightness and adjust as required.  
Check all gland seals and adjust as required. 
Visually inspect all pipework and joints for leaks.
Clean and flush out the steam cylinder.
Task.Notes: If automatic time controlled flush out valve is fitted, check correct operation by overriding timer. It may be necessary from time to time to adjust between automatic flushing depending upon humidification requirements which can vary with the weather conditions.

Task.Action: Check operation. Clean and renew washer.
Check level in gauge glass corresponds with indicator plate.

Check operation, clean if necessary.
For Further Guidance see Sensors and Switching Devices (SFG 50-04 and 50-05).
Task.Notes: Use a hand held hydrometer to check accuracy of operation.

Task.Action: Observe spray pattern, clean if necessary.
Task.Notes: Clean with compressed air. Do not use wire or pointed objects as these will enlarge the orifices and lead to a poor misting pattern.

Task.Action: Check for correct functioning.
Check operation condition of filters and sight glasses.
Check.
Check strainer on steam supply clean or replace as necessary.

Turn off at ball valve and empty via drain cock. Disconnect the water supply and remove the fill valve from the humidifier. Remove the inlet strainer. Clean the fill valve and inlet strainer using the same solution as used to clean the steam cylinder.

Remove outer casing lid baffles. Remove any scale either physically or by using suitable chemical descaling agent. If the electrodes are deteriorated, replace the steam cylinder rather than cleaning it.
Task.Notes: Ensure that any sludge or scale deposits are removed from the bottom of the steaming chamber. Additional access may be provided on the side of the vessel to facilitate cleaning. Waste Disposal Regulations may apply.

Task.Action: Check that it is clear.
Inspect all valves for wear or scale deposits. Worn or damaged parts should be replaced as well as the gland seal packaging. Check for complete isolation and free movement.
Task.Notes: Graphite packaging is subject to wear. It is therefore recommended to replace such items.

Task.Action: Ensure all joint faces are clean and re-assemble using new gaskets. If the unit does not restart and go to normal operation, then the electrodes may be too badly deteriorated to be reused and the cylinder must be replaced.

Put back into service and check:
  • water level in gauge glass corresponds with indicator plate
  • ball valve operates correctly
  • controls and indicator lights function properly.
Check the function of the switch-off devices, e.g. the max hygrostat.

Introduction.Content:
In hard water areas maintenance may require to be carried out more frequently. If output is decreased due to heavy scaling renewal of the cylinder will be required, refer to client.

Persons responsible for maintenance should record who the competent persons responsible for maintenance are, tests and results, routine maintenance, cleaning and disinfection dates, as per the HSE’s Code of Practice L8.

High water conductivity in the boiler circulated water can damage the boiler cylinder vessel, only work within the boiler manufacturers values of conductivity.

Any action taken should conform to the HSE requirements.  The control of Legionella bacteria in water systems – ACOP L8, 2013 (www.hse.gov.uk) and HEVAC Association code of best practice 4 commissioning and planned maintenance.

All monitoring and maintenance activity should be recorded in a log, particularly that relating to Legionella monitoring and control.

Task.Action: Check and isolate both water and electricity supplies.
Task.Notes: Electrical isolation should meet HSAWA (www.hse.gov.uk) safety requirements.

Task.Action: Check all electrical connections on the cylinder for soundness and correct any defects. If the electrodes are deteriorated, replace the steam cylinder.
As per manufacturer's instructions.
Task.Notes: Cylinder exchange times will vary - hard water areas 3 months. Soft water areas 12 months. The procedure for changing a cylinder can be found in the manufacturer’s manual, but also if the cylinder is to be re-used check that the electrodes have not rotated within the cylinder and check that the seal or “O” ring is still in place.

Task.Action: Check for free flow of water by operating the pump. Repair any gland leaks. Check manual drain switch actuation.
Task.Notes: This may require the removal of the cylinder.

Task.Action: Check for free flow, actuate drain if necessary.
Task.Notes: This may require the removal of the cylinder.

Task.Action: Clean strainer. Disconnect the water supply and remove the fill valve from the humidifier. Remove the inlet strainer. Clean the fill valve and inlet strainer using the same solution as used to clean the steam cylinder.
Task.Notes: Always replace the strainer after cleaning to prevent material lodging in the valve.

Task.Action: Set the controls to 'start' and operate humidifier in its normal mode and ensure the functions are correct and humidistat is functioning.
Task.Notes: Ensure all electrical and mechanical covers are in their correct places.

Task.Action: Check output modulation.

Introduction.Content:
This schedule should be read in conjunction with those on air compressors and pressure Regulations may apply.

Any action taken should conform to the HSE.  The control of Legionella bacteria in water systems – ACOP L8, 2013 and HSG274 part 3 (www.hse.gov.uk) and HEVAC Association code of best practice 4 commissioning and planned maintenance.

Systems that generate an aerosol must be tested for Legionella every six months. In certain applications, such as food retailers, it is recommended the same water is also tested for E.Coli and coliform bacteria.

Where systems do not incorporate some of the design features outlined above, or where ambient temperatures exceed 20°C, or where the risk of aerosol inhalation or infection is greater, more regular sampling will be required. These might be using Dipslides for TVC, or more frequent testing for Legionella.

Persons responsible for maintenance should record who the competent persons responsible for maintenance are, water sampling frequency, tests and results, routine maintenance, cleaning and disinfection dates and details, as per the HSC’s Code of Practice L8.

All monitoring and maintenance activity should be recorded in a log, particularly that relating to Legionella monitoring and control.

Task.Action: Check (visually) inlet and outlet compressed air and water supply pressures, visual inspection of the compressed air filter to check on air quality, and visual inspection of the sprays.
Inspection of the compressed air filter to check on air quality, and visual inspection of the sprays.
Task.Notes: Electrical isolation should meet HSAWA (www.hse.gov.uk) requirements.

Task.Action: Clean dust and debris from outside of nozzles.
Task.Notes: It is advisable to remove the air caps annually to clean thoroughly. Take care not to damage the protective PTFE coating.

Task.Action: Inspect and replace strainer screen.
Check condition and carry out maintenance in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.
Task.Notes:
Items which may need periodic maintenance include:
  • 2-way air solenoid valve
  • 3-way water solenoid valve
  • air pressure regulator.

Task.Action: Water line components in the control panel are subject to greater wear and tear particularly in hard water areas, and sediment filter elements prior to the control panel should be changed.

Airline components in the control panel, such as pressure regulators, pressure switches and solenoid valves, will require annual inspection and cleaning. According to compressed air quality, air filters immediately prior to the control panel will need cleaning or replacement between six months and a year.
Change UV lamps.
Task.Notes: Weekly inspection of UV-lamp operation is recommended, although many compressed air systems using this technology incorporate failsafe systems to shut down the humidifier in the event of reduced effectiveness or failure.

Introduction.Content:
Any action taken must conform to the HSE requirements.  The control of Legionella bacteria in water systems – ACOP L8 and HSG274 part 3 (www.hse.gov.uk) and HEVAC Association code of best practice 4 commissioning and planned maintenance.

Systems that generate an aerosol must be tested for Legionella every six months. In certain applications, such as food retailers, it is recommended the same water is also tested for E.Coli and coliform bacteria.

Where systems do not incorporate some of the design features outlined above, or where ambient temperatures exceed 20°C, or where the risk of aerosol inhalation or infection is greater, more regular sampling will be required. These might be using Dipslides for TVC, or more frequent testing for Legionella.

Persons responsible for maintenance should record who the competent persons responsible for maintenance are, water sampling frequency, tests and results, routine maintenance, cleaning and disinfection dates and details, as per the HSC’s Code of Practice L8.

All monitoring and maintenance activity should be recorded in a log, particularly that relating to Legionella monitoring and control.

Task.Action: Clean out and refill.
Task.Notes: Unlike the humidifiers that boil water, water droplets can contain any impurities that are in the reservoir, including minerals from hard water (which then forms a difficult to remove white dust on nearby objects and furniture), and pathogens growing in a stagnant water tank.

Task.Action: Remove as necessary from top of reservoir.
Isolate electrically and hydraulically.
Task.Notes: Electrical isolation must meet HSAWA requirements.

Task.Action: Clean carefully with soft non-scratch cloth.

Check lamps to ensure the effectiveness of the lamp.
Change lamps where necessary.
Task.Notes: UVC lamps in general have a life of approximately 8,000 hours, however due to the nature of their construction; the degradation in output accelerates towards the end of its useful life.

Task.Action: Check operational efficiency as per manufacturer's instructions. Replace if necessary.
Task.Notes: The life of the ultra sonic generator will depend on type of manufacture and the water quality.

Task.Action: Check that the alarm system (both audible and visual) works when the automatic shutdown system operates. Check that the equipment shuts down correctly and drains the water reservoir.
Carry out a full disinfection of the calorifier.
Task.Notes:
Procedure as laid down by BS 8558 and HTM 04-01 Part B.
Frequency is indicated by Risk Assessment.

Legislation.Content: HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems
HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems
HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)
HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems

Introduction.Content:
In hard water areas more frequent maintenance may be required

Any action taken should conform to the HSE requirements.  The control of Legionella bacteria in water systems – ACOP L8, 2013 and HSG274 part 3 (www.hse.gov.uk) and HEVAC Association code of best practice 4 commissioning and planned maintenance.

Persons responsible for maintenance should record who the competent persons responsible for maintenance are, water sampling frequency, tests and results, routine maintenance, cleaning and disinfection dates and details, as per the HSC’s Code of Practice L8.

All monitoring and maintenance activity should be recorded in a log, particularly that relating to Legionella monitoring and control.

Task.Action: Isolate electrically and hydraulically.

Drain.
Check all electrical connections on the cylinder for soundness and correct any defects.
Inspect and descale as necessary.
Change as necessary.

Task.Item: 5. Float valve, or solenoid valve on make-up line.
Task.Action: Check operation.

Task.Item: 6. Control indicator lights (where part of humidifier).
Task.Action: Check for correct functioning.
Check for correct operation.

Introduction.Content:
All actions should conform with HSE requirements, L8 ACOP and HEVAC Association code of best practice 4 commissioning and planned maintenance.

Before chemical disinfection is carried out it is essential that the system is clean and it is important to ensure that all parts of the system are disinfected, not just those which are readily accessible.

Building occupants should be warned that the water is heavily chlorinated. If tanks and calorifiers are heavily contaminated by organic materials, the system should be disinfected before cleaning to reduce risks to cleaning staff and also after cleaning. It may be necessary to add chemical dispersants to remove organic fouling from pipework etc. and chemical descaling may also be necessary. Where possible, cleaning methods should not create an aerosol.

Persons responsible for maintenance should record who the competent persons responsible for maintenance are, water sampling frequency, tests and results, routine maintenance, cleaning and disinfection dates and details, as per the HSCs Code of Practice L8.

All monitoring and maintenance activity should be recorded in a log, particularly that relating to Legionella monitoring and control.

Task.Action: Isolate electrically and hydraulically, if not already isolated.
Task.Notes: Isolation of electrical supply should be in accordance with HSAWA (www.hse.gov.uk) requirements.

Task.Action: Allow humidity water to drain, remove solid debris with `wet and dry` vacuum cleaner.
Check condition and repaint as necessary, Check integrity of in-fill humidifier medium and replace if worn, damaged or heavily scaled.

Refill system with clean fresh water, disinfect system with addition of sodium hypochlorite solution to achieve free residual chlorine reserve of 50 mg/l, maintain circulation for one hour ensuring the level does not drop below 30 mg/l after one hour.
Task.Notes: Ensure drain valve closed during refill. Free chlorine is rapidly absorbed by organic matter and partially lost when the chlorinated water cascades through the infill matter, thus further additions of sodium hypochlorite may be required to maintain the free chlorine reserve at 50mg/litre.

Task.Action: Drain and thoroughly flush the sump and operate the pumps for a further 15 minutes. Drain sump, test to ensure that residual chlorine has dropped to below 0.5 mg/l. Refill sump if unit to be put back into service immediately.
Task.Notes: Particular attention is required if water used for disinfection is of a high pH (over 7.3pH) as this will reduce the effective chlorine.
