Introduction.Content:
Personnel carrying out leak checking, gas recovery or other refrigerant handling activities such as plant installation and maintenance must have a suitable refrigerant handling qualification. These works are covered under the current F-Gas regulations on fluorinated gases.

Check for leaks should be part of the routine servicing. “Checked for Leakage” means that the joints, valves including stems, seals, including seals on replaceable driers and filters, parts of the system subject to vibration, connections to safety or operational devices of the equipment or system is examined for leakage using direct or indirect measuring methods, focusing on those parts of the equipment or system most likely to leak. The frequency of testing depends on refrigerant charge and system type.

Systems containing:
<3 kg no leak test required
3 kg to 30 kg annual leak test required
30 kg to 300 kg half yearly leak test required and
>300 kg quarterly leak test required.

Hermetically Sealed Systems:
<6 kg no leak test required
6 kg to 30 kg annual leak test required
30 kg to 300 kg half yearly leak test required and
>300 kg quarterly leak test required.

These applications must also be checked for leakage within one month after a leak has been repaired to ensure that the repair has been effective.

Plants with more than 300 kg must be fitted with a leakage detection system, which is defined as: “a calibrated mechanical, electrical or electronic device for detecting leakage of refrigerants which, on detection, alerts the operator”. The detection system must be checked at least once a year to ensure proper functioning in line with manufacturers’ recommendations.

For any plant fitted with a leakage detection system (including those below the mandatory 300 kg threshold), the frequency of leak checking can be halved, although an annual check remains the minimum frequency.

ALWAYS UPDATE RECORDS.

Task.Action:
Personnel carrying out leak checking, gas recovery or other refrigerant handling activities such as plant installation and maintenance must have a suitable refrigerant handling qualification.

These works are covered under the current F-Gas regulations on fluorinated gases.
Task.Notes:
Check for leaks should be part of the routine servicing by Refrigeration Engineers. 

Where a system has a refrigerant charge greater than 300kg, an automatic leak detection system must be installed on the system to comply with the F-Gas Regulations.

Task.Action: Check for refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for refrigerant leaks. Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for refrigerant leaks. Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.

Check for refrigerant leaks. Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check operation and cleanliness. Test for refrigerant leaks.
Task.Notes:
Sight glasses, which should be fitted on any system, indicate refrigerant level and the presence of moisture.

Faults which may be observed are:
a) bubbles in sight glass indicating a shortage of refrigerant or a restriction in the liquid line.
b) a change in the colour of the moisture monitor from green to yellow indicates the presence of moisture in the system.

Task.Item: Superheat setting of thermostatic expansion valve (TEV)
Task.Action:
Check operation following the sequence outlined in the `notes` column. To adjust, remove valve cap at base of valve, turn adjusting stem counter clockwise to lower the superheat or clockwise to increase the superheat.

CAUTION: Only make one turn of the stem at a time.
Task.Notes:
a) Measure temperature of the suction line at the point where the TEV bulb is clamped
b) Read gauge pressure at compressor suction valve
c) Add estimated pressure drop between bulb location and suction valve
d) Convert the sum of the pressures to the equivalent temperature and subtract this from the actual suction line temperature.  This difference is the superheat. It can take thirty minutes for a new balance to be achieved.  Record new setting, it should be between 8º & 10ºC.

Task.Action: Check, if low, restore to recommended concentration.
Task.Notes: A fall in concentration may be the result of leakage and pipework should be checked.

Task.Action:
Check external condition.
Check soundness of vapour barrier and/or waterproof finish.
Check condition of flange and valve boxes including internal linings and fasteners.
Task.Notes: It cannot be stressed too heavily that ingress of water vapour has to be minimised otherwise efficiency will be reduced and energy wasted. Pay particular attention to seals round hangers and supports. Look for damage due to leaks. Check paintwork and identification bands.

Task.Action:
Inspect:

a) External condition of shell

b) Leak tightness of connections

c) Operation of valves and drains

d) Operation of float valves
Task.Notes: Many small units are sealed and the sight glass is on the oil separator.

Task.Action:
Check on operation of pressure switch contacts and re-adjust to correct operating pressures as necessary.
On completion of tests:
  • disconnect air pressure or vacuum equipment and alarm test set
  • remake electrical supply and alarm cables
  • test functionally
  • return to service.
Task.Notes:
Apply correct pressure or vacuum reading to coincide with pressure switch operating limits, note pressure or vacuum reading at which pressure switch contacts make on both upper and lower limits. 
Pressure switch isolation valves to be opened, where fitted.

Legislation.Content: F-Gas Regulation No. 517/2014 on fluorinated gases

Introduction.Content:
Room air conditioners [unitary reverse cycle heat pump terminal units with electrical heating and reversing valve]

Personnel carrying out leak checking, gas recovery or other refrigerant handling activities such as plant installation and maintenance must have a suitable refrigerant handling qualification. These works are covered under the current F-Gas regulations on fluorinated gases.

Check for leaks should be part of the routine servicing. “Checked for Leakage” means that the joints, valves including stems, seals, including seals on replaceable driers and filters, parts of the system subject to vibration, connections to safety or operational devices of the equipment or system is examined for leakage using direct or indirect measuring methods, focusing on those parts of the equipment or system most likely to leak. The frequency of testing depends on refrigerant charge and system type.

Systems containing:
<3 kg no leak test required
3 kg to 30 kg annual leak test required
30 kg to 300 kg half yearly leak test required and
>300 kg quarterly leak test required.

Hermetically Sealed Systems:
<6 kg no leak test required
6 kg to 30 kg annual leak test required
30 kg to 300 kg half yearly leak test required and
>300 kg quarterly leak test required.

These applications must also be checked for leakage within one month after a leak has been repaired to ensure that the repair has been effective.

Plants with more than 300 kg must be fitted with a leakage detection system, which is defined as: “a calibrated mechanical, electrical or electronic device for detecting leakage of refrigerants which, on detection, alerts the operator”. The detection system must be checked at least once a year to ensure proper functioning in line with manufacturers’ recommendations.

For any plant fitted with a leakage detection system (including those below the mandatory 300 kg threshold), the frequency of leak checking can be halved, although an annual check remains the minimum frequency.

ScheduleGroups.ScheduleGroup: 8.6.1 Surface water and foul water drainage

Introduction.Content:
This subject comes within the scope of the HSE Guidance Notes PM60, L101 and PM5.

 

Great care must be taken when entering brick or concrete drainage pits because of the possible presence of harmful gases.  They must be vented to ensure the chamber cannot be pressurised over 0.1 bar g. (1.5 psig).

 

Where entry into confined spaces is necessary, compliance with (www.hse.gov.uk) Guidance note L101 Safe Work in confined spaces 1997 Approved code of practice, regulations and guidance 2nd edition (2009) and INDG 258 Work in confined spaces - is required.

 

Staff training must be up to date.

Task.Action:
At every thorough examination of the associated steam boilers, or at such intervals determined by the competent person, the blowdown pit should be positively isolated (i.e. double shut-off or by blank flange) from the boiler(s) for examination purposes.

 

The electrical supply to the automated intermittent blowdown should be locked off and, where fitted, any compressed-air system should be isolated and de-pressurised.

 

The pit should then be drained, thoroughly cleaned out and examined.

 

If the quality of the boiler feedwater is poor, the blowdown pit may require draining and/or cleaning more often.
Task.Notes: This work must only be carried out by a competent person and appropriate safety precautions must be observed. The work may be carried out at the same time as the boiler inspection.

Task.Action: Check condition and security.
Task.Notes: Some pits may be fenced and if so the fencing should be checked and made good if necessary.

Task.Action: Check condition and ensure there is no blockage.
Task.Notes: If replacement or repair necessary, advise the client.

Task.Action: Check hole is clear.

Task.Notes: These are pressure vessels and as such come within the scope of the Pressure Systems and Transportable Gas Containers Regulations 2000.  See also HSE document L101.

Task.Action:
At every thorough examination of the associated steam boilers, or at such intervals determined by the competent person, the blowdown tank should be positively isolated (i.e. double shut-off or by blank flange) from the boiler(s) for examination purposes.

 

The electrical supply to the automated intermittent blowdown should be locked off and, where fitted, any compressed-air system should be isolated and de-pressurised.

 

The tank should then be drained, thoroughly cleaned out and examined.

 

If the quality of the boiler feedwater is poor, the blowdown tank may require draining and/or cleaning more often.
Task.Notes: This work must only be carried out by a competent person and appropriate safety precautions must be observed.  The work is normally carried out at the same time as the boiler inspection.

Introduction.Content:
Gas detectors are specialist devices and are often designed to detect a specific gas or family of gases, e.g. propane or butane, it is essential to refer to the manufacturer's instructions before commencing any maintenance work on them.

Detailed guidance is provided for the maintenance of Gas Detectors in an explosive Atmosphere by BS EN 60079.

Task.Action: Check sensing device and where appropriate sampling system for cleanliness and possible obstructions.
Task.Notes: Refer to the manufacturer's instructions for cleaning procedures.

Task.Action: Test for correct response and operation.
Task.Notes: For Further Guidance See Fire Alarm Systems (SFG 22-01).

Task.Action:
It is assumed that the operational staff will undertake the routine visual inspections of the installation.  Before proceeding with any maintenance task, the operative is to check the faults log for any outstanding faults/conditions.

Fixed gas detectors should be included in the plant maintenance schedule.  The performance of most detectors deteriorates with time, the rate depending on the type of sensor and the operating conditions, for example a dusty, corrosive or damp environment.  These factors will affect the frequency of inspection, maintenance and calibration.

Repair or maintenance of fixed apparatus (whether incorporating single-point sensors, open path sensors, a combination of these, or sampling systems) should be carried out under a control led procedure.

Defective apparatus should be removed for repair in a workshop outside the area being protected.  If a replacement apparatus cannot be provided immediately, then transport table apparatus should be used as a temporary substitute.
Task.Notes:
Before any work is undertaken on any sensor in a hazardous area, ensure the notes in Hazardous Area (Electrics) - (SFG 27) are read and fully understood.
 
Ensure all necessary local Permit to Work procedures are fully complied with.

Legislation.Content: BS EN 60079-29-2:2007 Explosive atmospheres - Part 29-2: Gas detectors Selection, installation, use and maintenance of detectors for flammable gases and Oxygen.

Introduction.Content:
Legionellosis (Legionnaires Disease and Associated Illnesses)

Approved Code of Practice - Legionnaires disease: The control of legionella bacteria in water systems: Approved Code of Practice, L8, 2013 sets out certain statutory requirements. In particular each water system must be identified and assessed for legionellosis risk. Once a risk has been identified and assessed a scheme must be prepared for preventing or controlling it, precautions implemented and managed records kept. The L8 has a special legal status, Part 1 being regulatory and Part 2 guidance which has been replaced by a separate Technical Guidance publication, HSG274 parts 1, 2 and 3.

The client must ensure that one person of adequate status is appointed as being responsible for overseeing the assessment and implementation of the precautions. Responsibility and lines of communication must be properly defined and personnel must be properly trained.

Before carrying out the following procedures, consideration should be given to removing infrequently used showers. If they are removed, the redundant supply pipework should be cut back, as far as possible, to a common supply, for example to the recirculating pipework or the pipework supplying a more frequently used upstream fitting.

Where it is difficult to carry out weekly flushing, the stagnant and potentially contaminated water from within the shower and associated dead-leg needs to be purged to drain before the appliance is used. It is important that this procedure is carried out with minimum production of aerosols, eg.  additional piping may be used to purge contaminated water to drain.

Frequency of maintenance will depend upon use and the quality of the water and should be agreed with the client.

Task.Action:
Dismantle, clean and descale removeable parts, heads, inserts and hoses (where fitted). 
Check adjustable sprays (if fitted).
Quarterly or as necessary.
Task.Notes:
Take care not to damage spray outlet holes. More often in hard water areas.

Frequency is quarterly or as indicated by the rate of fouling or other risk factors eg.  areas with high risk patients.

Task.Action:
Dismantle, clean jet heads and descale body jets.
Adjust water flow rates.
Quarterly or as necessary.
Task.Notes: More often in hard water areas.

Task.Action:
Dismantle, clean and descale hoses.
Check joints and flexible covering for damage.
Quarterly or as necessary.
Task.Notes: Report to client if replacement recommended. More often in hard water areas.

Task.Action:
Check for leaks on seals of doors and screens.
Rectify or replace as appropriate.
Task.Notes: Operate shower with door closed and carry out visual inspection.

Task.Action: Clean and unblock waste outlet trap as necessary.
Task.Notes: If possible fit top access waste trap. More frequent maintenance may be necessary depending upon frequency of use.

Task.Item: 3. Internal Surfaces; Tiles and Silicone Joints.
Task.Action:
Check internal surfaces for cracks in the tiles or grouting.
Check all silicone joints and seals.
Rake out damaged grout or silicone and repair as necessary.
Task.Notes: Generally, the day to day cleaning of the internal surfaces should be undertaken by the clients staff. Cracks or chips in the surfaces can be a breeding ground for bacteria.

HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems
HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems
HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)

In particular each water system must be identified and assessed for legionellosis risk. Task.Action: Check for damage and clean.

Check condition of local isolator, open and clean if required.
Remove motor terminal covers, check connections for tightness and terminal block for damage or dampness.

Carry out the following tests to all pumps and record results:
a.  Insulation resistance test on wiring and motors
b.  Earth loop impedance test on case or frame of units
c.  Load test on motors (start and run current).

Compare results with manufacturer’s specification.
Check that power lead at motor are undamaged and are securely held.
Clean and check.
Check for wear and movement out of position. Replace as necessary.
Check operation.
Task.Notes: The two switches fitted to a twin impeller pump for separate hot and cold water supplies should be checked separately.

Task.Notes: Air switches should be used only where a low static head is present.

Task.Action: Remove, clean and descale. Replace as necessary.
Check clearance round pump for proper motor ventilation.

Introduction.Content: In many shopping malls, warehouses, staircases and other similar areas openable ventilators are installed to relieve smoke natural vents and/or to provide natural ventilation. The actual fire prevention equipment does not come within the scope of this document and its maintenance should be carried out by specialist contractors.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Smoke Relief - Powered Smoke and Heat Exhaust Ventilators

Introduction.Content: Frequency of maintenance and testing for smoke relief ventilators should conform to BS EN 12101-3:2002 Smoke and heat control systems and should be in accordance with local authority requirements.

Task.Action: Isolate in accordance with HSAWA safety requirements. Refer to www.hse.gov.uk for detail.
Task.Notes: Ensure client is aware that system or part of system is inoperative during execution of maintenance.

Task.Action: See Filters SFG 21.

Check condition and clean all dirt from internal and external weathering channels and surfaces of the ventilator (take precautions to prevent inhalation of bird droppings - COSHH Regulations) with stiff (not wire) brush.
Clean impeller and rotor and check ease of rotation and correct direction of rotation.
Task.Notes: It is important to check for correct clearance between fan shrouds and impeller.  (See also Motors SFG 39)

Task.Action: Check fan inlet and discharge are unobstructed.
Check and adjust for correct operation.

Check:

a) spray nozzles are clean and undamaged

b) cleanliness

c) that water system is available at the required pressure.

Clean strainer where fitted.
Test weekly and record same as required by BS 7346.
Task.Notes: Ensure client is aware that system or part of system is inoperative during execution of maintenance.

Task.Notes: See Control panel and controllers SFG 14 for detailed maintenance.

Task.Notes: Only use lubricant as recommended by manufacturer. Report to client if repairs or replacement required.

Task.Notes: Only use lubricant as recommended by manufacturer.

Task.Notes: The client should carry out this task as part of their fire alarm testing once every week to ensure that the system integrity is maintained.  See Pipework systems SFG40-08

Check and note incoming voltage to controls.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Solar Hot Water Panels and Similar Collecting Devices

Introduction.Content: Working at heights should be in strict accordance with the Work at Height Regulations 2005.

Task.Item: Plate Type Collectors. 1. Glass cover plate.
Task.Action: Check condition and clean all dirt from surfaces of the unit (take precautions to prevent inhalation of bird droppings - COSHH Regulations) with stiff (not wire) brush.  Report condition if cracked.  A safe method of gaining height may be required; operatives are to be fully trained.
Task.Notes: Frequency will depend on location and local atmospheric condition. Dirt causes loss of collector efficiency. Cracked glass should be replaced.

Task.Action: Check condition and make good if necessary.
Task.Notes: Poor seals lead to internal condensation and loss of efficiency. If there are signs of internal algae growth on underside of glass plate, it should be removed, cleaned and resealed. Care should be taken not to damage absorber plate as it may have a special coating.

Task.Action: Check condition and top up to required concentration.
Task.Notes: Anti-freeze solution should be replaced every three years.

Task.Action: Check operation of thermostat and pump control.
Task.Notes: For more detailed maintenance of controls see relevant sections.

Task.Action: Check for leaks and signs of corrosion and make good as necessary.
Replace anti-freeze solution.

Check condition and clean all dirt from surfaces of the tubes (take precautions to prevent inhalation of bird droppings - COSHH Regulations) with stiff (not wire) brush.  Report condition if cracked.  A safe method of gaining height may be required; operatives are to be fully trained.
Task.Notes: Frequency will depend on location and local atmospheric condition. Dirt causes loss of collector efficiency. Cracked tubes should be replaced.

Task.Action: A safe method of gaining height may be required; operatives are to be fully trained.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Split Systems/Heat Pumps - Air-Cooled with Direct Expansion Evaporator (DX)

Introduction.Content:
Engineers working on these systems must belong to an approved Certified Scheme provider, in accordance with the "F" Gas and Building Regulations.

Check for leaks should be part of the routine servicing. Checked for leakage means that the joints, valves including stems, seals, including seals on replaceable driers and filters, parts of the system subject to vibration, connections to safety or operational devices of the equipment or system is examined for leakage using direct or indirect measuring methods, focusing on those parts of the equipment or system most likely to leak. The frequency of testing depends on refrigerant charge and system type.

Systems containing: <3 kg no leak test required, 3 kg to 30 kg annual leak test required, 30 kg to 300 kg half yearly leak test required and >300 kg quarterly leak test required.
Hermetically sealed systems: <6 kg no leak test required, 6 kg to 30 kg annual leak test required, 30 kg to 300 kg half yearly leak test required and >300 kg quarterly leak test required.

These applications must also be checked for leakage within one month after a leak has been repaired to ensure that the repair has been effective.

Plants with more than 300 kg must be fitted with a leakage detection system, which is defined as: a calibrated mechanical, electrical or electronic device for detecting leakage of refrigerants which, on detection, alerts the operator. The detection system must be checked at least once a year to ensure proper functioning in line with manufacturers recommendations.

For any plant fitted with a leakage detection system (including those below the mandatory 300 kg threshold), the frequency of leak checking can be halved, although an annual check remains the minimum frequency.

Task.Action: Check for undue noise or vibration. Check discharge and suction pressure and check superheat under full load condition.
Check for symptoms of 'wet' operation or excessive superheat.
Service providers must be registered to an approved Certified Scheme provider, in accordance with the "F" Gas and Building Regulations.
Check level in receiver and/or liquid line sight glass.
Task.Notes: Any shortfall or frequent topping up may indicate leakage and must be reported to the client.

Task.Action:
Personnel carrying out leak checking, gas recovery or other refrigerant handling activities such as plant installation and maintenance must have a suitable refrigerant handling qualification.

These works are covered under the current F-Gas regulations on fluorinated gases.

ALWAYS UPDATE RECORDS.
Task.Notes:
Check for leaks should be part of the routine servicing by Refrigeration Engineers.
 
Where a system has a refrigerant charge greater than 300kg, an automatic leak detection system must be installed on the system to comply with the F-Gas Regulations.

Task.Action: Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for damage and/or dust accumulation. Clean and comb coil fins, vacuum unit internally.
Task.Notes: Do not use refrigerant for cleaning tubes, use dry nitrogen or compressed air.  Sterilisation may be required.  Where Oxygen Free Nitrogen is used, a Risk Assessment must be carried out prior to use and suitable training given.

Task.Action: Check all nuts, (including holding down bolts) bolts, setscrews, etc. for security.  Check any drip tray for blockage/leaks etc.  Remove any debris and clean.

Task.Item: Fans and motors and damper drive motors (if fitted)
Task.Action: Check bearings and lubricate as necessary. Inspect and check on fan guard covers and inspection plates.
Task.Notes: Where appropriate check drive belts for condition and tension.  Adjust or replace as necessary. Ensure that all bolts, screws etc. are in place and tight.

Task.Item: Evaporator and drains, drip tray and pump
Task.Action: Check, flush and clean.  Check condensate drain is clear and clean.  Check operation of condensate pump (if fitted).
Task.Notes: Sterilisation of drip tray and drain may be required.

Task.Item: Compressor capacity control and unloaded start valves (if fitted)
Task.Action: Check for correct operation.  Check motor current against commissioning data or nameplate.
Task.Notes: Compressor unload on start should reduce and increase capacity on demand.

Task.Action: Check entire refrigerant pipework run.  Ensure pipes are secure, not sagging, and are in good repair.
Task.Notes: All pipework joints should be brazed or welded.  To prevent internal scaling, use dry, oxygen free, nitrogen (OFN) during the jointing process.  A Risk Assessment must be done prior to use.

Task.Action: Check condition and replace as necessary.
Task.Notes: Frequency to be determined depending on conditions.  It is however important to clean the filter prior to it becoming clogged.  This can affect the energy efficiency of the unit by as much as 10% and can also allow dirt to become clogged into the evaporator coil.

Task.Action: Check condition.  Repair and reseal as necessary.

Clean surfaces of compressor and components of condensing unit particularly fan impeller and motor casing.  Check and clean surfaces of unit casing, check for corrosion, repair and treat as found necessary.
Task.Notes: Remove any dirt or rubbish from vicinity of plant.

Task.Action: Check for satisfactory operation of local electrical isolation device (stoplock/isolator).  Examine and report condition of all associated wiring, ensure security of all terminal connections and check for satisfactory condition of any flexible cables/conduits.  Ensure plant has adequate earth conductor and bonding is secure.
Task.Notes: If main fuse carrier connections to compressors show any discoloration they must be changed.  Pay particular attention to contactors and terminals including all thermistor controls in compressor terminal box.

Task.Action: Check function and operation of all automatic sensors/detectors (flow/temperature).  Check for correct operation/shut-down of plant.  Ensure all devices are returned to their correct settings.  Clean air inlet & discharge grilles.  Check all access doors for fit and can be made secure.  When shut, ensure for air tight seal.  Check that unit is maintaining space conditions.
Task.Notes: i.e. Start/stops and capacity regulators should be in accordance with externally applied control systems if applicable.

Task.Action: See relevant Burner (SFG 07).
See relevant Heat Emitter (SFG 28).  Check for leaks.  Check anti-freeze protection on heating coil.
Check for symptoms of wet operation or excessive superheat.
Check operation of reversing valve to ensure the unit switches over affectively, from heating to cooling and back.
Confirm that it is in accordance with design parameters.
Task.Notes: i.e. Start/stops and capacity regulators should be in accordance with externally applied control systems if applicable.

Legislation.Content: Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995
F-Gas Regulation No. 517/2014 on fluorinated gases
HSE The Gas Safety (Management) Regulations 1996
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)

Check.

Check and set.

Task.Notes: Ensure arc chutes are precisely repositioned otherwise the moving parts of the contactor may be impeded and damage caused to the contacts, insulation and the chutes themselves.

Task.Action:
Check that air seals are intact.
Renew unit if leaks are evident.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Cold Water Storage Tanks and Cisterns

Introduction.Content:
Approved Code of Practice - Legionnaires disease

 The control of legionella bacteria in water systems:  Approved Code of Practice, L8, 2013 sets out certain statutory requirements.  In particular each water system must be identified and assessed for legionellosis risk.  Once a risk has been identified and assessed a scheme must be prepared for preventing or controlling it, precautions implemented and managed records kept.  The L8 has a special legal status, Part 1 being regulatory and Part 2 guidance which has been replaced by a separate Technical Guidance publication, HSG274 parts 1, 2 and 3.

The client must ensure that one person of adequate status is appointed as being responsible for overseeing the assessment and implementation of the precautions.  Responsibility and lines of communication must be properly defined and personnel must be properly trained.

Guidance note L101 Safe work in confined spaces 1997.  Approved code of practice, regulations and guidance 3rd edition (2014).

Whilst legionella bacteria are most active in the temperature range 20°C to 45°C, occasions can occur where growth is promoted even in cold water systems.  This can arise where the local temperature is raised by:

a) heat build up due to solar gain or the proximity to hot water services, or
b) the storage capacity is far greater than is necessary.  In general terms the storage capacity should not exceed one day's usage.
c) seasonal variations.  In the summertime it is not unusual to have incoming mains supplies exceeding 20°C.  When this occurs the systems should be reassessed with the likely outcome of increasing regular flushing to these outlets in a safe manner with minimal aerosolation.

Cleanliness of the system is of primary importance to ensure that the legionella bacteria do not have any nutrients for growth and survival.  Such nutrients can come from vegetable, animal and even mineral substances and it is for this reason that storage cisterns must be free from rust, dust, slime, mould, fungi and such items as dead birds, rats, mice, insects etc. and that non metallic materials satisfy the requirements of BS (http://www.bsi-global.com) 6920.  Lists of materials approved by the water industry (WRAS) are published in the Water Fittings and Materials Directory (see Standards List).  All new and replacement water fittings must satisfy Water Supply (water fittings) Regulations 1999 requirements and be listed in the WRAS directory (WRAS Simple Steps to Approval).

Cleansing of tanks, cisterns and associated pipework must be followed by full disinfection in accordance with the procedures laid down in BS 6700 Rev 2006 [partially superseded by BS EN 806-4:2010] and as per chemical manufacturers specification.

Cisterns must have close fitting lids, which should not be of timber or other porous materials.  Lids must have vent pipes of adequate cross section to prevent suction developing on water draw off.  All vent pipes and overflows must be fitted with close mesh to prevent the ingress of foreign matter.  These must be checked annually and cleaned if necessary.

The pipework system must be free of any points where pockets of dirt, slime or sediment can build up.

The need for full disinfection of Cisterns and associated down services is outlined in HSE's L8 Guidance page 53 paragraph 190 and HSG274 part 2, page 42.



WARNING: Subject to age, there are still many items lagged with Asbestos, if uncertain - STOP WORK.  A Certified Test Result MUST be obtained prior to consideration to proceed.

Task.Action: Check for adequate water level and, where provided, check tank warning pipe for signs of discharge.  Inspect tank for evidence of leaks and corrosion.
Check operation, water level and shut off.  Replace washer and/or defective parts if necessary.  Check float for leakage and security.
Check for scale deposits, clean as necessary and check function and operation of level switches, by simulating water level condition, ensure correct operation of associated plant.
Task.Notes: For specialist maintenance of level control switches.  See Switches (SFG 58).

Task.Action: Check for leaks and any structural weaknesses.
Task.Notes: Ensure that any brackets, etc. supporting the tank are firmly fixed.

Task.Action:
Note settings of tank valves (excluding DRV's).  Check, rotate handwheel sufficiently to indicate that wedge is not seized in closed position nor jammed in open position.  If normally open, close valve and reopen. 
When fully open, close valve ½ turn to ensure valve does not jam.
Task.Notes: Ensure that any insulation or trace heating cable removed during inspection is replaced or frost damage could ensue.  See Valves (SFG 61).

Task.Action: Check tank air vents are clean and unobstructed, where filters are provided remove, clean and/or replace as found necessary.
Task.Notes: Clean when necessary.  Report if replacement needed.

Task.Action: Check condition, replace if necessary.
Task.Notes: Look for any damp patches, if necessary removing insulation to find cause.

Task.Action: Check condition of seals.  Check lids, inspection cover(s) etc. can be correctly located and made secure.
Task.Notes: If lid has been removed for inspection purposes ensure seals are effective.

Task.Action:
All cold water storage cisterns and cold feed cisterns must be examined at least annually, paying particular attention to the presence of foreign objects, biological material and excessive corrosion.

On completion of the examinations, the cisterns should be cleaned, if required, and any remedial work carried out.

Before the cisterns and system are put back into use, they should be disinfected in accordance with BS 8558:2011.

Carry out full biological testing of water and report. 
Check atmosphere within tank prior to entry.
Task.Notes:
Check overflow and warning pipes are unobstructed, sized correctly and that the ends are conspicuous and well above the flood over level of a gully and conform to the water regulations.  If any remedial work needs to be carried out, advise client.  If painting is required, any paint should be non-toxic and WRC Water Byelaws Scheme/Water Supply (water fittings) Regulations 1999 WRAS approved. 

SEE HTM 04-01 Part A chapter 17.

All cisterns should be internally cleaned to remove all visible dirt and debris.  Cisterns and distributing pipework should be drained, filled with fresh water and then drained completely.  The cisterns should then be refilled and the supply servicing valves closed. 

On re-fitting it is normal practice to add high doses of sodium hypochlorite to the water in the cisterns, for example to give a calculated chlorine concentration of 50 ± 10 mg/L (ppm) in the water, and leave the water to stand for one hour.

Whatever disinfection method is used, the concentration should be adjusted if necessary. The use of a high dose ensures an adequate residual concentration to allow proper disinfection of the downstream services.  Each tap or fitting should then be opened, progressively away from the cisterns, and water discharged until the disinfectant is detected.  Each tap or fitting should then be closed, and the cistern and pipes left charged for a further hour.  The tap(s) furthermost from the cisterns should be opened, and the level of disinfectant in the water discharged from the taps measured. 
If the levels set are not achieved, the disinfection process should be repeated.

Task.Action: Check and record in logbook for water hygiene the incoming feed to the cistern storage at the ball valve and remote from the ball valve (that is farthest away from the incoming supply within the cistern) once in the summer and once in the winter.
Task.Notes: Ensure temperature at ball valve is less than 3C of the incoming supply to the building and similarly storage is less than 3C from ball valve.  Note maximum temperatures recorded by fixed max/min thermometers where fitted.

Task.Action: Ensure drains are clear and check condition.
Task.Notes: Check thoroughly for potential leakage.  Report to client.

Task.Action: Check condition and rectify any faults.
Task.Notes: Examine for corrosion, leaks and security of fittings and attachments.

Task.Action: Check that all items of equipment comply with Legislation and guidance (L8), HTM 04-01 (NHS), WRAS the Water Supply (water fittings) Regulations 1999.
Task.Notes: Report to client where remedial action is required.

Task.Action:
Where pipework, fittings or appliances are to be replaced, continuity of earthing and equipotential bonding shall be maintained. 

Where pipework has been used for earthing, alternative earthing arrangements shall be made in accordance with BS 7430 by a competent person. 

Where there is no evidence of main equipotential bonding, which may be required, the installer should inform the responsible person that any bonding should be checked and remedied where necessary by a competent person.

Legislation.Content: HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems
BS EN 806-5:2012 Specifications for installations inside buildings conveying water for human consumption. Operation and Maintenance
HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)
HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems
Water Supply (Water Fittings) Regulations 1999
HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems

Introduction.Content:
Further guidance available CIBSE TM 18.


Air conditioning systems incorporating ice storage can need less general maintenance than conventional systems.  However, they normally have heat exchangers and some additional instrumentation (flow meters etc.) and controls requiring maintenance.  The tasks below should be supplemented by those given from the specific manufacturer/supplier of the store and the complexity of the particular system.

Care should be taken to prevent a control malfunction that would allow a total 'freeze solid' condition to occur at the ice store.  Primary to secondary heat exchangers should be thoroughly tested especially in respect of low-temperature protection of secondary circuits.

Task.Action: Check percentage of glycol concentration in circuit.
Task.Notes: Correct as necessary.  If checks show continual need for topping up Specific Gravity, examine system for leaks.

Task.Action: Check operation of all isolating and control valves.
Check and log flow rates and pressure drops at appropriate loads and conditions and check against commissioning data.
Check operation of pumps.
Task.Notes: Take account of density of the secondary coolant.  See Pumps SFG 45.

Task.Action: Check that the flow and return temperatures across the ice store are being achieved in both ice charge and discharge modes.
Check control set points for correct values and operation.
Check correct level of water in storage container.
Check ice inventory device is correctly calibrated and operating to ensure correct glycol concentration levels.
Check that all temperatures, pressures, flow rates etc. are being received.
Check all insulation is in place.
Task.Notes: Check to ensure the full record of operating conditions over a period of time is being saved.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Task.Notes: Should any pipework be removed during maintenance and/or repairs, ensure that it is reinstated paying special attention to the quality of the vapour sealing.  The system will need to be dried out prior to being reinsulated to avoid sealing in moisture which could corrode pipework.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Check normal position.
Task.Notes: Condition of tanks is the responsibility of the gas supplier who will also check safety protection.

Task.Action: Check normal position.
Check action.
Check action.
Check change over.

Legislation.Content: Pressure Systems Safety Regulations 2000
Provision and Use of Work Equipment Regulations 1998 (PUWER)
Dangerous Substances & Explosive Atmospheres Regulation (DSEAR) 2002 HSE L136
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)

Introduction.Content:
The Control of Pollution (Oil Storage) (England) Regulations set minimum standards. They do not change other legislation under which it is an offence to cause water pollution.  Variations in local conditions may mean more stringent standards are needed to prevent pollution.

If there is a spill, immediate action must be taken to stop the oil getting into any drains or watercourses.  Soak up the spilt oil with the contents of the spill kit in accordance with the risk assessment.  Don’t hose the spillage down or use any detergents to try to get rid of it.  Notify the Environment Agency by calling their Emergency Hotline.

If oil soaks into the ground, the soil soaked in oil should be removed, by a specialist company.  Store any materials that are soaked in oil in containers that won’t let the oil run away until it can be correctly and legally disposed of.

In addition to the tasks there are daily and weekly operational tasks to be carried out including visual checks of the oil tanks, pipework and bund.  Please also see the section below [Bund - 3 monthly] which refers to the removal of rain water.  This must be done every time there has been heavy rainfall.

Refer to the Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH) Regulations.  Staff to be competent and fully trained in COSHH.  Risk Assessment/Method Statement requirements must be carried out before the work starts and a method statement produced.

Refer to www.hse.gov.uk for details.

Task.Item: Bulk Oil Storage (Heavy and Medium Oils)
Bulk Oil Storage (Heavy and Medium Oils)
Task.Action:
If there is a spill, immediate action must be taken to stop the oil getting into any drains or watercourses.  Soak up the spilt oil with the contents of the spill kit in accordance with the risk assessment.  Don’t hose the spillage down or use any detergents to try to get rid of it. 

Notify the Environment Agency by calling their Emergency Hotline.
Look for leakage and spillage from the tank resulting from filling or failure of tank soundness.
Remove and clean.

In addition to the tasks there are daily and weekly operational tasks to be carried out including visual checks of the oil tanks, pipework and bund. 

Please also see the section below (Bund - 3 Monthly) which refers to the removal of rain water.  This must be done every time there has been heavy rainfall.
Check operation and freedom of movement.  Moving parts should be lightly oiled or greased.

Refer to the Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH) Regulations. Staff to be Competent and fully trained in COSHH. 

Risk Assessment/Method Statement requirements must be carried out before the work starts and a method statement produced.
Check and log oil level.  Log also any inspections, any repair work on the tanks and who has done the works.
Dip tank to ensure gauge is working.

Check valves are locked.
Check the hand wheels have not been removed (vandalism/theft).
Pipework should be checked for leaks, corrosion, missing brackets etc. 
Check any trace heating and insulation is in place and working where appropriate.

Check that the notice showing the product type, tank capacity and, where appropriate, tank number is clearly visible – clean or replace as necessary. 

Check all notices are clearly visible and  warn that all valves must be locked when not in use.

Bunds should be inspected regularly for signs of damage, e.g. missing bricks in walls and water in the bund. 
Inspect closely where any draw off/feed lines pass through the bund wall to ensure it remains fully sealed to retain oil. 
Check that any trigger guns and hoses are being kept within the bund or the secure cabinet, which should be locked shut when not in use.
Task.Notes:
Checked visually by the operator at least weekly or after any heavy rainfall. Open bund - check the bund after heavy rainfall.

If there’s no rainwater in the bund, it might not be sealed properly and you should have it inspected and repaired.
Where rain water has collected in the bund, it will reduce the amount of oil it can contain.

To remove accumulated rainwater, use a manually operated pump or by bailing from the sump. 
Any accumulated water, oil or debris should be removed and disposed of in line with waste management legislation.

In all cases where wastes are removed, as the waste producer, you are obliged under Waste management, the Duty of Care, a code of practice to describe the waste accurately and dispose of it properly.


Guidance on the disposal of condensate and bund water - Joint OFTEC/WaterUK/Environment Agency/ SEPA publication.

Task.Action: Check that the device sounds the alarm, shows the visual warning or automatically stops the delivery whatever applies.

Check that the lockable fill cap and chain are in place and work. 
Clean the fill point drip tray.
A more detailed annual check is required by a trained operator e.g. in the OFTEC registered scheme.

Note settings of valves and take through total travel, returning to correct settings. 
Lock or remove hand wheel as appropriate. 
Pipework should be checked for leaks, corrosion, missing brackets etc.

60M Bulk Oil Storage (Heavy Oil). 
Clean tank externally, derust and paint, as found necessary. 
Place 'No Smoking' signs, drain tank, open manholes and vent tank. 

Refer to Permit to Work and Safe Systems of Work before entering tank, internally inspect, clean and repair as found necessary. Report condition before placing tank back on-line.

After maintenance inspection, close all manholes and covers, recharge tank and check for leaks.
Clean down exterior of outdoor tanks and repaint with bituminous paint.  
Inspect condition of any fixed ladders, handrails and catwalks. 
Check all fixings for security.
All tasks and frequencies are the same as for Bulk Oil Storage (Heavy and Medium Oils), as detailed above,  without the task for 'Outflow Heaters'.

Introduction.Content:
The main periods for maintaining outdoor swimming pools are:

 
  • in early autumn when the system is shut down for the winter and the equipment and pool are prepared for the winter; and
  • in the late spring when the pool is made ready for the new season.

For indoor pools maintenance should be programmed for times of minimum use.  If constructed with membrane liner, care should be taken to avoid perforation with sharp edges of equipment.
 
Maintenance of water quality is a daily operation usually carried out either automatically or manually by the pool attendant.  See Water Treatment (SFG 65).
 
It is also assumed that cleaning of the pool areas will be undertaken by the clients operational staff.

Task.Action:
Carry out routine testing of the water quality.
 
Tests should include: water clarity, disinfectant level, pH water temperature and air temperature.
Task.Notes:
The manual monitoring and measurement of the chemical state of the pool water should be performed using colorimetric comparison kits (comparator or spectrophotometer) or commercially available test kits using test tablets.
 
The accuracy of test kits should be maintained by:

a) keeping them scrupulously clean (including rinsing glassware components with deionized water to ensure that all traces of test reagents from previous uses are removed);
b) using separate cells for pH and disinfectant testing;
c) not exceeding the shelf life of the test reagents;
d) following storage instructions;
e) using only the test kit manufacturer’s specified test tablets;
f) diluting and testing a second sample for disinfectant residuals if the first gives a result at the top or the bottom of the kit’s range;
g) using a test kit with the applicable range for the water under test; and
h) being aware of the potential false readings that can arise from things like high calcium hardness and contamination with pool cleaning chemicals.
 
Where free chlorine levels are not monitored and controlled automatically by the water treatment plant, manual testing should be carried out, using commercially available test kits and the appropriate tablets.
 
These tests should be undertaken:

a) before the pool opens;
b) every 2 hours during opening hours; and
c) after it closes.
 
Even when free chlorine levels are monitored and controlled by automatic systems, chlorine levels should be tested manually at least three times daily at the start, midway and at the end of each day.  The tests should monitor both free chlorine and combined chlorine residuals.
 
Pool water samples for analysis should be taken at a depth of 200 mm to 400 mm, from a part of the pool that has been found to be representative of the general concentration.

Task.Action: Clean Filters.
Carry out routine testing of the water quality.  Tests should include alkalinity and cyanuric acid.
Task.Notes: See Notes above (Water Quality Testing - Daily).

Task.Action: If applicable, the deck-level transfer channels are to be drained a minimum of once a month.  They should be flushed out with a disinfecting solution suitable for the task, for example 10 mg/l chlorinated water, which can be returned to the balance tank.  The undersides of transfer channel grilles should be cleaned.
Re-calibrate automatic monitoring equipment.  Check all control indicator lamps and alarms.
Check log book for any reported defects and attend as required.  Any works carried out should be clearly recorded in accordance with the operating code of practice.
Task.Notes: This task is in addition to the daily check carried out as part of any operational procedure.

Task.Action:
Balance tanks should be drained at least twice per year. 
Debris should be removed and inner surfaces brushed and flushed down with a disinfecting solution, for example 10 mg/l chlorinated water, which can be returned to the circulation system via the filters. 
For safety, individuals should not enter balance tanks on their own.
If required, isolate from electrical supply by switching off and withdrawing fuses.
Task.Notes: Ensure that water supply is also turned off.

Task.Action: Check settings and action.

Check for tears and soundness. 
Check condition and security of anchor bolts.  
The underside of pool covers and moveable floors should be checked regularly and cleaned as necessary.

In the case of an indoor pool having a suspended ceiling the wire hangers holding the ceiling frame to the slab should be checked by a structural engineer due to the highly corrosion nature of the atmosphere and the possibility of the ceiling collapsing.
Check chlorine gas detectors in the plantroom/chemical store.
Check and clean the chemical control system including all dosing and monitoring equipment.  In addition any specialist items like ozonators and ultraviolet lamps.
Task.Notes: Although the frequency has been set at 6 Months, the DFE guidance note Guide 2, Managing School Facilities requires a minimum of 4 visits per year.

Task.Action: Ensure notices on all outlets and control devices are in place.
Check that all extraneous conductive parts in zones 0, 1 and 2 are connected by supplementary bonding conductors to the protective conductors of exposed conductive parts in these zones.

Legislation.Content: BS 7671:2008 + A3: 2015. Requirements for Electrical Installations. IET Wiring Regulations.

Introduction.Content:
Filtration plant

The filtration plant of a pool is designed to remove water from the pool, filter it, disinfect it and return it to the pool in a sterile condition.  Effective filtration should ensure that water clarity is good enough to allow unclouded or clear sight of the bottom of the pool at the deep end.

The main types of pool filters are:

a) Conventional rate pressure sand filtration;
b) Medium rate pressure sand filtration;
c) High rate pressure sand filtration;
d) Pre-coat cartridge (pressure and vacuum);
e) Disposable cartridge or glass fibre mat filtration.
Introduction.Notes: Effective filtration should ensure that water clarity is good enough to allow unclouded or clear sight of the bottom of the pool at the deep end.  The water turbidity should not exceed 0.5 NTU (nephelometric turbidity units).

Task.Item: Conventional, Medium and High Rate Pressure Filtration
Conventional, Medium and High Rate Pressure Filtration
Task.Notes: The terms conventional, medium and high rate refer to the rate of flow of water through the filter.  The maintenance requirements for the three types is similar.

Task.Action:
Carry out backwashing of main filters and discharge the backwash water to waste.  Backwash flow should be fast enough to fluidise the sand bed and should have a speed of at least 30 m/h. 
Fluidisation of the bed should be checked visually if possible, through a viewing window where provided. 
Backwashing should continue at least as long as recommended by the manufacturer, but certainly until the backwash water is clear.
Task.Notes:
Filters should be backwashed at least once a week and whenever the pressure loss across the sand bed reaches the level specified by the filter manufacturer.
Filters should be backwashed if the water circulation has been stopped (because of a failure or for maintenance). 
Backwashing is best done at the end of the working day. 
Air scouring prior to the backwashing at a speed of approximately 32 m/h can aid the backwashing process.
If a filter is being backwashed while other filters are still in service, flow to the filter should start and stop slowly over a 15 second to 20 second period to avoid rapid flow rate change in the in-service filters.

Task.Action: Check condition and clean.
Task.Notes: More frequent cleaning by the operator may be necessary if the inlet flow rate falls below the design level. (May be shown by increased suction pressure).

Task.Item: Chemical cleaning of filter bed material
Task.Action: Check clean 'running' pressure.  If high, may indicate fouling of filter medium.
Task.Notes: Refer to manufacturer's handbook for instructions and type of chemicals to be used.

Task.Action: Clean and check operation.
Task.Notes: The accuracy of the flow meter should be within 5%.

Task.Action: Inspect the filter and the top of the sand bed. Check for signs of corrosion, problems with the under-drains and problems with the filter medium e.g. mud balling, fissures, uneven bed.
Clean off any coating material and check condition of support elements.
Task.Notes: The frequency of this task can be increased where Coagulants (sometimes called flocculants) are not used to enhance the removal of dissolved, colloidal or suspended material.

Task.Action: Check condition and clean.
Task.Notes: More frequent cleaning by the operator may be necessary if the inlet flow rate falls below the design level.  (May be shown by increased suction pressure).

Task.Action: Clean off any deposits or sludge's.
Clean and check operation.
Task.Notes: The accuracy of the flow meter should be within 5%.

Task.Action: Check condition and clean.
Task.Notes: More frequent cleaning by the operator may be necessary if the inlet flow rate falls below the design level. (May be shown by increased suction pressure).

Task.Action: Check condition of seals on cartridge holders.  Replace if necessary.
Clean and check operation.
Task.Notes: The accuracy of the flow meter should be within 5%.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Swimming Pools - Pipework, Pumps, Heating etc

Task.Action: Manually check the pool hall air temperatures and relative humidity levels.
Task.Notes: The pool hall air temperatures should be no more than 1°C above that of the water temperature.  Air temperatures over 30°C should be avoided.  Relative humidity should be maintained at a level of (60 ± 10)% throughout the pool hall area.

Task.Item: Hot water temperature (at outlet of post swim showers)
Task.Action: Monitor to ensure compliance with ACOP L8 requirements.  Hot water supplied to the showers should be piped at no less than 50°C and mixed to (41 ± 2)°C.
Task.Notes: Responsibility for this test should be agreed with client.  Advise client if temperature outside ACOP L8 requirements for any remedial work to be put in hand.

Task.Action:
Check for leaks and corrosion, tighten gland if required.  
Check electrical connections for tightness and signs of corrosion.
Task.Notes:
See also Pumps (SFG 45).  

Although the frequency has been set at 6 Months, the DFE guidance note Guide 2, Managing School Facilities, requires a minimum of 4 visits per year.

Task.Item: Circulatory pipework, including solar panels (where fitted)
Task.Action:
Isolate from pool and drain down. 
Clean out and dry.
Task.Notes: Do not empty the pool in wintertime, frost will damage the lining if plastic or cause the tile lining to break away.

Task.Action: Remove, drain and clean.

Carry out maintenance procedures on the ventilation plant serving the pool and changing areas. 

For further Guidance on Maintenance see:
Air Handling Units (SFG 03),
Ducting (SFG 16) and
Fans (SFG 20).
Task.Notes:
The relative humidity should be maintained at a level of (60 ± 10)% throughout the pool hall area. 

It is understood that manufacturers of AHU's and ductwork specified for swimming pools will coat internal surfaces to protect from Chlorine attack. Therefore standard maintenance frequencies recommended in Air Handling Units (SFG 03), Ducting (SFG 16) and Fans (SFG 20) can be used.

Task.Item: Heating equipment (Oil - Solar - Gas - Heat Pump)
Task.Action:
Carry out maintenance procedures appropriate to the type of heating plant as detailed in relevant sections.  The air temperature should be no more than 1°C above the pool temperature. 

For further guidance on Maintenance see:
Boilers/Heat Generators (SFG 05),
Heat Exchangers (SFG 29) and
Solar Panels (SFG 53).
Task.Notes:
Maintenance of heating plant, other than routine, is best carried out before the heating season starts.

Although the frequency has been set at 6 Months, the DFE guidance note Guide 2, Managing School Facilities, requires a minimum of 4 visits per year.

Legislation.Content: HSE (L8 4th Edition) 2013: Prevention and Control of Legionellosis (Including Legionnaires Disease) HSE Approved Code of Practice L8 (ACoP L8)
HSG274 Part 2: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Hot and Cold Water Systems
HSG274 Part 1: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Evaporative Cooling Systems
HSG274 Part 3: The Control of Legionella Bacteria in Other Risk Systems

Task.Action: Check that thermostat is not affected by local heat sources.
Task.Notes: For example thermostats may be situated above radiators, affected by direct sunlight or in cold draughts. Report to client if change of location is needed.

Task.Action: Clean and check operation including contacts.
Check and report to client if significant variation in set point is found.
Task.Notes: Wrong settings can cause energy wastage. If manual or auto-reset provided check operation.

Check that humidistat is not affected by local heat sources.
Task.Notes: For example humidistats may be situated near moisture or heat sources. Report to client if change of location needed.

Task.Action: Clean and check operation, including contacts.
Check and report to client if significant variation in set point is found.
Task.Notes: If manual or auto-reset provided check operation.

Check and report to client if significant variation in set point is found.
Check for damage or obstruction.

Check and report to client if significant variation in set point is found.

Clean and check operation.
Check and report to client if significant variation in set point is found.
Check for damage or obstruction.
Check against standard.
Clean and check operation.
Check and report to client if significant variation in set point is found.
Task.Notes: If manual or auto-reset provided check operation.

Task.Action: Check against standard.
Inspect for excessive wear.
Check for wear, redress or replace as required.
Inspect for signs of overheating and insulation breakdown.
Operate relay and check for clean operation of each set of operations.
Clean if noisy operation of relay.
Carry out as per instructions given above.
Inspect for signs of burning.
Inspect for signs of overheating or arcing.
Inspect and check mechanical and electrical operation.
Inspect for wear, assembly, breakdown of insulation, or fraying of connections.
Carry out as per instructions given in Control panels SFG 14.
Check the mechanical and electrical operation of both latched states.

Introduction.Content:
The term Terminal Units covers those items of equipment relating to the ingress of ventilating or conditioned air into the working environment.  Operationally their effectiveness may be impaired by the build up of dust and related deposits, whilst visually, dirt will arise from the atmosphere.

In a dirty environment it may be necessary to increase the frequency of maintenance above that recommended in this specification.

Detailed maintenance of the associated controls is covered in Controls (SFG 14).

Task.Action: Check condition and clean or change if necessary.
Task.Notes: If unit filter is very dirty, check condition of main filter.

Task.Action: Check operation.
Task.Notes:
Air volume will increase/decrease depending upon thermostat position. 
Ensure space temperature is within thermostat range when testing.

Task.Action: Where fitted, check condition of bellows and replace as necessary.

Introduction.Content:
The term Terminal Units covers those items of equipment relating to the ingress of ventilating or conditioned air into the working environment.  Operationally their effectiveness may be impaired by the build up of dust and related deposits, whilst visually, dirt will arise from the atmosphere.

In a dirty environment it may be necessary to increase the frequency of maintenance above that recommended in this specification.

Detailed maintenance of the associated controls is covered in Controls (SFG 14).

Task.Action: Grease or oil bearings.
Task.Notes: For further guidance on maintaining fan motors, see Motors - Drive Elements (SFG 39-01).

Task.Action: Check operation and lubricate linkages if necessary.
Task.Notes: For further guidance on maintaining damper actuators see Actuators (SFG 01).

Task.Action: Check operation and clean.  Comb any fin damaged areas.
Check operation.
Task.Notes:
Calibration, Interrogation, Control adjustment. 
For further guidance on maintaining controls see Control Panels & Controllers (SFG 14).

Task.Action: Check operation and carry out routine maintenance.
Task.Notes: For further guidance on maintaining the reheaters see Heat Exchangers (SFG 29-01 and 29-02).

Introduction.Content:
The term Terminal Units covers those items of equipment relating to the ingress of ventilating or conditioned air into the working environment.  Operationally their effectiveness may be impaired by the build up of dust and related deposits, whilst visually, dirt will arise from the atmosphere.

In a dirty environment it may be necessary to increase the frequency of maintenance above that recommended in this specification.

Detailed maintenance of the associated controls is covered in Controls (SFG 14).

Task.Action: Clean or replace as necessary.
Task.Notes: Frequency of cleaning will depend upon the environment in which the unit operates.

Task.Action: Remove access panels or ceiling tiles as appropriate.
Task.Notes:
Where units are ceiling mounted, cover any machinery/office equipment situated below the unit.
Seek prior permission before switching off any equipment which is to be covered.
Take care not to stain ceiling tiles.

Task.Action: Disconnect pneumatic control pipe and check unit motors to alternative setting.
Task.Notes:
This is for information only. 
For details of maintenance, see relevant section.

Task.Action:
Disconnect electrical control and check unit motors to alternative setting. 
Reconnect.
Task.Notes:
This is for information only. 
For details of maintenance, see relevant section.

Task.Action: Check and if found rectify.
Check condition and make good as necessary.
If visible, check for dirt, lightly oil mechanism as described in Actuators (SFG 01).

Operate and check that VAV unit moves in relation to change in setting.
Restore to original setting.
Clean, taking care not to stain ceiling.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Terminal Units - Constant Volume including Mixing

Introduction.Content:
The term Terminal Units covers those items of equipment relating to the ingress of ventilating or conditioned air into the working environment.  Operationally their effectiveness may be impaired by the build up of dust and related deposits, whilst visually, dirt will arise from the atmosphere.

In a dirty environment it may be necessary to increase the frequency of maintenance above that recommended in this specification.

Detailed maintenance of the associated controls is covered in Controls (SFG 14).

Task.Action: Check operation.

Check operation by moving set point.
Restore to original setting.

Check operation. 
For high velocity mixing box, change over dampers. 
Check seals.
Task.Notes: For more information on damper maintenance see Ducting (SFG 16).

Task.Action: Clean, taking care not to dirty surround.
Check soundness of wires and contacts.
Clean or replace as necessary.
Task.Notes: In a dirty environment it may be necessary to clean/change the filter more frequently.

Introduction.Content:
The term Terminal Units covers those items of equipment relating to the ingress of ventilating or conditioned air into the working environment.  Operationally their effectiveness may be impaired by the build up of dust and related deposits, whilst visually, dirt will arise from the atmosphere.

In a dirty environment it may be necessary to increase the frequency of maintenance above that recommended in this specification.

Task.Action: Clean washable filter and retain for re-use.

Inspect for dirt and/or obstructions, cleaning where necessary.
Check also for water leaks and rectify as necessary.
Check condition, cleaning if necessary by brushing.
Check with manometer.
Task.Notes: Compare with commissioning data and correct any deviations.

Task.Action: Check correct functioning and rectify any defects.
Task.Notes: For further guidance see Actuators - Pnuematic Actuators (SFG 01-04).

Task.Action: Check functioning.
Task.Notes: For detailed maintenance see Valves - Automatic Control (SFG 62).

Task.Action: Check operation.
Task.Notes:
Setting should be 19ºC heating and 24ºC cooling. 
For detailed maintenance see Switches (SFG 58-01).

Task.Action: Check for leaks and rectify as necessary.
Task.Notes: For detailed maintenance see Valves - Automatic Control (SFG 62).

Task.Action: Clean internally and externally. Refit secondary air inlet filter. Replace any casing which was removed.
Task.Notes: Ensure filter is correctly seated to prevent air by-passing. Note any defects on report.

Introduction.Content:
The term Terminal Units covers those items of equipment relating to the ingress of ventilating or conditioned air into the working environment.  Operationally their effectiveness may be impaired by the build up of dust and related deposits, whilst visually, dirt will arise from the atmosphere.

In a dirty environment it may be necessary to increase the frequency of maintenance above that recommended in this specification.

Detailed maintenance of the associated controls is covered in Controls (SFG 14).

Task.Action: Switch off and isolate.
Task.Notes:
Electrical isolation should be carried out in accordance with HSE Guidance.
Where units are ceiling mounted, cover any office machinery/equipment situated below unit being serviced.

Task.Action:
Check connection is clear.
Ensure condensate lift pump is operational and able to discharge condensate to the drainage pipework.
Task.Notes: The check should also ensure that the condensate drainage pipework has the correct fall to allow water to flow to the drainage stack

Task.Action: Clean and refit, ensuring proper location.
Task.Notes: See Filters (SFG 21-02) with regard to safety instructions.

Task.Action: Replace, ensuring proper location.
Task.Notes: See Filters (SFG 21-02) with regard to safety and disposal procedures.

Task.Action:
Restore power supply and run unit. 
Check airflow is normal at correct speed setting.
Clean.
Task.Notes: Where units are above false ceilings ensure that tiles are not left in a stained condition.

Task.Action: Check functioning.

Check condition.
Repair/refix any ductwork to the spigots as necessary.
Clean using vacuum or alternatively, remove and clean.
Task.Notes: Care should be taken to avoid damage to diffuser ceiling lights or ceiling.

Task.Action: Inspect and clean strainers as necessary.
Task.Notes: Report any build up of sludge/filing to the client.

Task.Action:
Check operation by moving set point. 
Restore to original setting.

Introduction.Content:
The term Terminal Units covers those items of equipment relating to the ingress of ventilating or conditioned air into the working environment.  Operationally their effectiveness may be impaired by the build up of dust and related deposits, whilst visually, dirt will arise from the atmosphere.  

In a dirty environment, it may be necessary to increase the frequency of maintenance above that recommended in this specification.

Detailed maintenance of the associated controls is covered in Controls (SFG14).

VRV Systems are very specialist and should not be treated as a standard split system.  They are set up on commissioning and the set points should not be disturbed.

Where the installed power on the refrigeration system exceeds 25kW, a Written Scheme of Examination may be required to comply with the Pressure Systems Safety Regulations.

Service providers must be registered to an Approved Certified Scheme provider, in accordance with the F Gas and Building Regulations.

Task.Action: Check condition.
Clean and remove any debris. Comb any damaged areas of fin.

Check for oil leaks. 
Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.

Personnel carrying out leak checking, gas recovery or other refrigerant handling activities such as plant installation and maintenance must have a suitable refrigerant handling qualification.

These works are covered under the current F-Gas regulations on fluorinated gases.

ALWAYS UPDATE RECORDS.
Task.Notes:
Check for leaks should be part of the routine servicing by Refrigeration Engineers.
 
Where a system has a refrigerant charge greater than 300kg, an automatic leak detection system must be installed on the system to comply with the F-Gas Regulations.

Task.Action: Check for oil and refrigerant leaks. Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks.  Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.
Check for oil and refrigerant leaks. Any leak of refrigerant should be dealt with immediately.

Check for damage.
Check condition.
Check for contact and correct location.
Check and record.

Check power supply to unit and neutral and earth connections.  
Record.
Carry out Service of the compressor.
Task.Notes: For further guidance see Compressors - Refrigeration (SFG 12-01).

Task.Action: Check function.
Task.Notes:
Run units on heating and cooling cycles if heat pumps. 
Replace batteries on remote control units as necessary.

Task.Action: Clean.
Task.Notes: Air Filters may initially require monthly cleaning dependant on location. For further guidance see Filters (SFG 21-02).

Task.Action: Check for free running.
Check condition.

Task.Item: Change over valves and refrigerant control devices
Task.Action: Check action.
Task.Notes:
If a shortage of refrigerant is suspected all should be removed, any leaks rectified and the refrigerant change weighed in after calculation change using the Manufacturer's literature. 

This work must only be carried out by a service provider registered with an authorised scheme provider.

Introduction.Content:
In addition to routine maintenance, examinations of some pressure vessels are required under the Pressure Systems Safety Regulations 2000 - see relevant section SFG 40-08.

Maintenance should only be carried out by competent persons.

Task.Notes: For more detailed information on the maintenance of earthing electrical equipment see Power supplies earthing SFG 44-06.

Check flight time of shortest and longest runs.

Introduction.Content: When opening valves (especially steam valves etc.) they must be done in such a way as to avoid the chances of 'water hammer' occurring.

Task.Notes: Preventative maintenance on this type of valve is best obtained by daily checks on gland or stem leakage and repairing these as they occur.

Task.Action: Check by rotating handwheel sufficiently to indicate that wedge is not seized in closed position nor jammed in open position.  If normally open, close valve and reopen.  When fully open, close valve ½ turn to ensure valve does not jam.
Task.Notes: Action depends upon whether valve is normally closed or normally open. If valve is normally open, check closure performance in the event that corrosive deposits prevent wedge seating.

Task.Action: Ensure correct packing material is used for the fluid in the pipeline.
Task.Notes:
After installation or replacement, check for gland leakage daily for one week. Early signs of slight leaks are due to 'bedding in' or drying out and are usually cured by tightening of gland nuts.

Continuous leakage can lead to erosion or corrosion of the valve stem.

Task.Action: Inspect for external deterioration due to leaks at end flanges or aggressive environment.
Task.Notes: Leakage from end flanges can be due to pipe strains, ground settlement, poor joints or pipe supports.

Task.Action: Check by rotating handwheel sufficiently to ensure freedom of movement. When fully open, close valve ½ turn to ensure valve does not jam.
Ensure correct packing material is used for the fluid in the pipeline.
Task.Notes:
After installation or replacement, check for gland leakage daily for one week.  Early signs of slight leaks are due to 'bedding in' or drying out and are usually cured by tightening of gland nuts.

Continuous leakage can lead to erosion or corrosion of the valve stem.

Task.Action: Inspect for external deterioration due to leaks at end flanges or aggressive environment.
Task.Notes: Leakage from end flanges can be due to pipe strains, ground settlement, poor joints or pipe supports.

Task.Action: Check by partially rotating plug to ensure freedom of movement.
Task.Notes: Inject correct compound as recommended by the manufacturer to maintain smooth operation.

Task.Action: If evidence of leakage, inject correct compound, simultaneously rotating plug.
Task.Notes: After installation or overhaul, check daily for one week and then at three monthly intervals.

Task.Action: Inspect for external deterioration due to leaks at end flanges or aggressive environment.
Task.Notes: Leakage from end flanges can be due to pipe strains, ground settlement, poor joints or pipe supports.

Task.Action: Check by partially rotating disc to ensure freedom of movement.
Task.Notes: Close valve (if system condition allows) and check seat tightness, this tests the condition of the elastomeric seal.

Task.Action: Check for freedom from dirt particles. Tighten gland if adjustable type, if not, replace proprietary seals (e.g. 'O' rings).
Task.Notes: After installation or overhaul, check for stem leakage daily for the first week.

Task.Action: Check for deterioration externally or aggressive environment.
Task.Notes: Wafer pattern unlikely to have flange leakage, provided that flange bolting has been tightened evenly.

Task.Action: Check.
Check for drips from valve indicating leaking seat.
Task.Notes: Depress float to flush seat. If leak persists, check seat for damage or replace washer.

Task.Action: See Notes.
Task.Notes: It is recommended that these valves be operated over their full travel once every four weeks.

Task.Action: Check for body/cover joint leakage and tighten nuts to stop.
Task.Notes: As a matter of routine any visible signs of leakage should be reported to the site supervisor.

Task.Action: Valve normally closed, rotate handwheel to ensure freedom of movement. When fully open, close valve ½ turn to ensure valve does not jam.
Task.Notes: Close valve (if system allows) to check seat tightness. If valve normally closed, drop differential pressure to 1 bar or less (if system allows) and partially rotate to check for freedom from galling seats.

Task.Action: Inspect for external deterioration due to leaks at end flanges or aggressive environment.
Task.Notes: Leakage from end flanges can be due to pipe strains, ground settlement, poor joints or poor pipe supports.

Task.Action:
Check by raising gagging lever to discharge steam or air. Release gagging lever to reseat.
Check for dirt or damage.
Task.Notes:
Important:
Great care must be exercised to avoid injury to personnel.
Check that discharge is to free space or if piped, that pipe outlet is not directed to personnel.
Check with insurance company for frequency of mandatory checks.

Task.Action: Strip down, overhaul and then rebuild to comply with the Competent Persons requirements under the Pressure Regulations and the written scheme of examination.
Task.Notes: The Competent Person may require additional testing on completion of the rebuild.

Task.Action: Check condition, report.
Task.Notes: The Competent Person should be contacted for the routine replacement frequency for the bursting discs.
The written scheme of examination may require the valves to be stripped down, overhauled and then rebuilt to comply with the Competent Persons requirements under the Pressure Regulations.

Task.Item: Main valve seat and valve head
Task.Action: Isolate and reduce pressure to zero. Remove screen and clean, clean gasket faces and renew gasket.
Task.Notes: The actual maintenance requirements may vary with the type of valve and the manufacturer's instructions should be followed carefully.
