Task.Notes: The frequency is determined by Inspection and manufacturer's instructions.

Task.Action: Determination of sludge volume.

Measure the thickness of light liquids.  Check the operation of the automatic closure device.  Check the coalescing devices for permeability, if the water levels in front and behind the coalescing device show significant difference.  Check the function of the warning device.
Task.Notes: Emptying is recommended when one half of the sludge volume or 80% of the storage capacity of the separator is reached.

Task.Action: Clean the drain channel.
Task.Notes: Light liquid and sludge shall be removed as required.  Before putting in, service sludge trap and separator should be re-filled with fresh water.

Task.Action: Empty separator system and check for tightness of the system, structural condition, internal coatings [if present], condition of inbuilt parts, state of electrical devices and installations and checking of adjustment of automatic closure device, e.g. floating bodies.
Task.Notes: The frequency of 5 years is a maximum and depends upon local risk assessment.

Introduction.Content:
The Control of Pollution (Oil Storage) (England) Regulations 2001 and Groundwater Protection Code: Petrol stations and other fuel dispensing facilities involving underground storage tanks set minimum standards. They do not change other legislation under which it is an offence to cause water pollution. Variations in local conditions may mean more stringent standards are needed to prevent pollution.
If there is a spill, immediate action must be taken to stop the oil getting into any drains or watercourses. Soak up the spilt oil with the contents of the spill kit in accordance with the risk assessment. Dont hose the spillage down or use any detergents to try to get rid of it. Notify the Environment Agency by calling their Emergency Hotline on 0800 80 70 60.

If oil soaks into the ground, the soil soaked in oil should be removed, by a specialist company. Store any materials that are soaked in oil in containers that wont let the oil run away until it can be correctly and legally disposed of.

In addition to the tasks there are daily and weekly operational tasks to be carried out including visual checks of the oil tanks, pipework .

Refer to the Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH) Regulations. Staff to be Competent and fully trained in COSHH. Risk Assessment / Method Statement requirements must be carried out before the work starts and a method statement produced. Refer to www.hse.gov.uk for details.

Task.Action: Look for leakage and spillage from the tank resulting from filling or failure of tank soundness.
Remove and clean.
Ensure that the vent is clear and free from obstruction.
Check operation and freedom of movement. Moving parts should be lightly oiler or greased.

Ensure that all electrical connections remain clean, tight and dry. Check for liquid leakage around bolt-to-tank joint and element sheaths. When a drain connection is provided loosen drain valve and check for sludge build-up. If this is excessive, isolate heater and drain off quantity of sludge.
Check and log oil level. Log also any inspections, any repair work on the tanks and whos done the works.
Dip tank to ensure gauge is working and accurate
Use a suitable paste on the dip stick / line and check for water.
Task.Notes: Remove water and increase frequency of checks to ensure there is no leakage into the tank.

Task.Action: Check valves are locked or have there hand wheels removed [ vandalism / theft]. Pipework should be checked for leaks, corrosion, missing brackets etc. Check any trace heating and insulation is in place and working where appropriate.
Note settings of valves and take through total travel, returning to correct settings. Lock or remove hand wheel as appropriate. Pipework should be checked for leaks, corrosion, missing brackets etc.

Check that the notice showing the product type, tank capacity and, where appropriate, tank number is clearly visible clean or replace as necessary. Check all notices are clearly visible warning that all valves must be locked when not in use.
Check that the device sounds the alarm / shows the visual warning or automatically stops the delivery whatever applies.
Check that the lockable fill cap and chain are in place and work. Clean the fill point drip tray.
Check that the system is operating correctly as per manufacturers guidelines.
Task.Notes: In addition to this tasks there are daily and weekly operational tasks to be carried out to check leakage detection.

Task.Action: Check condition and record results
Task.Notes: This must be checked within 6 months of any new installation or repair to the sacrificial anode system. The results of the last two tests must be retained on site.

Task.Action: Check condition and record results
Task.Notes: The results of the last three tests must be retained on site.

Task.Action: Check soil conditions in terms of moisture content, electrical conductivity, pH, sulphide concentration and chloride concentration.
Task.Notes: Usually the corrosion of buried steel occurs as a result of electrochemical reactions with constituents of the enclosing soils. In order to assess the risk of corrosion failure, it is necessary to ascertain soil conditions such as moisture content, electrical conductivity, pH, sulphide concentration and chloride concentration. This data, once collected, can be analysed using a standard method to determine the probability of a leak caused by corrosion, both at present and in the future. Assessment of corrosion probability will help to decide if urgent action is required, e.g. the fitting of cathodic protection, tank lining or the replacement of a tank.

Legislation.Content: Control of Pollution (Oil Storage) (England) Regulations 2001
The Groundwater (England and Wales) Regulations 2009

Introduction.Content:
There are several hazards in entering and working in a silo. The main hazards include difficult access and egress, which makes entrapment, escape and rescue more problematic; being engulfed in a free flowing material if the chips/pellets have blocked and
bridged; the accumulation of vapours, gases or fumes; and the lack of ventilation. Some of these hazards may be introduced into the silo by the nature of the maintenance work (e.g. welding work
or cleaning work with solvents) or by incoming services.

Task.Action: Chip silos and storage rooms should be cleaned out at the end of each heating season, to avoid accumulation of dust, bacteria and fungi.
Task.Notes: Chip reception pits should be equipped with a ladder (set into the wall) to facilitate entry and egress.

Task.Action: Check the burn back control device is in place and that the sensor / wax seal is operational. Check that the water supply pressure is correct [normally in excess of 1 bar].
In case of bulk-blown pellet deliveries - check that the rubber mat is in place and that there is at least a 20mm air gap from a wall opposite the inlet to the store.

Introduction.Content:
The burning of coal is a complex operation involving the storage, handling of solid material, together with the handling. Coal is abrasive and the wear and tear on mechanical plant considerable, hence regular maintenance is vital to ensure continuous working and a clean environment.

A risk assessment and method statement must be undertaken before entering any confined space such as a hopper / silo to ensure that there is adequate ventilation and an absence of any fumes or flue gases.

Task.Action: Empty and check internal and external coatings.
Task.Notes: If there are signs of deterioration consult the manufacturer.

Introduction.Content:
Check for asbestos containing material prior to dismantling any equipment, if suspected STOP WORK, close off the area. Take actions in accordance with the Asbestos Regulations.  Refer to www.hse.gov.uk.

In certain applications the frequency of servicing will have to be increased, this to a large extent is governed by the working environment and should be established following a site specific unit by unit risk assessment being carried out to establish the correct frequency of maintenance.

Task.Action: Before any maintenance or servicing work is carried out the heater must be shut down, allowed to cool and have the oil and electric supplies to it turned off at the supply valve and isolator respectively.
Visually inspect the burner.
Clean and check spark electrode.
Clean and check photocell.
Check overheat safety is operational.
Carry out combustion test and check efficiency of combustion and levels of pollutant gases – adjust burner in accordance with results.
Carry out smoke test in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations.

The heat exchanger and combustion chamber should be visually inspected for signs of splits, cracks, and distortion.
Remove any accumulated deposits from the tubes by pushing through the full length with a flue brush. The flue brush should be withdrawn so as to pull any deposits back into the bottom of the flue box where they can then be removed by using a vacuum cleaner.

Particular attention should be paid to the upper internal surfaces of the tubes where, through convection, heavier deposition is likely to occur.
Any deposits which may have accumulated within the combustion chamber can be removed with a vacuum cleaner once the burner is removed.

All gaskets should be checked to ensure that they continue to provide a gas tight seal, if there is an element of doubt then they should be replaced.
Task.Notes: It is most important that a build up of deposits is not allowed to occur as this can have an adverse effect upon the efficiency of the heater and reduce the life of the heat exchanger.

Task.Action:
Check electrical connections to ensure they are secure and free from corrosion.

Terminals and connections should also be checked to ensure that no stray strands are bridging terminals.

Remove dust and other foreign matter by blowing off with compressed air or through the use of a soft bristle brush.

Check that the bearings do not show signs of excessive wear. It should be noted that generally these bearings do not require lubricating - check manufacturer's recommendations.

The oil supply pipework, tank and fittings should all be inspected to ensure they are free from corrosion and to ensure that where brackets have been fitted these remain secure and offer adequate support.

The oil filter should be replaced with a new one and the system should be checked for leaks.
If the oil level is such to allow removal of any sludge or other contaminants from the tank this too should be undertaken, particularly if there have been problems of poor firing associated with contaminants reaching the burner.
Task.Notes: Any waste oil or sludge must be disposed of correctly. Never dispose of it by dumping or tipping it down drains or into watercourses where ground water can become polluted and environmental damage caused.

Task.Action: Service burner in accordance with manufacturer's instructions.
A visual inspection should be undertaken to ensure that the air delivery system is in good order, that it remains adequately supported and that the various joints are effectively sealed.

A visual inspection should be carried out to ensure that the flue remains adequately supported, both internally as well as externally, and that the various joints are effectively sealed.

Inspection covers, where fitted, should be removed and the flue checked to see whether cleaning is required.  If inspection covers are not fitted the flue gas exit duct and flue spigot will provide not only an indication of the cleanliness of the flue but will also enable access for cleaning.

The presence of the flue terminal should be checked.

If a condensate trap and drain facility is fitted this should be checked to ensure that it continues to function correctly and the drainage of condensates is not impaired.
Following completion of the above 12M works, the heater should be re-commissioned in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.
Provide written report which should be signed by the service engineer and kept by client.
Task.Notes:
Premature failure and excessive fuel costs will result if satisfactory service is not carried out.

All service and maintenance must be carried out by a registered engineer in accordance with Health and Safety requirements.

All service and maintenance works must be carried out by a competent engineer in accordance with BS Codes of Practice for oil firing.

Task.Action: Before any maintenance or servicing work is carried out, the heater must be shut down, allowed to cool and have the oil and electric supplies to it turned off at the supply valve and isolator respectively.
Task.Notes:
Oil fired equipment must be installed and maintained in accordance with the current OFTEC Regulations for oil fired products.

Due account should also be taken of any obligations arising from the Health and Safety at Works Act or relevant codes of practice.

In addition, the installation must be carried out in accordance with the current IEE wiring regulations (BS 7671), BS 6896 (Industrial & Commercial) and any other relevant British Standards and Codes of Practice by a qualified installer.

All external wiring MUST comply with the current IEE wiring regulations.

Task.Action: Visually inspect the burner.
Clean and check spark electrode.
Clean and check photocell.
Check overheat safety is operational.
Carry out combustion test and check efficiency of combustion and levels of pollutant gases – adjust burner in accordance with results.
Carry out smoke test in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations.

The heat exchanger and combustion chamber should be visually inspected for signs of splits, cracks and distortion.

Remove any accumulated deposits from the tubes by pushing through the full length with a flue brush. The flue brush should be withdrawn so as to pull any deposits back into the bottom of the flue box where they can then be removed by using a vacuum cleaner.

Particular attention should be paid to the upper internal surfaces of the tubes, where through convection, heavier deposition is likely to occur.
Any deposits which may have accumulated within the combustion chamber can be removed with a vacuum cleaner once the burner is removed.

All gaskets should be checked to ensure that they continue to provide a gas tight seal.  If there is an element of doubt then they should be replaced.
Task.Notes: It is most important that a build up of deposits is not allowed to occur as this can have an adverse effect upon the efficiency of the heater and reduce the life of the heat exchanger.

Task.Action:
Check electrical connections to ensure they are secure and free from corrosion.

Terminals and connections should also be checked to ensure that no stray strands are bridging terminals.

Remove access panel.

Dust and other foreign matter should be cleaned by blowing over with compressed air and through the use of a soft bristle brush and cloth. Solvent wipes may be used to remove heavy soiling from the motor casing.

Traces of surplus lubricants spreading from the bearings should also be cleaned away.

Where motors are fitted with grease nipples, bearings should be lubricated with the correct grade of lubricant. Motors which do not have grease nipples feature sealed bearings which are lubricated during manufacture for their life.

The electrical connections should be checked for signs of corrosion and tightness and ensure that there are no stray strands which could form a short circuit. Clean, tighten and replace as necessary.

Replace cover and secure.

Remove dust and other foreign matter by blowing off with compressed air or through the use of a soft bristle brush.

Check that the bearings do not show signs of excessive wear. It should be noted that these bearings generally do not require lubricating.

If the bearings require replacing the following procedure should be followed:

(a) Remove belt(s).
(b) Loosen set screw on eccentric collar and tap collar in the opposite direction to fan rotation.
(c) Remove collar and bearing.
(d) Check shaft for alignment and straightness.
(e) Locate the bearing in its seat and place on the shaft with the cam facing outwards.
(f) Fit the eccentric collar and engage the cams.
(g) Tighten initially by rotating, then by tapping in the direction of the fan rotation.
(h) Replace fasteners and secure.
(i) Turn by hand to ensure free fan rotation.

Check pulleys for alignment using a straight edge, if necessary, reposition either or both of the pulleys and the fan motor.

Check for excessive wear within the root and sides of the grooves and check for any other signs of wear or damage.  If necessary, replace the pulley as follows:

(a) Release tension on belts and remove.
(b) Release the taper locks by slackening the securing screws by several complete turns.
(c) Fully remove one screw from the taper lock and having oiled it, insert into the threaded jacking point.
(d) Tighten screw until the taper lock is free.
(e) Remove taper lock and pulley.
(f) Fit taper lock in new pulley and provisionally position on the shaft.
(g) Remove the screw from the jacking point and tighten both screws in their clamping points until the pulley can just be moved on the shaft by hand.
(h) Align pulleys using a straight edge and by gradual alternate tightening of the screws clamp in position.
(i) Refit belts and check for the correct amount of tension.

Check belts for signs of wear.

Frayed or split belts must be replaced using belts with a common batch code.

Belt tension must be checked and if, on multi-belt units it is found that one belt contains more slack than its accompanying belts, then all the belts on the unit must be replaced, again using a common batch code.

The oil supply pipework, tank and fittings should all be inspected to ensure that they are free from corrosion and to ensure that where brackets have been fitted these remain secure and offer adequate support.

The oil filter should be replaced with a new one and the system should be checked for leaks. If the oil level is such to allow removal of any sludge or other contaminants from the tank, this too should be undertaken, particularly if there have been problems of poor firing associated with contaminants reaching the burner.
Task.Notes: Any waste oil or sludge must be disposed of correctly. Never dispose of it by dumping or tipping it down drains or into watercourses where ground water can become polluted and environmental damage caused.

Task.Action: Service burner in accordance with manufacturer's instructions.
A visual inspection should be undertaken to ensure that the air delivery system is in good order, that it remains adequately supported and that the various joints are effectively sealed.

A visual inspection should be carried out to ensure that the flue remains adequately supported, both internally as well as externally, and that the various joints are effectively sealed.

Inspection covers, where fitted, should be removed and the flue checked to see whether cleaning is required.  If inspection covers are not fitted, the flue gas exit duct and flue spigot will provide not only an indication of the cleanliness of the flue but will also enable access for cleaning.

The presence of the flue terminal should be checked.

If a condensate trap and drain facility is fitted this should be checked to ensure that it continues to function correctly and the drainage of condensates is not impaired.
Following completion of the above 12M works the heater should be re-commissioned in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.
Provide written report which should be signed by the service engineer and kept by the client.
Task.Notes:
Premature failure and excessive fuel costs will result if satisfactory service is not carried out.

All service and maintenance must be carried out by a registered engineer in accordance with Health and Safety requirements.

All service and maintenance works must be carried out by a competent engineer in accordance with BS Codes of Practice for oil firing.

Legislation.Content: Boiler (Efficiency) Regulations 1993
Landlord and Tenant Act 1985
Building Regulations 2000 Approved Document J (2010) Heat producing appliances
Clean Air Act 1993
Control of Pollution (Oil Storage) (England) Regulations 2001
Control of Pollution Act 1974

Task.Notes: The frequency of cleaning will be driven by the environment in which the beams are installed and the filter level in the AHU and this should be reviewed on a site by site basis.

Task.Action:
Vacuum all dirt clear to ensure air has a free path through the exchanger for maximum performance. 

If the fins are damaged, comb back into shape.
Task.Notes: Please ensure that when vacuuming the coil, care is taken not to damage the aluminium fins as this will affect the performance of the unit.

Task.Action: Check the air connection spigot is secure.
Clean the unit with a cloth wetted with detergent diluted with water.

Check the operation of both the cooling and heating (as applicable) control valves.

Take note of any signs of leaking and correct and/or report as appropriate.
Check condition and report any signs of rusting or leakage.

Task.Notes: The frequency of cleaning will be driven by the environment in which the beams are installed and this should be reviewed on a site by site basis.

Task.Action:
Vacuum all dirt clear to ensure air has a free path through the exchanger for maximum performance.  

If the fins are damaged, comb back into shape.
Task.Notes: Please ensure that when vacuuming the coil, care is taken not to damage the aluminium fins as this will affect the performance of the unit.

Task.Action: Clean the unit with a cloth wetted with detergent diluted with water.

Check the operation of both the cooling and heating control valves, as applicable. 

Take note of any signs of leaking and correct and/or report as appropriate.
Check condition and report any signs of rusting or leakage.

ScheduleGroups.ScheduleGroup: 2.5.1 External Enclosing Walls - Above Ground Level:
2.5.2 External Enclosing Walls - Below Ground Level

Introduction.Content:
Many photovoltaic systems power critical loads, such as communication or warning lights. Be sure to get permission from the appropriate authority to disconnect such loads before doing so. In some cases, an auxiliary power supply may be necessary to operate the load while it is being inspected.

Working at heights should be in strict accordance with the Work at Height Regulations.

Before maintenance is carried out, each component of the system should be isolated. This would involve switching off circuit breakers to and from the battery bank and the solar panels.

Battery banks, even at low voltages, can produce potentially lethal amounts of current. Always be careful when working around them.
Introduction.Notes:
Be sure to open disconnect switches during any operation involving wiring.

Photovoltaic modules produce electricity whenever they are exposed to light. When working on their wiring, cover them with an opaque material, turn them face down on a clean, soft surface, or work at night.

Task.Action:
Inspect systems batteries.

Check for any electrolyte leak, cracks in the batteries or corrosion at the terminals or connectors.
Task.Notes: Do not smoke or light fire near batteries.  Batteries produce hydrogen gas which is highly flammable.

Task.Action:
This component can be maintained by minimizing dust accumulation. A dry cloth should be used to wipe away any accumulated dirt/dust. A visual inspection should be done to ensure that all the indicators such as LED lights are working and that the wires leading to and from this device are not loose.

Note that the charge controller should indicate that the system is charging when the sun is up.

The cells should be watered back to the original acid level which is "¼ - ½" below the bottom of the vent well (the tube inside the battery cell with slots on each side).

Test the specific gravity of the electrolyte and compare the state of charge of each individual cell.
Task.Notes:
Do not smoke or light fire near batteries. Batteries produce hydrogen gas which is highly flammable.

Do not use the same hydrometer for testing lead acid batteries and ni cad batteries. The ni cad batteries will be destroyed by traces of acid.

Use only distilled water to top up the batteries.

Task.Action:
Battery cleaning procedures are as follows:

1. Switch off/disconnect all loads on the system. Turn off or disconnect the solar charge. Then turn off the circuit breaker to and from the battery bank.
2. Ensure that the caps on the batteries are sealed tight to keep any dirt from entering the battery. Wipe the top and outside of the battery with a (damp) cloth. If corrosion is present at the terminals, mix baking soda with fresh water and apply the solution to the affected area. Stubborn areas should be scrubbed with a metal brush. After cleaning, rinse the terminals with water. If available, apply petroleum jelly or grease to the connected terminal to prevent future corrosion.
3. Maintenance of gel cell and AGM batteries relates only to the battery terminals and connections. The terminals and posts should be wiped until they are shiny.  If corroded, clean them properly with Bi-carbonate soda and water. If available, apply petroleum jelly or grease to the connected terminals.
Task.Notes: Do not smoke or light fire near batteries. Batteries produce hydrogen gas which is highly flammable.

Task.Action:
Clean panels using hot water, no chemicals or cleaning agents and a telescopic cleaning pole to allow cleaning from a safe foothold.  Do not use a metal brush to clean solar panel surface.
A visual inspection of the modules can then be done to check for defects in the modules such as cracks, chips, de-lamination, fogged glazing, water leaks and discoloration. If any obvious defects are found, note their location in the system logbook, so they can be monitored in the future in case further deterioration affects the modules’ output.
The condition of the array mounting frame should also be noted. Items to observe should include the array mounting bolts (e.g. bolt rusting) and checks to ensure that the frame and modules are firmly secured.
The junction boxes should also be checked to ensure that the wires are not chewed by rodents or insects.
Task.Notes:
The solar array (a number of solar panels connected together) is often thought to be maintenance free. However, occasional maintenance and inspection of the solar array must be performed to ensure the optimal use of the solar panels. This can be done by keeping the surface (glass) area of the module clean from any excess dirt. 

The frequency of cleaning will vary, particularly if the panels are located near a large tree (sap & bird droppings).

Task.Action:
Wiring installations should be checked for any cracks, breaks or deterioration in the insulation/conduits. Inspect panel boxes to ensure that they have not become a home for rodents and insects. Also inspect connections for any corrosion and/or burning. Switches should not spark when turned on or off.
 
The following sections of conduit and wiring should be checked for any signs of damage:
a)  Solar panels to the charge controller
b)  Charge controller to the battery bank
c)  Inverter/charger to the battery bank
d)  Generator to Inverter/charger
e)  Inverter/charger and Generator to the AC outlets
f)  Battery bank to the DC outlets/load.
If damage is found report as soon as possible. 
 
All earthing cables should be checked to ensure they are not broken.

Introduction.Content:
This is a specialised field and requires suitably competent engineers to maintain this type of equipment.  

A Written Scheme of Examination may be required  to comply with the Pressure Systems Safety Regulations.
ALWAYS UPDATE RECORDS.
Introduction.Notes:
Absorption refrigeration can also be used to provide cooling using heat from a solar energy source. Potential solar sources are flat-plate collectors (water or air), evacuated tube collectors and parabolic concentrators.

Typical COPs for single-effect absorption chillers are 0·7 to 0·8, while double-effect chillers produce COPs of 1·0 to 1·2. However, to achieve this level of performance, a heat supply temperature of 80ºC to 100ºC will be required for single-effect chillers, while double-effect chillers will require a temperature of around 150ºC.

Flat-plate collectors can provide a temperature of 60ºC to 90ºC.

With selective-surface flat-plate collectors the temperature can be increased to 120ºC, although the collector efficiency will be low at this level.

Evacuated tube solar collectors can provide 80ºC to 120ºC (higher temperatures are possible but at lower flow rates).

Compound parabolic concentrators can operate at temperatures between 100ºC and 165ºC.

Task.Action: See (SFG 09-03) Lithium Bromide/Water Absorption Chillers
Check as per manufacturer's instructions.
Task.Notes: Record and note changes in specific gravity from given conditions.

Task.Action: Determine as per manufacturer's instructions.
Task.Notes: Note leak rate and compare with manufacturer's maximum rate.  If higher, this indicates that machine has a leak and action must be taken to trace and rectify.

Task.Action: Check as per manufacturer's instructions.
Check as per manufacturer's instructions.
Check as per manufacturer's instructions.
Check operation as per manufacturer's instructions.
Check for scale.  Action to be determined by findings.
Task.Notes: When chemical cleaning is carried out, ensure that competent company and personnel are used.

Task.Action: Take as per manufacturer's instructions.  Add amounts of chemicals as advised by chemist (i.e. inhibitor octyl-alcohol etc.).
Task.Notes: Record results and compare with last set of readings. Record details of action, compare with last report and file.

Task.Action:
Determine as per manufacturer's instructions. 

 

Experience is vital in determining the significance of any loss.
Task.Notes:
Recorded loss should not be greater than 3b0 F. 

Measure and record:
i. refrigerant temperature
ii. temperature and specific gravity of solution
iii. temperature at the outlet of the solution pump.
 
Early resolution of any crystallisation problems is important as damage to pumps may occur.

Task.Action: Replace as per manufacturer's specifications.
Check Condition and make good any defects, however small.
Task.Notes: Poor or faulty insulation can lead to loss of efficiency, energy wastage and the formation of condensation.

Task.Action: Visually inspect for corrosion, erosion and deformities.
Any pressure relief device should be checked if fitted.
See (SFG 53-01) Solar Hot Water Panels and similar COLLECTING DEVICES.
Task.Notes: Working at heights should be in strict accordance with the Work at Height Regulations.

Task.Action:
Check condition and clean all dirt from surfaces of the unit (take precautions to prevent inhalation of bird droppings - COSHH Regulations) with stiff (not wire) brush.

Report condition if cracked. 

A safe method of gaining height may be required; operatives are to be fully trained.
Task.Notes:
Frequency will depend on location and local atmospheric condition. 

Dirt causes loss of collector efficiency. 

Cracked glass should be replaced.

Task.Action: Check condition and make good if necessary.
Task.Notes:
Poor seals lead to internal condensation and loss of efficiency. 

If there are signs of internal algae growth on underside of glass plate, it should be removed, cleaned and resealed. 

Care should be taken not to damage absorber plate as it may have a special coating.

Task.Action: Check condition and top up to required concentration.
Task.Notes: Anti-freeze solution should be replaced every 3 years.

Task.Action: Check operation of thermostat and pump control.
Task.Notes: For more detailed maintenance of controls, see relevant SFG20 sections.

Task.Action: Check for leaks and signs of corrosion and make good as necessary.
Replace anti-freeze solution.

Check condition and clean all dirt from surfaces of the tubes (take precautions to prevent inhalation of bird droppings - COSHH Regulations) with stiff (not wire) brush.

Report condition if cracked.

A safe method of gaining height may be required; operatives are to be fully trained.
Task.Notes:
Frequency will depend on location and local atmospheric condition. 

Dirt causes loss of collector efficiency. 

Cracked tubes should be replaced.

Task.Action: A safe method of gaining height may be required; operatives are to be fully trained.
Task.Notes:
Frequency will depend on location and local atmospheric condition. 

Dirt causes loss of collector efficiency. 

Care should be taken to avoid damaging the reflector surface.

Task.Action: Check condition and top up to required concentration.
Task.Notes: Anti-freeze solution should be replaced every 3 years.

Task.Action: Check operation of thermostat and pump control.
Task.Notes: For more detailed maintenance of controls, see relevant SFG20 sections.

Task.Action: Check for leaks and signs of corrosion and make good as necessary.
Task.Notes: For more detailed maintenance of controls, see relevant SFG20 sections.

Task.Action: Replace anti-freeze solution.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Combined Heat and Power (CHP) - Diesel Fueled Engine

Introduction.Content:
Frequency is normally set on an hours run basis and below the main engine tasks are set using engine hours run. Each machine should
be reviewed in terms of site conditions, priority, criticality etc and the frequency for each task established.
Introduction.Notes:
Before carrying out any work, check status and isolate in accordance with HASAWA (http://www.hse.gov.uk) and Electricity at Work requirements. This may require the engineer to follow a permit to work system.

The actual frequencies / run hours will vary according to the cleanliness of the combustion air, cleanliness of the engine room, engine manufacturer’s recommendations, number of engine starts and stops, and lubricating conditions indicated by oil analysis. With some engines and some operating conditions, the intervals between procedures listed below may be extended or reduced as the frequencies given are generic and need firming to the specific conditions and manufacturers recomendations of the actual engine in question.

The maintenance frequencies below are based on the number of hours run.

Engine / daily log books should be kept on all pertinent operating parameters, such as:

• Water and lubricating oil temperatures
• Individual cylinder compression pressures, which are useful in indicating blowby
• Changes in valve tappet clearance, which indicate the extent of wear in the valve system.

Task.Action: Wipe down the engine which will help show any leaks. Pay attention to abnormal sounds and odours. Check for any unaccountable speed changes.
Check all flexible connections for leaks.
Check that the air inlet louvre is clear of any debris that would impede airflow.
Take lubricating oil sample.
Change lubricating oil filters.
Task.Notes:
This task should be carried out at least every 6 months.

Frequency:  350-750 hours.

Task.Action: Clean or replace air filters
Clean fuel filters.
Change lubricating oil.
Task.Notes:
Frequency:  500-1000 hours.

This task should be carried out at least every 6 months.

Additionally take sample at each oil change.

Lubricating analysis should be completed by a commercial laboratory. The analysis should measure the concentration of various elements found in the lubricating oil, such as bearing metals, silicates, and calcium. It should also measure the dilution of the oil, suspended and non-suspended solids, water and oil viscosity.

Task.Action: Clean crankcase breather.
Adjust valves.
Lubricate tachometer, fuel priming pump and auxiliary drive bearings.
Flush lubrication oil piping system.
Change air filter.
Replace turbocharger seals and bearings.

Replace piston rings, cylinder liners (if applicable), connecting rod bearings and cylinder heads;
Recondition or replace turbochargers;
Replace gaskets and seals.

Replace piston rings, cylinder liners (if applicable), connecting rod bearings and cylinder heads;
Recondition or replace turbochargers;
Replace gaskets and seals;
Recondition or replace crankshaft;
Replace all bearings.
Check the operation of all alarm and shutdown controls.
Task.Notes:
• Speed control (under and over speed)
• Lubrication (low oil pressure, high oil temperature)
• Heat removal (high coolant temperature or lack of coolant flow)
• Combustion process (fuel, ignition)
• Lubricating oil level
• Water level

Task.Action:
Check starter batteries are fully charged.
Top up with distilled water as necessary.
Inspect cells and ensure that vent holes in filter caps are clear.
Check that conducting bars and cable connections are clean and tight, any trace of verdigras to be cleaned off and connections to be coated with petroleum jelly.
Take random test or specific gravity and cell voltage.
Task.Notes:
Charge batteries as necessary (in accordance with instructions in operating log).
Top up electrolyte using pure distilled water, ensure that cells are gassing freely whilst charging.
Charge batteries to 1250 s.g. and 2.1 volts per cell, or otherwise as specified.

Re-check specific gravity:

a. Electrolyte should be kept to 12 mm above plates, only pure distilled water to be used for this purpose.
b. Topping up should be carried out before charging to ensure good mixing.
c. Ventilation holes in filter caps must be kept clean.
d. A lead acid battery is fully charged when s.g. is 1250 and all cells are at 2.4 volts. The battery cells should not be allowed to fall below 1150 s.g. or 1.8 volts.
e. When the charging rate is in doubt, a long slow charge is better than a short sharp one.

Task.Action: Check condition.
Check condition and report to client if replacement is required.
Task.Notes: Batteries should be disposed of only in accordance with H&S and Environmental Regulations recommendations.

Task.Action:
Check all electrical connections for security. Examine brush gear in the dynamo and starter and clean commutator, renew brushes as necessary.
Check operation of low oil and high coolant shutdown switches.

Open all composite control panels and associated switchgear.
Clean out interior of all panels.
Inspect all wiring for condition.
Inspect all terminations for security and overheating.
Visually check that an efficient earth is being maintained.
Open, inspect and clean any changeover switches on emergency supply system.
Check overloads are functional and are set to correct value.
Ensure fuses of correct size and type are fitted.
Examine all contacts for arcing and pitting, dress or replace contacts as applicable.
Lightly lubricate all contact faces with pure petroleum jelly.
Check relays for correct function, replace any defective components.
Examine switch-blades in isolators, ensure they are free to move.
Lubricate pivots lightly with grease, ensuring no grease comes into contact with a conducting surface.
Check for smooth operation and that switches are clearly marked.

Before carrying out the following test disconnect L.V. circuits, i.e. rotating rectifier diodes and A.V.R. circuits etc.

Carry out the following test:

a. Insulation Resistance Test on alternator and wiring. A figure of 1 megohm or above is acceptable.
b. Earth Loop Impedance Test on alternator frame. Supply voltage = Maximum allowed 3 X rating of Fuse in amps, impedance in ohms.
Check that air intake grilles on alternator are clean and unobstructed. Remove cover from non-drive and remove any fluff or dirt that may have accumulated around diode plates and exciter assembly.
Check that instruments are functioning correctly and that glass is clean.

Schedule.ScheduleTitle: Combined Heat and Power (CHP) - Gaseous Fueled Engine

Introduction.Content:
A type of internal-combustion engine using a flammable gas, such as coal gas, LPG or natural gas, as fuel.

Frequency is normally set on an hours run basis and below the main engine tasks are set using engine hours run. Each machine should
be reviewed in terms of site conditions, priority, criticality etc and the frequency for each task established.

Certain procedures will require compliance of gas safety (installation and use) regulations.
Introduction.Notes:
Before carrying out any work, check status and isolate in accordance with HASAWA (http://www.hse.gov.uk) and Electricity at Work requirements. This may require the engineer to follow a permit to work system.

The actual frequencies / run hours will vary according to the cleanliness of the combustion air, cleanliness of the engine room, engine manufacturer’s recommendations, number of engine starts and stops, and lubricating conditions indicated by oil analysis. With some engines and some operating conditions, the intervals between procedures listed below may be extended or reduced as the frequencies given are generic and need firming to the specific conditions and manufacturers recomendations of the actual engine in question.

The maintenance frequencies below are based on the number of hours run.

Engine / daily log books should be kept on all pertinent operating parameters, such as:

• Water and lubricating oil temperatures
• Individual cylinder compression pressures, which are useful in indicating blowby
• Changes in valve tappet clearance, which indicate the extent of wear in the valve system.

Task.Action: Wipe down the engine which will help show any leaks. Pay attention to abnormal sounds and odours. Check for any unaccountable speed changes.
Check all flexible connections for leaks.
Check that the air inlet louvre is clear of any debris that would impede airflow.
Take lubricating oil sample.
Task.Notes:
Additionally, take sample at each oil change.

Lubricating analysis should be completed by a commercial laboratory.  The analysis should measure the concentration of various elements found in the lubricating oil, such as bearing metals, silicates and calcium.  It should also measure the dilution of the oil, suspended and non-suspended solidas, water and oil viscosity.

Task.Action: Change lubricating oil filters.
Task.Notes:
This task should be carried out at least every 6 months.

Frequency:  500-1000 hours.

Task.Action: Clean or replace air filters
Change lubricating oil.
Task.Notes:
Frequency:  1000-2000 hours.

This task should be carried out at least every 6 months.

Additionally take sample at each oil change.

Lubricating analysis should be completed by a commercial laboratory. The analysis should measure the concentration of various elements found in the lubricating oil, such as bearing metals, silicates, and calcium. It should also measure the dilution of the oil, suspended and non-suspended solids, water and oil viscosity.

Task.Action: Clean crankcase breather.
Adjust valves.
Lubricate tachometer and auxiliary drive bearings.

Service ignition system;
Adjust breaker gap, timing, spark plug gap and magneto.
Check transistorised magneto.
Flush lubrication oil piping system.
Change air filter.
Replace turbocharger seals and bearings.

Replace piston rings, cylinder liners (if applicable), connecting rod bearings and cylinder heads.
Recondition or replace turbochargers.
Replace gaskets and seals.

Replace piston rings, cylinder liners (if applicable), connecting rod bearings and cylinder heads.
Recondition or replace turbochargers.
Replace gaskets and seals.
Recondition or replace crankshaft.
Replace all bearings.
Check the operation of all alarm and shutdown controls.
Task.Notes:
• Speed control (under and over speed)
• Lubrication (low oil pressure, high oil temperature)
• Heat removal (high coolant temperature or lack of coolant flow)
• Combustion process (fuel, ignition)
• Lubricating oil level
• Water level

Task.Action:
Check starter batteries are fully charged.
Top up with distilled water as necessary.
Inspect cells and ensure that vent holes in filter caps are clear.
Check that conducting bars and cable connections are clean and tight, any trace of verdigras to be cleaned off and connections to be coated with petroleum jelly.
Take random test or specific gravity and cell voltage.
Task.Notes:
Charge batteries as necessary (in accordance with instructions in operating log).
Top up electrolyte using pure distilled water, ensure that cells are gassing freely whilst charging.
Charge batteries to 1250 s.g. and 2.1 volts per cell, or otherwise as specified.

Re-check specific gravity:

a. Electrolyte should be kept to 12 mm above plates, only pure distilled water to be used for this purpose.
b. Topping up should be carried out before charging to ensure good mixing.
c. Ventilation holes in filter caps must be kept clean.
d. A lead acid battery is fully charged when s.g. is 1250 and all cells are at 2.4 volts. The battery cells should not be allowed to fall below 1150 s.g. or 1.8 volts.
e. When the charging rate is in doubt, a long slow charge is better than a short sharp one.

Task.Action: Check condition.
Check condition and report to client if replacement is required.
Task.Notes: Batteries should be disposed of only in accordance with H&S and Environmental Regulations recommendations.

Task.Action:
Check all electrical connections for security. Examine brush gear in the dynamo and starter and clean commutator, renew brushes as necessary.
Check operation of low oil and high coolant shutdown switches.

Open all composite control panels and associated switchgear.
Clean out interior of all panels.
Inspect all wiring for condition.
Inspect all terminations for security and overheating.
Visually check that an efficient earth is being maintained.
Open, inspect and clean any changeover switches on emergency supply system.
Check overloads are functional and are set to correct value.
Ensure fuses of correct size and type are fitted.
Examine all contacts for arcing and pitting, dress or replace contacts as applicable.
Lightly lubricate all contact faces with pure petroleum jelly.
Check relays for correct function, replace any defective components.
Examine switch-blades in isolators, ensure they are free to move.
Lubricate pivots lightly with grease, ensuring no grease comes into contact with a conducting surface.
Check for smooth operation and that switches are clearly marked.

Before carrying out the following test disconnect L.V. circuits, i.e. rotating rectifier diodes and A.V.R. circuits etc.

Carry out the following test:

a. Insulation Resistance Test on alternator and wiring. A figure of 1 megohm or above is acceptable.
b. Earth Loop Impedance Test on alternator frame.
Check that air intake grilles on alternator are clean and unobstructed. Remove cover from non-drive and remove any fluff or dirt that may have accumulated around diode plates and exciter assembly.
Check that instruments are functioning correctly and that glass is clean.
Ensure that no exhaust products are entering the area of the building where the CHP is situated.
Task.Notes: The report must be signed by the servicing engineer and the client/responsible person/clients representative. Premature failure of the plant will result if a satisfactory service is not carried out by a competent engineer. Depending on the nature/urgency of the fault and the type of premises this report may be verbal.

Task.Action:
Open gas cock and test for gas soundness, reconnect electrical services.
Test controls operation and run up engine.
Task.Notes: Check manifold gas pressure against manufacturer's settings, adjust if required.  If in doubt, check gas supply standing pressure at the meter.

Task.Action:
Check for soundness and leakage.
Emergency control valves should be checked for accessibility and operation.

Gas detector tests should be carried out in areas where gas can accumulate and linger, e.g. enclosed spaces, ducts and voids and around the pipework entry to buildings. Gas detector tests may also be carried out on joints and over known routes of underground pipework.

Leak detection fluid may be used to check exposed joints for leakage.

Soundness and leakage tests may be carried out as specified in current BS or LPGA Codes of Practice, as appropriate.

Individual appliance governors should be examined to ensure that diaphragms are sound and in good condition.

Check that the outlet pressure should be reasonably constant between low and high rev. rates.

Check manifold gas pressure against manufacturer's settings, adjust if required. If in doubt check gas supply standing pressure at the meter.
Task.Notes: See also Boilers/Heat Generators, Gas Governor or Gas Regulator (SFG 05-40).

Task.Action: Recommendations.
Task.Notes: If after servicing, the unit is considered unsafe the recommendation to the client is that it must be taken out of use. If approval for this action is refused an appropriate label must be attached to the appliance and a written report must be signed by the client/responsible person/clients representative and the gas supplier and a supervisor/manager informed.

Legislation.Content: Electricity at Work Regulations 1989
Gas Appliances (Safety) Regulations 1995
The Gas Safety (Installation & Use) Regulations 1998 (GSIUR)
Electrical Equipment (Safety) Regulations 1994
